On 8 June 2023, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) proudly welcomed 19 Prison Officers from Cohort 1-2022. All officers successfully completed their training at the Singapore Prison Training Institute (SPTI) and recited the Prison Officers' Pledge during the Graduation Ceremony held at the Home Team Academy! Meet SPSs exceptional officers, SGT Akyd Bin Shahlan and RO Chua Yee Shan, who have not only completed their training with distinction, but also received multiple awards for their exemplary performance.SGT Akyds curiosity about the inner workings behind bars and his desire for an action-packed job led him to join SPS. He shares, The training has taught me that Prison Officers do not just ensure safe and secure custody of inmates but also support their rehabilitation and reintegration to society.RO Chua found the training both challenging and fulfilling. Through local and overseas experiential learning, she realised that courage is a choice and expressed gratitude to her supportive squadmates, "We overcame many challenges and celebrated together. A friend once told me 'Don't doubt yourself' as I abseiled into a cave during the overseas training component. Those words stayed with me and reminded me to face obstacles with courage." Join us in congratulating SGT Akyd and RO Chua on their exceptional achievements. With their dedication, compassion, and unwavering commitment, they are ready to uphold the values of SPS and make a positive impact on the lives of inmates. SPSCohort122022 CaptainsOfLives BeyondPrisonWalls BehindPrisonWalls EnforcingChange SPSGraduation2023

On 1st June 2023, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) held the inaugural SPS Family Partners Day at the .The event, graced by Minister of State, Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of National Development, , was attended by more than 150 stakeholders and community partners, including social service agencies and self-help groups. The event fosters collaboration among SPS's community partners who have expertise in assisting families affected by incarceration. It also provides a platform for various agencies to share updates, resources and support mechanisms in the field of inmate and family wellbeing. The event also facilitated engagement sessions between Family Service Centres (FSCs) and SPS's community partners which provide timely interventions and assistance to inmates' families and children. These collaborative efforts are crucial, serving as a vital source of support for those in prison, helping to reduce intergenerational offending and preventing future re-offending.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChance

On 1st June 2023, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) held the inaugural SPS Family Partners Day at the .The event, graced by Minister of State, Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of National Development, , was attended by more than 150 stakeholders and community partners, including social service agencies and self-help groups. The event fosters collaboration among SPS's community partners who have expertise in assisting families affected by incarceration. It also provides a platform for various agencies to share updates, resources and support mechanisms in the field of inmate and family wellbeing. The event also facilitated engagement sessions between Family Service Centres (FSCs) and SPS's community partners which provide timely interventions and assistance to inmates' families and children. These collaborative efforts are crucial, serving as a vital source of support for those in prison, helping to reduce intergenerational offending and preventing future re-offending.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChance

The Singapore Prison Services (SPS) SPEAR Force team emerged first runner-up at the Mock Prison Riot Competition held from 28 April to 1 May 2023 in West Virginia, USA! The annual event, organised by West Virginia Division of Corrections & Rehabilitation (WVDCR) and the Worldwide Corrections Training Foundation, unites professionals from diverse fields, including corrections, law enforcement, military, and public safety, offering them immersive training and exposure to cutting-edge technology. At the Skills Competition, participants were challenged to demonstrate their communication abilities, training expertise, endurance, and exceptional teamwork. Despite a four-year hiatus, RO Ang Kian Heng led a six-men squad which demonstrated resilience and tactical brilliance. They dominated three out of five team events against 18 global competitor teams! The team battled freezing weather and tough competitors. They emerged stronger than ever to put SPS and Singapore amongst the top competitors in the international correctional tactical arena. Congratulations to all participants for doing Singapore proud! Also, stay tuned for an upcoming highlight video showcasing the SPEAR Force team's performance in the competition! TeamSPS SingaporeRepresent MockPrisonRiot2023 CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

Step inside the latest issue of the Prison News and take a deep dive into all things education! From skills training programmes and community initiatives, to inmates attending their graduation ceremony for completing the NITEC Programme, we showcase how the Singapore Prison Service helps inmates upgrade themselves and turn their lives around.In this issue, hear from Mr Kenneth Louis Victor, a former Prison Officer turned ITE lecturer, on why he decided to make a career switch. On this Mother's Day, meet the mother-son duo at the Singapore Prison Service (SPS), who shares the same passion in changing lives! With 23 years of service, SUPT Won Tien Li oversees strategic planning for inmates rehabilitation. Her son, Danial, is currently an intern in the same division as her; this makes them colleagues! Inspired by his mother's role as a prison officer and the positive impact she has made on inmates' rehabilitation journey, Danial plans to pursue a degree in Social Work in university after completing his internship at SPS. His caring personality is greatly acknowledged by SUPT Won, Danial is the best son! As a person, he is caring and kind. He looks out for those around him.Danial cherishes his mother and shared his admiration for her genuine kindness, which extends beyond work. My mum is really kind, and you can tell it is very genuine. I can be safe to say that anyone who is working with her would agree.Happy Mother's Day to all the incredible mum figures who bring love, strength, and endless warmth to our lives. You are cherished beyond words. HappyMothersDay MothersDay2023 CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) and Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG) hosted the annual SPS-YRSG Corporate Advance at the Suntec Convention Centre, themed 'Forward Corrections: Strengthening Partnerships' on 10 May 2023.The event emphasised the importance of community partnerships in helping inmates and ex-offenders achieve long-term desistance upon re-entry into society.Guest-of-honour, Mr K Shanmugam, Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law, joined over 600 stakeholders and representatives from the halfway houses and social service agencies to recognise Singapore's leadership in rehabilitating inmates and reintegrating ex-offenders through community partnerships and throughcare efforts.Minister Shanmugan also launched a book titled Correctional Rehabilitation and Psychological Interventions in Singapore: Practitioners Experience in Singapore Prison Service", which documented the experiences of SPS's psychologists and Correctional Rehabilitation Specialists working directly with inmates. Together, SPS and will forge ahead in their correctional efforts and seek long-term support and partnership from the community in preventing re-offending, for a safer Singapore.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

Meet RO Gary Loh Wen Qi - a Senior Correctional Unit Officer who supports the daily and smooth running of the Prison School at the Singapore Prison Service (SPS). The Prison School resembles a typical school, offering condensed academic curriculum. By utilising their time behind bars, inmates can attain educational qualifications that can increase their chances of obtaining better employment opportunities upon their release, and mitigate risks of reoffending. As a Senior Correctional Unit Officer, RO Loh is responsible for maintaining inmate discipline and ensuring their safe custody. His duties also include facilitating rehabilitation initiatives and providing educational opportunities for inmates. RO Lohs commitment to the holistic development of inmates is exemplified through his involvement in the multimedia hub, where inmates can learn through creating multimedia projects for SPS.RO Lohs philosophy on rehabilitation is grounded in his belief that, "The only person you are destined to become is the person you decide to be. CaptainsOfLives BeyondPrisonWalls BehindPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances PrisonSchool

Rynelissa Binte Ryhan, a Year 1 student from Temasek Polytechnic has been awarded the prestigious Home Team Diploma Sponsorship by Singapore Prison Service (SPS)! The award recognises outstanding Polytechnic students demonstrating leadership qualities and passion for strengthening Singapore's security and public safety. Rynelissa is a passionate advocate for equality in society and firmly believes that every person deserves to be given an opportunity and support to achieve their dreams. She aspires to be a Prison Officer and shares her commitment to advocate for second chances and improve the lives of others regardless of their background, race, gender, and past. Upon graduation, Rynelissa will be joining SPS as a CaptainOfLives. SPS is excited to see Rynelissa's future achievements and wishes her all the best in her studies and career.BeyondPrisonWalls BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives SG4SecondChance

The Desistor Network (DN) was launched on 15 April 2023 by Minister of State, Ministry of Home Affairs & Ministry of National Development, , who joined over 200 guests and community partners to mark this significant milestone.DN, a new initiative between the Singapore Prison Service (SPS), community partners and desistors, provides an ecosystem of prosocial support for ex-offenders through activities and programmes.So far, 53 agencies have signed up to be part of the DN. This expanding partnership with the community is critical to support the successful rehabilitation and reintegration of ex-offenders to desist from crime and drugs.By creating opportunities to foster mutual collaboration and partnerships, ex-offenders can stay accountable, help one another stay on the right path, reduce the likelihood of reoffending, and contribute back to society.DesistorNetwork BeyondPrisonWalls BehindPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

The Desistor Network is a new initiative by the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) to create a sustainable ecosystem of support for the ex-offenders desistance journey. While prosocial support is a key aspect in the desistance journey, the networking and collaboration amongst Desistor Network member agencies will also provide other opportunities, such as community service, training to become mentors and employment opportunities, to strengthen the ex-offenders desistance efforts. Successful desistors who are SPS volunteers and befrienders may also be assigned as mentors for the inmates to provide them with the support required in their rehabilitation journey. As we count down to the upcoming launch of the Desistor Network in April 2023, stay tuned and follow us to learn more about this new initiative! CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances DesistorNetwork

An art exhibition that showcased artworks by Singapores former drug abusers was held in Vienna, Austria, from 13 to 16 March 2023. New Futures featured artworks and crafts created by recovering drug abusers, emphasising the importance of strong community support to help them maintain drug-free and productive lives.The exhibition was a powerful reminder that everyone deserves a second chance. By promoting rehabilitation and reintegration, we can create a world where drug abusers can break free from the vicious cycle of addiction and become the best versions of themselves.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

Introduced in 2019, the Throughcare Volunteer Framework (TVF) aims to strengthen the Singapore Prison Services (SPS) existing efforts to enhance inmates pro-social support through close collaboration with our community partners and volunteers.One of these community partners is the Sikh Welfare Council (SIWEC), which has been working closely with SPS since 1995 to provide religious counselling services for inmates, ex-offenders and their families. SIWEC also provides aftercare support to ex-offenders by offering befriending services, sourcing for meaningful employment and providing financial aid to them.Under the TVF, SPS and SIWEC can better prepare the inmates and their families before the inmates release. This ensures that ex-offenders can continue to receive the pro-social support they need, as they work towards a life without re-offending.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4secondchances .sg

Meet CW Ragini D/O Anpazhahan, a Correctional Unit Officer with the Singapore Prison Service (SPS)! CW Ragini has always been interested to work in a uniformed organisation. She joined SPS in 2014 after some encouragement from her family. Having been with SPS for nine years, CW Ragini has taken on many concurrent roles, including being a Looking Forward facilitator and trainer. CW Ragini is also one of the key members responsible for the successful implementation of the Arts Behind Bars programme in Institution A4, which uses art as a form of rehabilitation for women inmates. This year, crafts by the women inmates will be exhibited in Vienna during the 66th Session of the UN Commission on Narcotics Drugs from 13 to 17 March 2023, under a section titled Arts for Women. The exhibition emphasises the importance of strong community support in helping drug abusers build strong family units and live drug-free and productive lives. CW Ragini's story is a testament to the many contributions that women make in the field of corrections. As a woman CaptainOfLives (COLs), she has positively impacted the lives of inmates under her charge. As we celebrate International Women's Day today, CW Ragini would like to share a simple but powerful quote from Michelle Obama, "There is no limit to what we, as women, can accomplish." InternationalWomensDay BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances JoinUS

Thank you .happiness for conducting Macrame workshops for inmates at Selarang Park Complex. During the workshops, the inmates tried their hands at the traditional craft of using cords and knots to create handmade trinkets, which will be donated to our furry friends at .Sam (not his real name), an inmate participant, shared, "I enjoyed this programme. Its not only giving me a new skill to learn but also trained me to be more focused. I hope SPS will have more programmes like this. Thank you, teachers and prison officers, for the workshop!"Workshops like this help inmates to acquire new skills, regain their confidence, give back to society, and eventually help them to undergo positive transformation and reintegrate into society. Such workshops are made possible because of the support from our community partners .WeavingHappiness CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

On 23 February 2023, 23 inmate students proudly received their newly attained NITEC in Business Services certificates during their Graduation ceremony in Changi Prison Complex.Launched in 2021, the NITEC programme for inmates is a collaboration between the Singapore Prison Service (SPS), Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG) and the Institute of Technical Education (ITE) to offer inmates the opportunity to upgrade their education while serving their sentence in prison. The Business Services Programme covers six modules: Business Communication Introduction to Data Analytics & Cyber-Security Social Media Marketing Customer Service Event Planning & Administration Sales Technique & Engagement. Amongst the inmate students who graduated from the programme is Lily (not her real name), who was incarcerated for cheating-related offences. Despite initially hesitating to apply for the programme, Lily has since demonstrated a commitment to upgrade her education and took advantage of the educational opportunities available.With better qualifications, inmates have more employment opportunities upon their release to ease their reintegration into society! CaptainsOfLives BeyondSecondChances BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

At the Reformative Training Centre (RTC), suitable rehabilitation programmes are developed for reformative trainees (RTs). They are young inmates and support is given to help them reflect on their past behaviours and encourage pro-social values and lifestyles, in preparation for their return to society.The RTs had recently completed a basketball mentoring programme, 'Triumph's Dunk'. The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) had also facilitated a friendly basketball match between the RTs and volunteers from in December 2022.Desmond Loh, a volunteer basketball coach from HUG Community Services, coached the RTs weekly for over six months. "From my interactions, inmates (i.e. RTs) and ex-offenders are no different from people outside of prison. Inmates and ex-offenders are often misunderstood because others tend to stereotype them (negatively)."Community partners and support are crucial to the successful rehabilitation and reintegration of these RTs. The support from volunteers like Desmond, and social service agencies like HUG Community Services, provide additional support to help them lead a crime and drug-free lifestyle.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

DidYouKnow? Just like students in mainstream schools, inmate students from the Prison School take their national examinations during the same period as them nationwide. On 17 February 2023, 16 inmate students received their GCE 'A' Level examination results. Among the 16 students who received their results was 'Jake', who is serving a 14-year sentence for drug-related offences. Motivated by the success stories of fellow ex-offenders, 'Jake' decided to pursue his education behind bars. The 29-year-old shared, "I never enjoyed studying, but I found the strength to persevere because of my parents' support. They always told me the results do not matter as long as I did my best. It was stressful, but I coped by playing basketball and sharing jokes with other inmates." 'Jake' was pleasantly surprised that he scored a 'C' for his weakest subject, H1 Mathematics, contrary to the 'F' he received during his preliminary examinations.Mr Tan Teck Khiang, a Principles of Accounts (POA) teacher at Prison School, would often go the extra mile for 'Jake' and other inmate students by preparing additional teaching materials to supplement their lesson plans. He hopes that all inmate students continue to do their best after release and apply the accounting principles taught in their daily lives. CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances JoinUs

DidYouKnow? Just like students in mainstream schools, inmate students from the Prison School take their national examinations during the same period as them nationwide. On 17 February 2023, 16 inmate students received their GCE 'A' Level examination results. Among the 16 students who received their results was 'Jake', who is serving a 14-year sentence for drug-related offences. Motivated by the success stories of fellow ex-offenders, 'Jake' decided to pursue his education behind bars. The 29-year-old shared, "I never enjoyed studying, but I found the strength to persevere because of my parents' support. They always told me the results do not matter as long as I did my best. It was stressful, but I coped by playing basketball and sharing jokes with other inmates." 'Jake' was pleasantly surprised that he scored a 'C' for his weakest subject, H1 Mathematics, contrary to the 'F' he received during his preliminary examinations.Mr Tan Teck Khiang, a Principles of Accounts (POA) teacher at Prison School, would often go the extra mile for 'Jake' and other inmate students by preparing additional teaching materials to supplement their lesson plans. He hopes that all inmate students continue to do their best after release and apply the accounting principles taught in their daily lives. CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances JoinUs

Introducing our CaptainsOfLives couple, CW Mu Weiqiang Cleve and CW Chen Lifen Joann!A chance meeting at the lift of their housing estate blossomed into a happy marriage of over 12 years and counting! Our first date was quite boring , as CW Chen recounted. I was still a trainee at the Singapore Prison Training Institute. When Cleve asked me out, we went on a study date at the Changi Airport. And he gave me some advice to help me with my upcoming test!Today, CW Chen is a Correctional Unit Officer overseeing inmates' well-being and rehabilitation programmes in her Correctional Unit at Institution A4.CW Mu, an officer from the Singapore Prisons Emergency Action Response (SPEAR) Force, is the Officer-in-Charge of the Prison Secure Ward, where he oversees the security and administration of the ward.On what its like to have a spouse who works in the same organisation, CW Mu reflects, It's great because were able to consult one another about our daily issues and challenges since we both know the work culture. At the end of our workday, well always make time to exercise together and then have dinner!Whats the secret behind their everlasting love? Appreciate your partners work ethic. Give your partner space when needed but always be thankful for their presence.Happy Valentines Day from the Captains of Lives! BeyondPrisonWalls BehindPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances HappyValentinesDay

Thanks to our CaptainsOfLives, our prisons remain safe and secure. A safe prison allows the smooth conduct of the rehabilitation programmes and services by our staff, community partners and volunteers for our inmates, to reduce re-offending.The two-year recidivism rate of inmates released in 2020 release cohort remained low and stable at about 20%. In order to promote long-term desistance, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) and (YRSG) will continue to collaborate with community partners and volunteers.The partnership between various community partners and volunteers provides structured support for inmates, such as the Throughcare Volunteer Framework and the upcoming Desistor Network.By galvanising the community to strengthen support for ex-offenders and their families, we can create an inclusive society for second chances, and break the cycle of re-offending and intergenerational offending.BeyondPrisonWalls BehindPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

When life gives you rice, walk for it! In partnership with the , the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) participated in the FairPrice Walk for Rice+ South East 2022 initiative, which advocates for a healthier lifestyle while contributing to a good cause. For every 300m clocked, the FairPrice Foundation () will donate one bowl of white rice, brown rice, and oatmeal to vulnerable families. Our Captains of Lives took the initiative to gather at Changi Prison Complex and clocked more than 149km in January 2023. This means 496 bowls of white rice, brown rice and oatmeal will be donated to vulnerable families in South East CDC. Together, lets pledge to make a difference for the less privileged. WalkForRice2022 BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

Meet Edna Tan, a recipient of the Yellow Ribbon Community Project (YRCP) Long Service Award (10 years), and her befriendee, Tony (pseudonym), who was incarcerated for drug-related offences.Befrienders, like Edna, volunteer with the YRCP, a grassroots initiative by the Singapore Prison Service, to provide support to ex-offenders and inmates' families, such as helping them access government and community assistance."An ex-offender requires a caring hand to lead them when they are lost, patience to listen to their fears and anxieties, and knowing that there is someone they can trust and rely on," shared Edna, reflecting on her experience as a befriender. For Tony, Edna's positive influence has motivated him to lead a crime-free life and contribute positively to society. "Edna has been my role model. She's an inspiring figure that ripples hopes," he shared.Today, he has a stable job and actively participates in various community programmes to help the less fortunate. Everyone needs a little support sometimes. This is especially true for inmates and ex-offenders who are trying hard to desist from crime and drugs to reintegrate into society. You can join Edna as a volunteer and embark on a meaningful journey to support second chances. Find out more at CaptainsOfLives YRCP BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

The Looking Forward (LF) Programme is a group-based motivational programme conducted by uniformed prison officers from the Singapore Prison Service for newly admitted inmates. LF Programme aims to ignite inmates motivation for change. Officers engage inmates in meaningful conversations on how to live a life according to their values and roles while navigating their prison sentence. Unlike most psychology-based correctional programmes, LF Programme is conducted by trained prison officers who are Correctional Unit Officers and they are supported by a specialist from the Psychological and Correctional Rehabilitation Division. During the LF Programme, inmates will better understand their strengths and weaknesses, learn skills to make better decisions, and be guided to take proactive steps in setting positive goals for their rehabilitation journey. CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChance

DidYouKnow Singapore Prison Service (SPS) facilitates virtual medical consultations for inmates requiring specialist services from hospitals. In collaboration with Changi General Hospital () and Singapore General Hospital (), SPS facilitates teleconsultation services for inmates who require specialist follow-ups at Public Healthcare Institutions (PHIs). This minimises the security risks from escorting inmates out of prison while ensuring uninterrupted clinical care for the inmates.Since its pilot in 2021, teleconsultation sessions have been adopted across a range of specialist services which include: Haemato-oncology Otorhinolaryngology Orthopaedic surgerySPS will continue to leverage technology and work with Public Health Institutions to enhance operational excellence and enforce the safe and secure custody of inmates under our care, for a safer Singapore.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

On 12 January 2023, inmate students from the Tanah Merah Prison School received their GCE O Level examination results.Among them is Siva (not his real name), who is currently serving a sentence for drug-related offences. Sivas resolve to change was partly driven by his desire to be a positive role model for his younger brother, who is also currently incarcerated. My brother always likes to follow my footsteps. I hope that when he sees that I can do well in my education, it will inspire him to also become a better man. For the 37-year-old, education is key to breaking the cycle of reoffending. I decided to study at Prison School because I did not wish to return to prison anymore. Education broadens my mind and I soon realised there are many pathways to success.SGT Louis Sim, a Correctional Unit Officer, noticed a change in behaviour among inmate students as they start preparing to take their national examinations.He would see them spending every hour of their free time revising and working on mock examination papers given by their teachers. Similarly, Mr Lin Wenwei, who teaches Mathematics at the Prison School, feels very proud of all the effort and hard work put in by the inmate students. He hopes that they will continue to remain motivated with their education, regardless of their results.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

I hope that when he sees that I can do well in my education, it will inspire him to also become a better man. For the 37-year-old, education is key to breaking the cycle of reoffending. I decided to study at Prison School because I did not wish to return to prison anymore. Education broadens my mind and I soon realised there are many pathways to success.SGT Louis Sim, a Correctional Unit Officer, noticed a change in behaviour among inmate students as they start preparing to take their national examinations.He would see them spending every hour of their free time revising and working on mock examination papers given by their teachers. Similarly, Mr Lin Wenwei, who teaches Mathematics at the Prison School, feels very proud of all the effort and hard work put in by the inmate students. He hopes that they will continue to remain motivated with their education, regardless of their results.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

Seven incarcerated fathers reunited with their children on 23 December 2022 during a family-joint session in Changi Prison Complex. The session was facilitated by Singapore Prison Service and Awful Grace, a non-profit organisation. The programme, themed 'Dads Do Care', aims to help inmates maintain and improve their relationships with their children through parent-child bonding activities, such as pottery. At the end of the session, the children brought the pottery artwork home as a memento. With parental support, children of incarcerated parents can avoid developing insecurities and anti-social behaviours. As such, sessions like 'Dads Do Care' help prevent intergenerational offending and decrease the likelihood for inmates to reoffend. CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

() .Meet SGT Muhammad Hashnul Nizam Hassan, a Correctional Unit Officer from Institution B3!Since joining SPS in 2011, SGT Hashnul supervises and guides inmates with their rehabilitation, transforming them into responsible citizens. He also engages with inmates who renounce their gang affiliations as part of SPS Gang Renunciation Programme.As a CaptainOfLives, SGT Hashnul finds great joy when he sees inmates and ex-offenders turn their lives around upon their release, forging positive relationships with their families and the community. , SGT Hashnul also plays the bagpipes, an instrument he learnt from his days in secondary school. The bagpipe is such a powerful instrument with a strong and immersive sound. When playing the bagpipes, you must be bold and daring. Bagpipes are not instruments that allow you to hide, because everyone in a 400m radius is going to hear you!Besides the bagpipes, SGT Hashnul plays the flute, clarinet, trombone, trumpet, guitar, and concertina. Stay tuned on SPS social media for a special rendition of Auld Lang Syne, performed by SGT Hashnul and our Captains of Lives to bid farewell to 2022!BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

Meet DSP Lynette Hu, the final recipient of the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) Outstanding Captains of Lives Award 2022! As a Staff Officer from Cluster Cs Operations Planning & Development, DSP Hu ensures the smooth operations of Cluster C through the planning of contingency exercises and establishing operational guidelines and policies.For DSP Hu, a CaptainOfLives must be empathetic, as well as firm and fair. She also reiterated the importance of positive and supportive environments to facilitate the in inmates rehabilitation. Reflecting on her 11-year career with SPS, DSP Hu said, "I believe having positive influences and resources in my work helped me become the person I am today. I can, in turn, use those experiences to guide inmates and become a pillar of support in their transformational journey." Outside of work, DSP Lynette spends most of her time binging all sorts of dramas! BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

Introducing the Singapore Prison Services (SPS) CaptainOfLives, DSP Simon Lee! You might have seen him as Tian Boon Kengs Reintegration Officer (RO) in three-part documentary Beyond Maximum Security'!As a Manager at the Community Corrections Command, DSP Lee works closely with a team of ROs to oversee and support the inmates emplaced under Community Based Programmes (CBPs), such as Home Detention Scheme, Halfway House Scheme and Work Release Scheme (which is now known as Employment Preparation Scheme). Under the CBPs, eligible inmates, like Boon Keng, are assessed for their suitability to serve the tail-end of their sentences in the community as supervisees.CBPs allow supervisees to practise the social skills learnt in prison within the community. The interactions with their ROs, career coaches, colleagues, families, friends, and wider communities are stepping stones to rebuild their confidence and ease their reintegration into society.DSP Lee is glad that Boon Kengs behaviours have been consistent with his resolve to change. "Since his emplacement, Im glad that Boon Keng takes the initiative to inform me of his whereabouts and we would regularly catch up on his progress to address any concerns. I hope that he will continue to persevere and break free from his old lifestyle, shared DSP Lee. Catch Beyond Maximum Security to learn how SPS continues to provide support to inmates BeyondPrisonWalls together with , community partners and volunteers.BehindPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

On 19 December 2022, 63 inmate students from the Prison School received their GCE N Level examination results!43 inmate students received their GCE Normal Academic (NA) results, while 20 received their GCE Normal Technical (NT) results.Johan (not his real name) was one of the top students in the NT examinations, receiving 3 As. Since being sentenced in October 2020 for drug-related offences, Johan resolved to improve himself through education. With his fathers encouragement, who was also incarcerated at that time, Johan enrolled in the Prison Schools N-Level programme in early 2022. Returning to school was challenging for the 23-year-old, and he initially faced some difficulties with his studies. Johan also almost dropped out of the programme when he received word that his familys hawker business was struggling due to COVID-19. However, he persevered after receiving encouragement from his family.Unlike normal schools, we have limited access to supplementary educational resources and facilities in Prison School, shared Johan. But with the support of the teachers, volunteers, Prison Officers and fellow inmate students, we are able to create a positive environment where we support one another for our examinations. Johan is currently applying for the Specialist Diploma in Social Media Marketing and Online Content Creation. Upon his release, he hopes to pursue a career in counselling.Congratulations to all the inmate students for their perseverance and hard work!CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

On 28 September 2022, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) and (SANA) launched a book entitled A Womans Journey Home: Stories of Hope and Empowerment. The book features stories from 16 women ex-offenders who have overcome drug addiction to reintegrate into the community and rebuilt their lives. On what inspired them to publish these stories, Marilyn Lee, co-author and Correctional Rehabilitation Specialist from SPS shared, We dont often hear many success stories from women ex-offenders. As such, we wanted to give these women a voice to share their experiences and highlight their unique challenges. The project spanned two years and involved interviews with many ex-offenders. Camelia Liow, co-author, and Senior Correctional Rehabilitation Specialist from SPS, reflected, The interview process was memorable for me. During these interviews, I realised that everyone is different; what works for one might not work for another. Each woman goes through a unique journey of recovery. To learn more about the different stories featured in the book, you can read the e-book version here! CaptainsOfLives BeyondPrisonWalls BehindPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

() : . On 23 November 2022, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) held its NYAA 2022 Presentation Ceremony for 81 inmates who completed the programme. Two of these inmate participants are Marc (not his real name) and Farah (not her real name), who were awarded the NYAA Gold Award for their efforts. After enrolling in the Prison School in 2021, Marc devoted his time in his studies and extra-curricular activities. This year, he was given the opportunity to participate in the NYAA programme to give back to society, while serving his sentence. Some of the activities he participated under the NYAA programme includes running for the Running to Give initiative, where a backpack sponsored by Under Armour is donated to needy individuals, for every 10km completed. He also cultivated edible plants , in conjunction with National Parks Boards () Gardening with Edibles initiative, which he found particularly memorable.RO Foo Yong Hui, a Senior Correctional Unit Officer, expressed his pride at seeing the inmate participants enthusiasm, especially when cultivating the edible plants. He remarked, it really gave the inmate participants a great sense of achievement when they see their perseverance bear fruit. Since her incarceration, Farah, found a renewed sense of purpose in providing for her family by sending home her allowance from the work programme that she participated in prison. For NYAA, Farah participated in a variety of projects, which includes recording audio articles for the visually impaired from the Singapore Association of the Visually Handicapped (). She also ran in the Running to Give initiative, as well as other physical activities. Reflecting on the NYAA, she said, The physical activities, such as the run, was especially fruitful. Its great that we were given the opportunity to keep fit and healthy while giving back to the community. CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

Meet RO Soh Chi Yiong and CW Nor Hafizah Jamal Shariff, who are among 800 CaptainsOfLives who received Singapore Prison Service (SPS) Awards on 17 November 2022. The SPS Awards recognise SPS staff for their excellent performance and outstanding contributions towards SPS work to enforce secure custody of inmates and rehabilitate them to become responsible citizens, for a safe Singapore. RO Chi Yiong works in Institution B3 and supports inmates who have renounced their gang affiliations and equips them with relevant skills for pro-social living upon their release. "Prison Officers are the most important change agents in inmates' rehabilitation journey as they will respond accordingly to our actions and positive reinforcement, and hopefully set off the second ripple of change towards their family, shared RO Chi Yiong. CW Hafizah oversees various categories of women inmates, such as those from the Assisted Living Correctional Unit, Long Sentences, and pre-release inmates. She shares, "As a Prison Officer, we can only guide and share with them the different available resources, such as upgrading themselves by taking up courses , which can be useful when they return to society." Congratulations to all SPS Award recipients for your dedication to contributing to a safer Singapore! BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

Meet Mr Philip Lim and Ustazah Nur Faiqah Binte Ramlan, two Long Service Award recipients at the SPS Volunteer Awards Ceremony 2022 held on 18 November! Mr Lim's volunteer journey began when he had an opportunity to collaborate with the Yellow Ribbon Bakery. He felt compelled to serve as a volunteer befriender with the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) after noticing how inmates without social support felt lost and lonely. As a befriender, Mr Lim listens to inmates and supports them through their troubles.Ustazah Faiqah volunteers as a religious counsellor with for Muslim inmates.She humbly shares, "My role is to facilitate and enlighten their path to seeking spiritual guidance. They are already enthusiastic about their own journey towards betterment, and I am grateful to be on this journey with them." Congratulations to all the award winners at the SPS Volunteer Awards Ceremony 2022!CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

"Since I joined the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) in 1998, I have felt a sense of pride and accomplishment because Im involved in the transformational journey of inmates and ex-offenders." RO Lim Hwee Tien is a Staff Officer (Staff Development) from the Community Corrections Command and one of the seven proud awardees of the Outstanding Captains of Lives Award 2022! As part of her duties as a CaptainOfLives, RO Lim supports the development and implementation of staff activities, such as onboarding of new staff, arranging orientation programmes, processing applications and more. She cites the various opportunities to instill and bring about transformation for inmates and ex-offenders as her constant source of pride and motivation. RO Lim believes empathy, passion and creativity are key traits that all Captains of Lives must possess to carry out their duties. Outside of work, RO Lim passes her time by cultivating shrimp both in open and closed tanks! BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) held its National Youth Achievement Awards (NYAA) Presentation Ceremony for 81 inmates who completed the programme this year. 61 Gold and 20 Silver awards were presented to the inmate participants, who showed their commitment to serve the community and strive for personal development while serving their sentence.The ceremony was graced by Guest-of-Honour Dr , Minister, Prime Ministers Office, Second Minister for Education and Second Minister for Foreign Affairs. In his speech, Dr Maliki commended the awardees for their perseverance and encouraged them to continue improving on themselves so that they can make meaningful contributions to society. This years NYAA theme, Giving Beyond, encouraged participants to think about different ways to give back to society, despite their circumstances. With the support of our CaptainsOfLives, community partners and inmates family members, participants discovered what giving beyond means to them and reinforced their commitment towards change. BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) Restorative Practices Seminar, themed 'Starting Conversations, Inspiring Connections' was held on 8 November 2022. SPS staff shared with community partners from , State Courts, , , .sg and ISCOS on how restorative practices process is incorporated in our rehabilitative effort to help inmates restore their relationships and resolve conflicts. Restorative practices enable SPS to create a more harmonious environment for inmates, their families and staff. This, in turn, helps SPS to create a safer and more effective workplace for everyone.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

At the Community Chest Awards (CCA) 2022, held at the Istana on 1 November 2022, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) was conferred the SHARE Platinum Award.Deputy Commissioner (Policy & Transformation) of Prisons, SAC Daniel Tan received the award on behalf of SPS. Ms .xueling, Minister of State for Home Affairs and Minister of State for Social and Family Development presented the award to SPS. The award recognises organisations and individuals who have made outstanding contributions to the social service sector to care for communities in need. SPS will continue to collaborate with , the philanthropy and engagement arm of .sg, to contribute and empower everyone to live with dignity in a caring and inclusive society.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls ComChestsg

On 19 November 2022, Singapore Prison Service (SPS) and jointly held the 12th annual Yellow Ribbon Community Project (YRCP) Awards and Appreciation Luncheon 2022. The YRCP is a grassroots-led initiative that provides pro-social support and assistance to families of offenders through the help of trained volunteers. At the event, a total of 115 awards were presented to grassroot divisions and individuals to recognise their contributions to YRCP over the years.Inmates, ex-offenders and their families face a wide range of challenges which includes temptations throughout their Desistance journey. Community partnership is crucial to complement the rehabilitation and reintegration work by SPS and . Together with our community partners and over 4,000 volunteers from various segments of society, SPS provides continuous support and assistance to ex-offenders and their families, to foster a stronger and an inclusive society. Thank you, Guest-of-Honour, Mr , Minister for Social and Family Development, Second Minister for Health & Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs, for attending the event.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SGSecondChances

During the Volunteer Awards Ceremony held on 18 November 2022, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) presented 417 awards to recognise the contributions and efforts of community partners and volunteers who have dedicated themselves to partner SPS in the inmates rehabilitation journey and positively impact their lives.Community partners and volunteers render their support for inmates, ex-offenders and their families through programmes and services such as religious counselling, academic tutoring, lifeskills training and befriending.SPS is thankful to its community partners and volunteers who have committed to the cause for many years, and will continue to partner them to champion second chances and support the rehabilitation and reintegration of inmates and ex-offenders. Thank you Guest-of-Honour , Minister of State, Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of National Development, for attending the event!CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

The Singapore Prison Service Awards Ceremony was held on 17 November 2022 after a hiatus due to COVID-19 pandemic.More than 800 individual and team awards were presented to CaptainsOfLives to recognise their outstanding contributions to SPS, excellent performance and dedication to contribute to a safer Singapore. These awards span across various categories, such as long service, quality service, innovation, and other outstanding contributions.To all Captains of Lives, thank you for your commitment to ensure safe custody of inmates and rehabilitate them to renew and restart their lives for the better. The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) was conferred the Staff Well-being and Development Award 2022 during the 24th International Corrections and Prisons Association Conference (ICPA), which was held in Florida, United States of America from 23 to 28 October 2022. Commissioner of Prisons, Ms Shie Yong Lee received the award on behalf of SPS. In addition to ensuring a safe and secure Singapore through the secure custody and rehabilitation of inmates, SPS remains committed to provide a nurturing and supportive workplace environment for our Captains of Lives. CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

Did you knowFor certain non-serious offences, offenders may be sentenced to one or more types of Community-Based Sentences (CBS), for example, the Day Reporting Order (DRO). A DRO requires the supervisee to report regularly for supervision at the Day Reporting Centre.At the Day Reporting Centre, the supervisee undergoes counselling and rehabilitation programmes. They may also be monitored via electronic tagging and placed under a home curfew. Once the supervisee completes CBS, their record of conviction will be removed. SPS will continue to provide rehabilitation and reintegration opportunities to inmates and ex-offenders.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWall

Introducing CW Noor Azhar Mohd Yusoff, one of the seven CaptainsOfLives who received the Outstanding Captains of Lives (OCOL) Award 2022! CW Azhar's curiosity to learn about the work of a Prison Officer led him to join the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) in 1998.As a Correctional Unit Officer, CW Azhar oversees the secure custody of inmates and rehabilitate them to become responsible citizens. He is also the Assistant Team Leader of 'Aspire Wing', a specialised unit which supervises inmates with persistent disruptive behaviours.CW Azhar also conducts Restorative Practices training, an engagement and reflection process where inmates learn to manage their emotions and take ownership of their actions as part of their rehabilitation journey.Despite the challenges he faces in his duty, CW Azhar finds it all worthwhile when inmates successfully rehabilitate and reintegrate into society."I would always advise inmates to have faith and hold on to hope. Having them think about the special people in their lives can help strengthen their resolve to change for the better."Outside of his work, CW Azhar enjoys flying drones to capture aerial photography and videography. He also occasionally races drones with a drone racing community!BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWall

() . . Mdm Phang Seok Sieng, a former Prison Officer who retired in 2017.On 17 October 2022, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) invited retired Prison Officers to tour the Selarang Park Complex and visit the SPS Heritage Gallery. They were given a glimpse of the prison history and its transformation over the years to enhance its operational effectiveness and rehabilitative capability. Among the returning retirees include a former Commissioner of Prisons, Mr Desmond Chin, who retired in 2020. He remarked, "I was delighted when I heard that the recidivism rate has dropped to 20%. It's a testament to how far SPS has come."Mr Chin added that he hopes the new generation of Captains of Lives understand their impact in helping inmates and ex-offenders to rewrite their history, change and leave a better legacy for themselves and their families.For Mr Masadi Masdawi, the visit was genuinely nostalgic as he reminisced about the old days with his former colleagues. Returning to SPS after his retirement in 1999, he reflected, "I was overwhelmed with pride to witness SPS' growth over the years. The Heritage Gallery is the life history of SPS, from its humble beginning to its present standing."CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SPSHeritage

Did you know On average, two to three wheelchair-bound inmates are escorted to various hospitals for medical appointments via private ambulances daily. In June 2022, the Wheelchair-Enable Secured Transporter (WEST) was operationalised to reduce the reliance on private ambulances. For these non-emergency cases, WEST will be used by the staff to escort wheelchair-bound inmates for their medical appointments, while ensuring their safe and secure custody.WEST leverages technology by retrofitting existing vehicles to transport up to two wheelchair-bound inmates in a single trip. WEST is also equipped with additional safety and security features which are important for prison transport operations. CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

The Family and Inmates Throughcare Assistance Haven (FITRAH), is a collaborative effort between the , the Singapore Prison Service (SPS), and .bersama.m3 partners (.sg, and MESRA). was launched in April 2019 to provide enhanced support services to incarcerated Muslim individuals and their families. Inmates are supported through incare services, such as weekly religious counselling, while ex-offenders receive aftercare support to ease their reintegration into society. As part of its aftercare services, FITRAH provides case management services for a selected group of supervisees serving the tail-end of their sentences under Community-Based Programmes. They may also be referred to community resources for employment assistance, financial assistance and religious classes. Through SPS Throughcare Volunteer Framework (TVF), inmates and ex-offenders also receive befriending services from FITRAH, where FITRAH befrienders provide a listening ear and assistance to them and their families as a form of pro-social engagement in the community. Under the TVF, SPS and FITRAH ensure that inmates, ex-offenders and their families receive the support they need as the ex-offenders work towards a life without re-offending. CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

In collaboration with the Visual Arts Hub at Changi Prison Complex and Canvas, selected artworks from inmates and ex-offenders were exhibited in Variasi Performing Arts' stage production titled 'Ruang'.Variasi Performing Arts is a non-profit arts group in Singapore that inspires young artists and a centre of excellence for practitioners of the performing arts. The showcase, which was held last month at the Arts House, sets the stage for inmate artists to showcase their talents, and motivates them to pursue their interest in arts upon release. The inmate artists poured their hearts out onto their canvases around the production theme, 'Kekosongan' or 'Emptiness'.Wielding their brushes to voice their feelings, inmate artists can pick up soft skills, such as flexibility, perseverance and patience. These values develop their self-confidence and contribute in their rehabilitation to become productive members of society after release.Swipe to witness the captivating masterpieces of the inmates! CaptainsOfLivesBehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

CW Umaparen s/o Subramaniam is one of the seven CaptainsOfLives who received the Outstanding Captains of Lives (OCOL) Award 2022. As a Trans-Tech Sustainment Officer in the Transformation & Technology Division, CW Umaparen assists and guides users in IT-related matters to ensure smooth operations. Having started his journey with the Singapore Prison Service in October 1996, he will soon mark his 26th year in service! Looking back at his long and fruitful career, CW Umaparen vividly recalls his time at the Kaki Bukit Centre - Prison School, which made him realise the important role of CaptainsOfLives in the rehabilitation of inmates. "A few inmates were keen to pursue their degree after their release and I encouraged them to set it as their personal goal and to take up the opportunity. Later on, I found out that they were doing very well after I came across some ex-offenders who were featured in newspapers for their achievements." Outside of his work, CW Umaparen enjoys exercising and keeping himself fit. He works out at least 4 to 5 times a week! BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWall

Much like secondary school and junior college students, inmate students at Tanah Merah Prison School are also hard at work revising for their examinations! Education is one of the factors that can contribute positively to the inmates rehabilitation and reintegration.Through the guidance of the teachers and CaptainsOfLives, inmates can continue to pursue further studies, upgrade themselves, and have greater employment opportunities upon release.The Singapore Prison Service wishes all students the best of luck in their upcoming examinations!BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

Frances Lee joined the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) in February 2020 after being intrigued by its key strategies, Prison Without Guards, Learning Prison and Prison Without Walls. As the Assistant Director for the Organisational Planning & Development Branch in the SPS Strategic Planning Division, Frances manages the development and implementation of organisational development initiatives to support SPS strategic direction. Her team leads innovation initiatives and oversees ground sensing efforts to identify improvement opportunities. Since June 2021, Frances has also taken an additional role as the Behavioural Insights Officer in SPS. She had the opportunity to work on My Action Plan (MAP), a project that encourages inmates to put together clear and achievable goals as part of their rehabilitation journey. We interviewed Prison Officers and inmates to learn what worked well and challenges they faced. I hope the interventions will encourage inmates to take greater ownership of their rehabilitation and plan for change with their Correctional Unit Officers. Outside her work as a CaptainOfLives, Frances runs regularly as a volunteer for the Special Olympics Singapore () since 2018. During these running sessions, she is paired with special needs athletes, who she will accompany and motivate to run. Since I run regularly for leisure, I thought, why not run and give back to the society simultaneously? Its very heartening when the athletes I have been running with show progress in their behaviours and physical fitness! BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

On World Mental Health Day, we share how the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) has been taking steps to support the mental wellness of our CaptainsOfLives, so they can continue to thrive in a correctional setting. Trainings, workshops, initiatives, and consultation projects organised by the Operational Psychology Branch aim to enhance the operational effectiveness and mental well-being of SPS staff. Personal Wellness Kits were distributed to interested staff as a coping resource to help them utilise their five senses to ground themselves in the here and now. Grounding techniques have been found to significantly reduce stress and anxiety by allowing individuals to focus on the present.Specially curated self-help resources are made easily accessible and on the go through the WeWorkWell Telegram chat for all staff. Share with us your favourite self-care tips in the comments below WorldMentalHealthDay MentalHealth BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

Share with us your favourite self-care tips in the comments below WorldMentalHealthDay MentalHealth BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

On 23 September 2022, 44 Senior Prison Officers from Cohort 2/2021 had successfully completed their Rehabilitation Officer Conversion (ROC) Course at the Singapore Prison Training Institute. The Graduation Ceremony was held at the Home Team Academy, where they also recited the Prison Officers' Pledge as a commitment to SPS mission.Among this year's cohort were RO Syed Jufri Bin Syed Omar and RO Ewen Thai, who both underwent the ROC Course to upgrade their leadership skills and correctional knowledge.Both RO Jufri and RO Thai were presented the Merit Award for their outstanding performance and leadership qualities demonstrated during their ROC Course. RO Jufri joined SPS in 2010 immediately after NS and was intrigued by SPS tagline of Rehab, Renew, Restart. He reflected on his new appointment as a Rehabilitation Officer, We must lead and be role models to those under our supervision. I honed my leadership skills by undergoing courses and investing more time and efforts to know my officers and guide them to achieve their fullest potential. I hope to continue giving my best to SPS and continue to enforce the secure custody of inmates and facilitate their rehabilitation." RO Thai first joined SPS in 2003 as a Corporal and continued to upskill himself over the years with the support from SPS. He shared his experience after completing the ROC Course, I am extremely appreciative of the intentional efforts put in by the trainers to facilitate a safe environment for discussion and sharing. It enabled us to address difficult, real-world challenges and learn from each others failures and successes." Congratulations to RO Jufri, RO Thai and the rest of the officers from Cohort 2/2021. We are proud of their commitment to upgrade themselves and contribute to SPS. Best wishes to them, and as CaptainsOfLives, we hope that they will continue to inspire everyone at every chance towards a society without re-offending.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

. CW Nurhida Binte Buang, a Visit Centre Officer at Operations & Security Command, shared that it was her inquisitiveness that led her to join the Singapore Prison Services at the age of 22! Since then, she has never looked back and continues to pursue her calling to make a difference in the lives of those who are incarcerated. CW Nurhida is one of seven CaptainsOfLives who received the Outstanding Captains of Lives (OCOL) Award 2022! As a Visit Centre Officer, CW Nurhida ensures that visits for families of inmates are conducted smoothly. She also manages the programmes held at the various Prison Link Centres. Over the course of her meaningful career, she regularly interacts with inmates and their loved ones, offering words of encouragement and guidance. I feel a sense of achievement when I see ex-offenders being able to forge a new life for themselves. I tell inmates it will not be easy; they will fall many times and they need to continue to be resilient and pick themselves up while remembering the goal they set out to achieve. Aside from donning the hat of a Captain of Lives, CW Nurhida loves cycling, caf hopping and going to theme parks. One of her bucket list is to visit the various theme parks around the world! BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

This year, the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run has been rebranded to Yellow Ribbon Race (YRR) 2022 to provide opportunities for all to show their support for second chances, as part of building an inclusive society. The physical run/walk segment is also back since the two-year hiatus due to COVID-19, in addition to a virtual race! After months of planning, the YRR physical run/walk was successfully held this morning. Despite the bad weather, we were thrilled at the turnout of about 3,000 high-spirited participants, all geared up and determined to complete the race! This event would not have been successful without the support from our community partners, volunteers, CaptainsOfLives, ex-offenders and their families, and all YRR participants, who turned up in force, despite the rain, to show their support for second chances. Thank you to , Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance, .ylm, Minister for Communications and Information, and Second Minister for Home Affairs and , Minister of State, Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of National Development for joining us at the event. If you missed our physical run, fret not! You can still participate in the Virtual Race, with foot , water, and wheels mode, which is still ongoing till 30 September 2022! It's never too late to join the YRR 2022 and show your support for second chances.Register now: (Link in bio)YRrace2022 SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

On 23 September 2022, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) welcomed Prison Officers from Cohort 2-2021. They had successfully completed their training at the Singapore Prison Training Institute and recited the Prison Officers' Pledge during their Graduation Ceremony at the Home Team Academy! Following the footsteps of her father, SGT Chua Tandra joined SPS to inspire change in the lives of others. Under the Home Team Diploma Sponsorship Programme, SGT Chua previously had the opportunity to serve her internship with SPS Staff Development Division. She recounts, I have grown up around relatives who will now be my colleagues. These pleasant initial encounters gave me the impression that SPS is an organisation that provides opportunities and cares for the well-being of their staff. For her outstanding performance demonstrated during her training, SGT Chua received the Academic Studies Award and the Physical Fitness Award (Female).SGT Muhammad Rusdi Bin Badrit took a leap of faith to embark on a career as a Prison Officer after working nine years working in the audio and music industry, as he wanted to gain new experiences and knowledge that would let him make a positive contribution to the community. On how his impressions changed since becoming a Prison Officer, SGT Rusdi reflects, After my attachment in the correctional units, I realised the importance of the roles of Prison Officers in rehabilitating inmates. Beyond enforcing order and discipline, we must be mindful and humane in guiding inmates to influence them to become responsible citizens. For his excellent performance throughout his training, SGT Rusdi was conferred the Outstanding Trainee Award, Operational & Tactical Excellence Award, and the Physical Fitness Award (Male). Congratulations to our new Prison Officers aka CaptainsOfLives, as they embark on their careers enforcing the secure custody of inmates and rehabilitating them to become responsible citizens for a safer Singapore! BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) is the host of this year's Asian and Pacific Conference of Correctional Administrators (APCCA) from 19 to 23 September 2022. The conference, which includes a Plenary Session and a Fireside Chat, provides a platform for government agencies responsible for prison and correctional administration to meet, exchange ideas and share practices in corrections. Chairman of APCCA 2022 Organising Committee, AC Benjamin Chia shares some insights about organising a virtual conference, the first of its kind for APCCA. It is a virtual conference due to the COVID-19 situation."I noticed a great desire to connect and learn from one another after the two-year hiatus, evidenced by more than 700 participants who signed up this year; that is three times more than regular conferences at SPS!""Two days into the event, we experienced warm enthusiasm from countries who prepared their presentation items thoroughly and participated in rehearsals to make it a successful event. In the future, we will look into reaching out to more correctional staff with virtual segments. This way, we make sharing and learning accessible to all."CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls APCCA2022

The Rise Above Halfway House is ready to receive its first batch of women supervisees from end September 2022.A collaboration between the Singapore Prison Service and , Rise Above Halfway House will be the first secular halfway house for women supervisees undergoing the community-based programmes.Rise Above Halfway House creates a safe space to promote and strengthen supervisees resolution to lead a socially responsible lifestyle, easing their reintegration into society and prevent re-offending. Their programmes and services are grounded in family-centric practices, trauma-informed, and gender-responsive interventions which are conducted by an all-women team of volunteers and staff. Supervisees also receive counselling support and participate in therapeutic group work sessions and educational talks as part of their reintegration into society.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances PPIS

Since the introduction of the Throughcare Volunteer Framework (TVF) in 2019, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) has been strengthening its existing efforts to enhance inmates pro-social capital through close collaboration with our community partners and volunteers. One of these community partners is (PFS), which has been working closely with SPS since the 1950s to provide support to inmates, ex-offenders and their families. Over the years, PFS has extended their services from providing religious counselling to inmates, to include aftercare support for ex-offenders and their loved ones. More recently, PFS has been actively undertaking pre-sentence counselling for its beneficiaries, which provides a more holistic spectrum of social support services for inmates' rehabilitation and reintegration journey. Under the TVF, SPS and PFS can better prepare inmates and their families prior to the inmates release, by ascertaining their needs in advance. This ensures that ex-offenders are able to continue receiving the support they need, as they work towards a life without re-offending. BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SGSecondChances PrisonFellowshipSingapore

" - ."Meet DSP Keonz Quek Yong Qiang, one of the seven CaptainsOfLives who won the Outstanding Captains of Lives (OCOL) Award 2022! DSP Quek, a Senior Correctional Rehabilitation Specialist at the Psychological and Correctional Rehabilitation Division, assesses and delivers the Psychological Correctional Programme for drug inmates. He also conducts training and coaching for his teammates. Having spent eleven years as a Prison Officer, DSP Quek ascribes his decade-long career to his belief in second chances for inmates and ex-offenders. "The mission entrusted to me as a Captain of Lives and seeing how people grow and change for the better motivates me to perform my duties. It is one of the most meaningful careers that inspires many, and a career one will be proud to be a part of."In his free time, DSP Quek enjoys hiking and frequently goes for a run around his neighbourhood. Fun fact: He volunteers with the as a Volunteer Special Constabulary! BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

From now until 11 September 2022, visit the Five Blessings () on display as part of the Mid-Autumn Festival celebrations at Gardens by the Bay! With the theme Reunion this year, the Five Blessings display is a collaboration between the Singapore Prison Service, Yellow Ribbon Project and . The five tiger lanterns were designed and painted by 19 women inmates undergoing the Arts Behind Bars Programme. It provides an opportunity to showcase their artistic talents and give back to society, as part of their rehabilitation and reintegration journey. Congratulations to SUPT Tan Wee Teck and ASP Kelvin Ang Chuean Wee for receiving the Exemplary Leader Award and the Exemplary SkillsFuture @ Public Service Award respectively at the Public Sector Transformation (PST) Awards 2022! During the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, SUPT Tan led his team in planning and coordinating different safe management measures within prison. He was also instrumental in spearheading various rehabilitation initiatives in Institution B1 that transformed the rehabilitation culture for inmates. Under his leadership, Institution B1 has seen transformational changes to inmates rehabilitation, strengthened operational capabilities and levelled up staff competencies. As Head of the Singapore Prisons Emergency Action Response (SPEAR) Force Operations, ASP Ang oversees the deployment of SPEAR operations, planning and doctrine. Having acquired knowledge in various Information and Communications Technology fields like 3D mapping, 3D printing, robotics, drones and electronics, he embraced the spirit of continuous learning and innovation, and leveraged technology to enhance SPEARs tactical operations.Our heartfelt congratulations to the winners for their contributions to SPS and the Public Service! CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

During the Home Team National Day Observance Ceremony 2022 on 4 August 2022, three of our CaptainsOfLives, SGT Nurazmie Bin Abdul Talib, CW Ganeshwaraa @ Steven S/O C Ponniah and Ms Ng Zeying, Cherlynn, were awarded the Minister for Home Affairs National Day Awards (Individual) for their exemplary work with the Singapore Prison Service (SPS)! SGT Nurazmie had devoted over 11 years of his career to the rehabilitation of inmates. As a Reintegration Officer in the Release on Supervision (ROS) team, he has had to respond decisively, and coordinate with multiple stakeholders in order to de-escalate situations to ensure the safety of the supervisees.Likewise, CW Steven has demonstrated consistency in delivering excellent work and strong problem-solving skills over his 20-year career with SPS. During the COVID-19 pandemic, he played a pivotal role coordinating the inmates vaccination exercise in Cluster B and the procurement of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE). He also showed great compassion to those around him, constantly checking in on his staffs well-being and ensuring the safety of those under his charge throughout the pandemic.With a career spanning over 10 years with SPS, Ms Ng has taken on many roles rehabilitating inmates towards positive change. Currently a Correctional Rehabilitation Specialist, Ms Ng facilitates information sharing and works to enhance the throughcare rehabilitation efforts for inmates. She also provides training for SPS staff and rehabilitation partners, where she demonstrates admirable leadership skills and dedication.The Minister for Home Affairs National Day Awards (Home Team Volunteers) was also conferred to Ms Laila Bte Abu Hasan, a SPS volunteer from Family and Inmates Throughcare Assistance Haven (FITRAH). A passionate volunteer for over 19 years, Ms Laila has contributed greatly to the group religious counselling sessions for women inmates at Institution A4. She also provides support to a group of ex-offenders who continue to seek her guidance even after their release from prisons.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls NDP2022 HTVolunteers

# ! ASP Wong Ying Kit and Mr Surender Singh s/o Jagdish Singh, who have spent over three decades as CaptainsOfLives, share how the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) has transformed across the years. ASP Wong became a Prison Officer in 1990 after chancing upon a pamphlet advertising a career with SPS. Since then, hes had many opportunities to rise through the ranks, working to ensure the secure custody of inmates and help them in their rehabilitation. When reflecting on the impact of his work over the years, ASP Wong shared that it has been a fulfilling journey guiding inmates towards becoming better citizens. - . ."For Mr Singh, his tenure with SPS has also been a meaningful one. He first joined SPS in 1991 as a Prison Officer before converting to a civilian scheme in 2017. , . , . , . , , -.SPSHeritage BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

In partnership with the Singapore Chefs' Association, the annual Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition (YRCC 2022) has come to an end! In line with the theme A Taste Of Home, inmate participants were tasked to re-define local hawker food with chicken as the main ingredient. Through the competition, inmate participants gained insights into the food and beverage industry and developed the confidence to create their own recipes. The skills and experiences gained from this competition further enhances their employment opportunities after release.After an intense competition, Felix (not his real name), creator of the dish, Home ( ), emerged as champion!Thank you, MOS Associate Prof Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim (), trusted partners, chef mentors and our CaptainOfLives for making this event a success!BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls YRCC2022 YellowRibbonCulinaryCompetition ATasteOfHome

. Introducing RO William Yeo Chin Boon, one of the seven CaptainsOfLives awarded the Outstanding Captains of Lives (OCOL) Award 2022! As the Officer-in-Charge of an Institutional Control Centre (ICC), RO Yeo oversees the day-to-day operations of the ICC, together with the Prison Officers under his charge to monitor the safety and security of the institution. RO Yeo also expressed his sense of fulfillment in his role as a Captain of Lives, rehabilitating inmates to transform their lives for the better. In my former role as the Institution Programme Officer in Institution A1, I oversaw the conduct of family programmes for inmates. Its really priceless when you see the inmates treasure every opportunity they get to spend some time with their loved ones. The positive bonds and familial support they build go a long way to help inmates in their rehabilitation and reintegration journey. When hes off the clock, the loving family man spends his time going to the cinema with his family. He also dabbles in Radio Control (RC) model cars, where he will meet up with other enthusiasts to assemble the model cars and race one another! BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) congratulates our CaptainsOfLives who received the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) Scholarship and Sponsorship Awards 2022! SPS is also proud to have four of our COLs - SGT Aaron Koh Tat Hin, SGT Anisah Rahziah Binte Abdul Rahman, SGT Chua Yong An and SGT Marilyn Tan Ai Ling, awarded the book prize and/or best dissertation winners.We wish them all the best in their learning journey. SPS will continue to support the learning and development of our COLs so that they inspire everyone at every chance towards a society without re-offending.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWallsSG4SecondChances

In April 2021, Muneeswaran Community Services (MCS) partnered with the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) to provide befriending services to newly released inmates under the Throughcare Volunteer Framework (TVF). They provide a listening ear and guidance to the ex-offenders to ease their reintegration into the community.One of these volunteers is Ms B Thanabavany Naidu, who is passionate about helping others in the community. On her experience as a befriender, she recounts, I always listen to them and try to understand the issue from their perspective. As a befriender, my goal is to motivate the ex-offenders to break free from the mistakes of their past and build a positive relationship with their family and community.MCS also provides social services to ex-offenders such as assisting with referrals for financial or employment assistance, providing spiritual counselling and welfare aid for their families.By providing aftercare support to ex-offenders through the collaboration of SPS community partners and volunteers, we can break the cycle of offending and reoffending to keep Singapore safe and secure!CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

Singapore Prison Service (SPS) and (YRSG) provides opportunities to inmates to undergo work programmes with market-relevant skills. Such programmes cultivate positive work ethics and also facilitate their reintegration into Singapores workforce upon their release.Since 2004, SPS and YRSG partnered New Hope Food Industries Pte Ltd, a subsidiary company of , in the manufacturing of Frozen Puff Pastries under the Private Partnership Scheme.Under the supervision of our CaptainsOfLives and staff from New Hope, inmates are exposed to the day-to-day production processes of puff pastry manufacturing - from the cooking of fillings, lamination of dough, product forming, product packaging as well as stock inventory and product quality examination.Inmates on the programme undergo on-the-job training (OJT) with the workshop instructors, and they are issued an OJT certificate upon completion, which helps improve their employment opportunities after their release. Inmates will also develop a sense of responsibility and discipline, having to comply with strict food handling regulations and working in a structured work environment. They also develop a renewed sense of purpose through their work, as they can contribute back to the community while serving their sentence.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances
