, . ASP Ng RiyingAfter working in the private sector for three years, ASP Ng joined the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) in 2009, in search of a meaningful career which could help make a difference in someones life.Upon the completion of her training, ASP Ng was assigned to work at the former Changi Womens Prison/Drug Rehabilitation Centre (CWP). It was there she learnt that she needed to be able to adapt quickly to respond to any situation as part of her duties as a prison officer.She recalls one incident where she had to separate an inmate from her cellmates after a heated argument. When the inmate calmed down, ASP Ng found her in tears. She took the time to speak with the inmate, who had from then on, opened up to ASP Ng about her issues. The day before her release, she thanked ASP Ng for her encouragement, which helped her change for the better. Since then, ASP Ng has felt a tremendous sense of pride in her role as a prison officer, which has allowed her to inspire change in the lives of others. , ASP Ng has also been practising Muay Thai for nearly four years. Besides keeping fit, Muay Thai also sharpens her focus and concentration, when learning the techniques in class.ASP Ng reflects, Muay Thai has taught me to remain calm and resilient when facing challenges. These are useful traits to have as CaptainsOfLives, as we need to adapt to change and sometimes make decisions quickly.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

When drug abusers are arrested for the consumption of controlled drugs, they will be detained for rehabilitationat the Drug Rehabilitation Centre (DRCs). Under the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) DRC regime, inmates will undergoin-carerehabilitationprogrammes during their incarcerationdepending on their risks and needs. They will also continue to receive aftercare support upon release, to help them lead a drug-free life. During the in-care phase, inmates undergoevidence-informedprogrammes, such as psychology-based correctional programmestotarget attitudes and beliefs regarding drug abuse,and family programmesto strengthen familial bonds. Theseprogrammeshelptoequip inmates with skills toincreasetheir chances for successful rehabilitation and reintegration. Suitableinmates serving the tail-end of theirdetentionwill also undergo programmes to prepare them for their emplacement on Community-Based Programmes (CBPs). During CBPs, supervisees are allowed to serve their remainingdetentionby working in the community under the supervision of SPS. Supervisees will also be subjected to a supervision period of up to five years by the Central Narcotics Bureau (.drugfreesg), to ensure that they do not relapse into the cycle of drug abuse. Our CaptainsOfLives, community partners and volunteersare committed to rehabilitating drug offenders to keep Singapore safe and drug-free! DrugFreeSG BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

Positive family support is crucial to the successful rehabilitation of inmates and ex-offenders, helping them to break the cycle of reoffending. This Fathers Day, the Singapore Prison Service and volunteers from organised a special flower arrangement workshop for women inmates.The flowers were then delivered to their fathers with a special handwritten card. For some, this is the first time they gave their fathers a gift. Aside from expressing appreciation, the workshop also allowed inmates to reflect on their mistakes, make amends with their families and rebuild familial relationships. CaptainsOfLives HappyFathersDay BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) and Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG) held the annual SPS-YRSG Corporate Advance today. During his opening remarks, Guest-of-Honour Associate Professor , Minister of State, Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of National Development, praised the collaborative efforts of SPS, YRSG and their partners in reducing the two-year recidivism rate for the 2019 release cohort to 20%, which is among the lowest in the world.The SPS Heritage Gallery was also officially unveiled by MOS Faishal, together with Commissioner of Prisons, Ms Shie Yong Lee.The SPS Heritage Gallery, features four zones which document the progression of the corrections landscape in Singapore from the 1800s till present day, and the transformation of SPS from a custodial agency to a leading correctional agency. It also pays tribute to the contributions of past and present CaptainsOfLives.The Gallery also showcases the formation of the Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-offenders (CARE) Network in 2000, launch of the Yellow Ribbon Project in 2004 and mobilisation of community action in giving second chances to ex-offenders.Stay tuned to find out more about our SPS Heritage Gallery!SPSHeritage BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

Work programmes for inmates help cultivate positive work ethics and impart market-relevant skills for their reintegration into Singapores workforce upon their release. These programmes are administered by community partners. Connect Centre Pte Ltd has been partnering with the Singapore Prison Service and to provide skills training such as sales and customer service, to the inmates before they are placed on the work programmes. The inmates are attached to the call centre, under the supervision of our CaptainsOfLives and Team Leaders from Connect Centre. Inmates are trained and guided by professional consultants to manage difficult situations and help them gain an understanding in customer service work, which requires patience and empathy. Such values, positive work ethics and structured work routine will facilitate their reintegration into society. BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

The Throughcare Volunteer Framework (TVF) was introduced in 2019 to enable the volunteers of the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) to continue befriending and mentoring ex-offenders after their release. The volunteers provide emotional support and link them with other prosocial networks in the community. In 2019, SPS partnered with the Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-offenders (CARE) Network agencies to conduct TVF-based programmes in prisons. Since then, we have seen an increase in the number of community partners coming onboard this initiative.SPS remains committed in our mission to enforce secure custody of inmates and rehabilitating them to become responsible citizens, for a safer Singapore!Stay tuned over the coming months as we shed light on the work of these community partners and volunteers!CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

The Throughcare Volunteer Framework (TVF) was introduced in 2019 to enable the volunteers of the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) to continue befriending and mentoring ex-offenders after their release. The volunteers provide emotional support and link them with other prosocial networks in the community. In 2019, SPS partnered with the Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-offenders (CARE) Network agencies to conduct TVF-based programmes in prisons. Since then, we have seen an increase in the number of community partners coming onboard this initiative.SPS remains committed in our mission to enforce secure custody of inmates and rehabilitating them to become responsible citizens, for a safer Singapore!Stay tuned over the coming months as we shed light on the work of these community partners and volunteers!CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

On 6 May 2022, the Singapore Prison Service welcomed 32 Prison Officers from Cohort 1/2021. They had successfully completed their training at the Singapore Prison Training Institute and recited the Prison Officers' Pledge during their Graduation Ceremony at the Home Team Academy.For Sergeants, they went through four months, while Rehabilitation Officers underwent nine months of training that each comprised correctional, physical, and tactical readiness training.During the ceremony, RO Toh Jun Hong, who clinched the Outstanding Trainee Award (Rehabilitation Officer), shared an inspiring speech with his fellow cohort mates, "I always wanted a rewarding and meaningful career that knowing what I do can make a positive difference in the lives of others."SGT Nur Rashidah Binte Rumli, who received the Outstanding Trainee Award (Sergeant), expressed her appreciation to her fellow trainees and trainers for a memorable training experience.Congratulations to our new Prison Officers as they embark in their careers as CaptainsOfLives!BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

This MothersDay, RO Eo Hwee Mui, Jervel, shared how she juggles her time as a Prison Officer and a mother of three! Since joining the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) in 2005, Jervel, has built a meaningful career rising through the ranks from a Prison Officer (Sergeant) to a Prison Officer (Rehabilitation Officer). As a CaptainOfLives, she has been given many opportunities to excel in her work and demonstrate her leadership abilities. Reflecting on her time being a woman in a male dominated workplace, Jervel shared, I feel comfortable working in SPS because Im treated as an equal among my peers.When I first found out that I was expecting twins, I spoke to my supervisor about the possibility of going on no-pay leave and they supported me. Such arrangement allows me to spend quality time with my children, watch them grow up and be there for them in their formative years.When asked if she has any advice for other working women, she said, For me, communication is key. Speak with your spouse at home to achieve a mutual understanding in caring for the children and handling the chores. Also seek support from your supervisors and colleagues at work. I am thankful that my working environment in SPS has helped me to achieve a work-life harmony.To all Mothers out there, we wish you a Happy Mothers Day! BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

As a CaptainOfLives, I learnt over the years that we should always strive to give supervisees the chance to reach their full potential.After working a few years in the social service sector as a case worker and counsellor, Muzafar Muneer Mustafar joined the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) in April 2012, because he became interested in tackling the rising trend of repeat and new young drug abusers.As a Senior Correctional Rehabilitation Specialist (CRS) in Community Corrections Command, Muzafar conducts criminogenic risk assessments and formulates rehabilitation plans for supervisees under the Mandatory Aftercare Scheme through core correctional practices and correctional case management. He also manages a team of Lead Specialists and CRSes in delivering rehabilitation programmes to the supervisees in the community, as well as conducts clinical supervision.The close partnership and collaboration that we have at SPS between the Reintegration Officers, CRSes and Social Service Professionals can make a difference, even to the most hardened inmate.Outside of work, Muzafar is an avid fan of Star Wars. Hes a member of the 501st Legion Singapore Garrison, a local costuming group of passionate Star Wars fans. The group is an active supporter of several charities, where companies and organisations would engage garrison members to turn up in their Star Wars costumes. Some of the Star Wars costumes that Muzafar owns include the Shadow Guard, a 181st Tie Interceptor Pilot and a Galactic Marine from the Attack of the Clones.This year, Muzafar will be attending StarWarsDay at Suntec City, held on 4 May and 7 to 16 May 2022.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls MayThe4thBeWithYou

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) would like to express our heartfelt thanks to for taking the time to break fast with our CaptainsOfLives and inmates.During his visits to SPS, Associate Professor Faishal met with the inmates of Institution B5 and Tanah Merah Prison School. He gave words of encouragement and support to them.He also spoke with the prison officers to learn more about the various rehabilitation programmes available to help inmates in their rehabilitation and reintegration journey.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

Our inaugural batch of 17 inmates have graduated from the TAP (Train and Place) & Grow Precision Engineering Training Programme!They received their Workforce Skills Qualifications (WSQ) Advanced Certificate in Precision Engineering from Assoc Prof Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim , Minister of State, Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of National Development during a graduation ceremony on 27 April 2022.The programme, a collaboration that started in 2020 between , Precision Engineering and Technology Association and Nanyang Polytechnic , is part of YRSG's TAP & Grow initiative to partner like-minded employers, training institutions, and community partners to set up training academies in the prisons. The WSQ training provides inmates with opportunities to develop essential skills to embark on a career in the precision engineering industry, or pursue a further education to obtain a Diploma in Precision Engineering upon their release. Their persistence and determination have paid off. Join us in congratulating them for their achievement!BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

Remember Khai from Inside Maximum Security? We caught up with him to find out how hes doing during the fasting month of Ramadan.For Muslims, Ramadan is not only about fasting - it is also about forgiveness, sacrifices and self-reflection to improve oneself spiritually. It is also where one spends time with their loved ones to eat pre-dawn meals and break their fast together.For Khai, this is the second year he is spending Ramadan in prison since his incarceration in December 2020. In the past, Khai would let his emotions control his actions, never stopping to think about the consequences. This eventually resulted in a series of incarcerations throughout his youth. It was only during his latest incarceration, shortly after the passing of his father, that Khai finally realised that he had to change. He recounts, Its been very challenging for me since my fathers passing just before I went into prison. Fasting for me these past two years feels empty without him and my family. He would often spend his days reflecting, reading the Quran and learning from other inmates who have also resolved to improve themselves spiritually.The thought of his mother and young daughter also keeps Khai inspired to change himself for the better, with the letters from them being a constant source of motivation for him.Just before he passed on, my father reminded me to take care of my mother upon my release from prison. He never gave up on me despite all my mistakes. If he believed I could still change, then I cant give up on myself too. I have to believe that I can be a better man.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls TransformingLivesWithYou

In the past, Khai would let his emotions control his actions, never stopping to think about the consequences. This eventually resulted in a series of incarcerations throughout his youth. It was only during his latest incarceration, shortly after the passing of his father, that Khai finally realised that he had to change. He recounts, Its been very challenging for me since my fathers passing just before I went into prison. Fasting for me these past two years feels empty without him and my family. He would often spend his days reflecting, reading the Quran and learning from other inmates who have also resolved to improve themselves spiritually.The thought of his mother and young daughter also keeps Khai inspired to change himself for the better, with the letters from them being a constant source of motivation for him.Just before he passed on, my father reminded me to take care of my mother upon my release from prison. He never gave up on me despite all my mistakes. If he believed I could still change, then I cant give up on myself too. I have to believe that I can be a better man.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls TransformingLivesWithYou

Rise Above Halfway House (RAHWH) is a safe, structured and holistic space for women supervisees undergoing community-based programmes to facilitate their reintegration and help them reconnect with the community. RAHWH, Singapores first secular all-women residential halfway house, was established in 2021 under a partnership between PPIS (Singapore Muslim Women's Association) and the Singapore Prison Service. Renovations at RAHWH has started and its residents will move in later this year. On 23 April 2022, as part of an initiative to connect with the community and foster stronger community ties, RAHWH staff joined PPIS President, Mdm Hazlina Abdul Halim, and Chief Executive Officer, Mdm Tuminah Sapawi, to distribute 100 bottles of Hari Raya cookies to its nearby neighbours at St Georges Lane. Special thanks to the YRI bakery, a subsidiary of Yellow Ribbon Singapore , for sponsoring the cookies! credits: PPIS PPIS RAHWH BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

DIRECT (Digitalisation of Inmate Rehabilitation and Corrections Tool) was introduced in 2019 to provide inmates with access to a suite of digital applications to facilitate their rehabilitation and self-learning. It also helps familarise inmates with the use of technology, which eases their reintegration into society upon their release.DIRECT allows inmates to send and receive e-letters to keep in touch with their loved ones. They can also access materials which will help in their rehabilitation journey.Over the years, the Singapore Prison Service has leveraged technology to enhance our operational efficiency and effectiveness, while enforcing the secure custody of inmates and rehabilitating them for a safer Singapore.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

Join us in CelebratingSGFamilies! Family support is one of the key factors in contributing to the inmates successful rehabilitation. Fostering strong familial bonds and teaching inmates to communicate better with their children, help to break the cycle of reoffending and reduce the likelihood of intergenerational offending, for a safer Singapore. In our March issue of Prison News, find out how our CaptainsOfLives and community partners support inmates rehabilitation and help their families through the various family-based programmes. BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

ICYMIThe Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) Skills Training Assistance to Restart (STAR) Bursary signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the Singapore Teochew Foundation on 1 April 2022. Under the MOU, the Singapore Teochew Foundation will donate $2 million to the YRF STAR Bursary over the next10 years. Jack (pseudonym), an inmate beneficiary of the YRF STAR Bursary, has been in and out of prison for over 20 years. Wanting to become a better role model for his children, he decided to improve his life by pursuing part-time Bachelor of Science in Marketing during his current prison sentence. The 49-year-old recalls, I was raised by a single father who passed away when I was a teenager. Ive been alone most of my life and did not have much support, which led me to my current circumstances. Thats not something I want for my children. I hope that by getting a degree, I can be a good example for them.On receiving the YRF STAR Bursary, Jack is grateful for the support from YRF. With no savings, I feel that the Bursary will really help others like me. Now, I dont have to worry about course fees and just focus on my studies.Pursuing education behind bars provides inmates with an opportunity to upgrade their academic qualifications as part of their rehabilitation, and increases their chances of securing better employment opportunities after their release.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

A conversation in 2007 between John (pseudonym) and his then 10-year-old son shifted something within the once hardened secret society member. From that moment, John took steps in prison to make changes about himself. He actively took part in the faith-based counselling sessions and was part of the inaugural Gang Renunciation Programme in 2009. This was where he pledged to renounce all affiliations to his gang. Fellow inmates discouraged him, but John was firm in his resolve.For years, everyones problem was my problem. It was time I took back the power I gave away so easily. John also participated in the violence intervention programme that equipped him with skills to cope with his troubled past. I now practice the 30-second-rule. Before I react, I count till 30. Till today its one of the most helpful tips I received. Since his release in 2014, John has supported other inmates who are facing similar struggles and challenges. As an (ISCOS) Titan volunteer and Outreach Coordinator, he counsels inmates and supports them in their journey of change. BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

. , . SGT Zulhilmi The search for a meaningful career led SGT Zulhilmi to the Singapore Prison Service in 2018. As a Personal Supervisor at the Reformative Training Centre, his duties include enforcing the safety and security of inmates, as well as meaningfully engage those under his care, most of whom are young offenders. , Zulhilmi is a budding musician who writes and composes his own music. This multi-instrumentalists passion for songwriting began in his early school years, where he taught himself to play the drums, guitar and keyboard. Recently, SGT Zulhilmi was able to showcase his musical talents when he joined Mediacorp Surias songwriting competition . Putting all his skills to highlight a serious social issue, Zulhilmi wrote a song to motivate women victims of domestic abuse. For his moving composition, he was awarded first runner-up for the competition. I feel grateful that I had the opportunity and support from my family, friends and colleagues, Zulhilmi reflected. What I love about music is its ability to connect people together and shed light on important issues. CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls BeyondTheUniform

On 22 February 2022, 17 inmate students from the Tanah Merah Prison School received their GCE A-Level examination results. Eight of them qualified for polytechnic, private degree courses or full-time local university courses.Amongst them was Jason (not his real name), who was sentenced to five years imprisonment for drug-related offences and was released under the Mandatory Aftercare Scheme in February 2022. He scored 4 As and 1 B.Jasons resolve to change was ignited after reading a book while in prison. Im actually an avid reader, and one day while reading Denial of Death by Ernest Becker, I realised I should make the most of my time while in prison. Jason decided to pursue his A-levels as it was the best way to show his commitment to change. For the next nine months, he studied rigorously until news of his grandmothers passing shocked him into grief.It was really very hard for me when I got the news. As the eldest grandson, she was always worried about me and because of my mistakes I couldnt be with her when she was sick, shared Jason. Remembering his late grandmothers wish for him to do better, Jason converted his grief into motivation.Jason credits his General Paper teacher, Mdm Michelle Cheam, for inspiring him. Jason was very hardworking. Sometimes, handing two to three essays instead of just the one he was required to write. He did that to improve his writing, Mdm Cheam recalled. I hope that his result will continue to motivate him towards a bright future, and he will create a legacy that he has always wanted to achieve.Today, Jason aspires to attain a law degree and become a lawyer, where he hopes to use his knowledge to help others like him.Congratulations to all the inmate students for their perseverance and hard work! BeyondPrisonWall BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives SG4SecondChances

We started in the same squad back in 1991. Both of us are very active in sports. We used to play badminton and hang out together after work.What started out as a friendship soon blossomed into a fulfilling marriage and partnership that has lasted over 30 years for our CaptainsOfLives, RO Charlvi Tan and ASP Toh Siew Choo.Suddenly, something changed, and I held her hand one day while crossing the street and here we are 30 years later, RO Tan recalled. Its definitely been an adventure, ASP Toh said. The good thing about being married to another Prison Officer is that you have someone who understands what youre going through. Were able to share our experiences, learn from each other, share our problems and come up with solutions together. Rising through the ranks together, the couple, who started as Junior Prison Officers and are now Senior Prison Officers, is grateful for the opportunities with the Singapore Prison Service (SPS).It feels nice to be recognised for your efforts, the father of two said. We always attend each others promotion ceremony to the point that our colleagues joke about meeting us at all ceremonies! Today, ASP Toh, is the OC Medical Centre of Institution A4, where she oversees and manages the prison operations of a Medical Centre in Institution A4. RO Tan is a Housing Unit Officer at Institution B2, where he oversees the daily operations in the housing unit with inmates pending Courts sentencing and instill order and discipline among them. Together with their team members, both ASP Toh and RO Tan always look for opportunities to motivate the inmates in their rehabilitation journey through the engagements during their daily prison operations.Whats the secret behind their everlasting love? Understanding and learning to trust one another is key, you must also give each other their personal space, moral support and lots of encouragement. Happy Valentines Day! BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls HappyValentinesDay

Today, ASP Toh, is the OC Medical Centre of Institution A4, where she oversees and manages the prison operations of a Medical Centre in Institution A4. RO Tan is a Housing Unit Officer at Institution B2, where he oversees the daily operations in the housing unit with inmates pending Courts sentencing and instill order and discipline among them. Together with their team members, both ASP Toh and RO Tan always look for opportunities to motivate the inmates in their rehabilitation journey through the engagements during their daily prison operations.Whats the secret behind their everlasting love? Understanding and learning to trust one another is key, you must also give each other their personal space, moral support and lots of encouragement. Happy Valentines Day! BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls HappyValentinesDay

We started in the same squad back in 1991. Both of us are very active in sports. We used to play badminton and hang out together after work.What started out as a friendship soon blossomed into a fulfilling marriage and partnership that has lasted over 30 years for our CaptainsOfLives, RO Charlvi Tan and ASP Toh Siew Choo.Suddenly, something changed, and I held her hand one day while crossing the street and here we are 30 years later, RO Tan recalled. Its definitely been an adventure, ASP Toh said. The good thing about being married to another Prison Officer is that you have someone who understands what youre going through. Were able to share our experiences, learn from each other, share our problems and come up with solutions together. Meet ASP Muhammad Ali Mochtar our CaptainOfLives and co-star of the recently released three-part SPS series. Ali is featured in the second part titled Step Forward and he shared his debut film experience with us! () (), ?It was definitely a good experience being able to share about my job with the cast and crew during filming.In real life, Im a Manager for Community Corrections (Halfway House/Home Detention) at the Community Corrections Command (COMC) in the SPS. I work with a team of ROs to oversee supervisees who are undergoing the Community-Based Programme (CBP) at various community facilities. What was featured in the film was just a glimpse of our work. We work with multiple stakeholders, such as Correctional Rehabilitation Specialists (CRS), employers, case management partners, as well as the families of supervisees. For complex cases, we conduct home visits, as well as joint sessions with family, or employers. ?Some people think that we only monitor the discipline of supervisees who are serving their sentences in the community. However, theres much more to it! ROs also provide prosocial support that aids the supervisees in their rehabilitation and reintegration. -?By giving ex-offenders second chances, we help to break their cycle of re-offending. If you know of any ex-offenders, be it your co-worker, or your neighbour, show your support and encourage them to be better individuals. You can be their agents of change!BeyondPrisonWalls BehindPrisonWalls StepForward

As Assistant Senior Social Worker at the Sree Narayana Mission Nursing Home, Ms Yogeswari d/o Chandrasekaran has always found meaning in helping others. Her passion for volunteerism led her to join the Yellow Ribbon Community Project (YRCP) in 2011.For Ms Yogeswari, her time as a YRCP volunteer has been an eye-opening experience. During one of my first few visits years ago, I met the family member of an incarcerated inmate, she recalled. As we spoke, she suddenly broke down and cried. All I could do then was to provide a listening ear. Now with my social work experience, I can help them with their daily needs, and provide some psychosocial support.Reflecting on her journey, the grassroot leader for over 13 years is heartened to see more ex-offenders and their families receiving the support they need from the community. She feels inspired whenever she reads success stories of ex-offenders.On October 2021, Yogeswari was awarded the 10-Year Long Service Award at the Yellow Ribbon Community Project Awards & Appreciation 2021! She hopes that her efforts with the families of incarcerated inmates will continue to make a positive difference in their lives.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

Introducing CW Leong Lian Der, the seventh and final Outstanding Captains of Lives (OCOL) award recipient for 2021! CW Leong was conferred the OCOL award because of his professionalism at work and for being an exemplary role model to those around him! CW Leong is a Work Programme Officer at Institution A5, where he oversees the day-to-day operations of the kitchen, as well as the deployment and training of inmate workers. During the onset of COVID-19 pandemic, CW Leong and his team were presented with many new and unexpected challenges. It was a time of uncertainty that required them to adapt and update their work processes to ensure safety for all the staff, inmates and volunteers. I was truly proud with the patience and perseverance shown by my colleagues. Over time, we adapted new practices and ensured that safety of inmates and staff continued to be our top priority. For CW Leong, being a CaptainOfLives means that the values he upholds while on duty continues to stay with him even after work. As leaders, I believe that we need to lead by example to inspire those around us, both in our professional and personal lives. When hes off the clock, the proud family man devotes all his free time to his loved ones, spending time and creating memories with them. BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

Goodbye 2 0 2 1! What an epic year it has been!Read the December edition of Prison News for an insight into: does SPS provide step-down aftercare support and supervision? are the various community-based programmes available? are the CaptainsOfLives and community partners who provide aftercare support for inmates?Its definitely worth the read BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

# Our CaptainsOfLives conduct and facilitate rehabilitation programmes which include personal development and enrichment programmes for inmates, not just in , but also in .Rehabilitation programmes and opportunities are provided for the inmates after their risks and needs are assessed. They are expected to take ownership of their rehabilitation in prisons and eventual reintegration into society. These programmes may be conducted in group settings, or one-on-one as seen in our film!Watch Eighteen Steps, part one of a three-part video series, on the roles of Prison Officers in rehabilitating inmates for a safe Singapore!BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

Abang, Im really proud of you. You can really do this! These were the last words from Adams (pseudonym) beloved brother during a visit. A week later, he passed away in a traffic accident. Adam was six months away from sitting for his GCE O-Level examinations when he received the devastating news of his younger brother. Grief stricken, the 37-year-old inmate student was unable to concentrate. However, his brothers encouragement kept playing in his mind. A month later, I decided that I will use the grief to motivate me and not distract me, said the former Chef.At Prison School, Adam spent his time studying and revising his work with his eight cellmates, all of whom were sitting for their national examinations. He shared that over the years in prison, he tried several times to apply to Prison School and was finally given the opportunity in 2021. I feel so fortunate to be able to spend my time serving my sentence meaningfully. When you study, your world opens. The best part is that the Prison Officers treat us as students first, inmates second and that helps us a lot. RO2 Mohamad Faizal Bin Noh, who accompanied Adam to his late brothers funeral, was truly heartened when he heard about Adams stellar results. Its really inspiring to see Adams tenacity to press on despite his circumstances. I hope his story can inspire other inmate students to be better individuals.When asked how studying behind bars is different from schools outside, Adam said there were lesser distractions. Thus, he can focus all his energy into studies. During the COVID-19 pandemic, physical classes had to be suspended, and he shared, Our world became smaller with less face-to-face classes. We spent more time in group studies.Adam also shared on how his Form Teacher, Ms Nor Aishah Binte Mohamed Salleh, was a huge motivating factor. She went the extra mile to make sure we really understood what she was teaching. It wasnt just studies, she also helped us in character building.After scoring a majority of As and Bs for his O-Levels, Adam has applied to pursue a Diploma in Business Management in Prison School.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

SGT3 Nurazmie, a Prison Officer at Tanah Merah Prison School, first met Shakur after he was assigned to be Shakurs Personal Supervisor in 2016. Seeing Shakurs pent up anger and frustrations, Nurazmie would often take the time to listen to his concerns and provide advice. Drawing upon his own experience practising Mixed Martial Arts, Nurazmie told Shakur: Since you like to fight so much, go fight in the ring. Those were the words eventually kickstarted Shakurs journey into combat sports. As a CaptainofLives, it was heartening for Nurazmie to know that his advice was able to help Shakur turn his life around. He continues to take great pride in his work with inmates at the Reformative Training Centre, instilling a sense of responsibility and purpose for those seeking to transform their lives for the better.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

Making resolutions for the new year keeps one motivated and focused on self-improvement. Newly admitted inmates are encouraged to chart their resolutions using My Action Plan' (MAP), as part of their rehabilitation.Inmates use the guiding questions in MAP to take ownership of their rehabilitation through a process of reflection.Inmates regularly review the progress of their rehabilitation goals, guided and supported by their assigned Prison Officers aka CaptainsOfLives. Taking ownership of their rehabilitation increases their chances for successful reintegration when released from prisons and contribute to a safer Singapore. Share with us your goals for 2022 in the comments below! BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

Since retiring, Mr Wong Shee Kong always wanted to give back to society. He began volunteering at the senior centres around his estate. Eventually, his spirit of volunteerism led him to join the Yellow Ribbon Community Project (YRCP) under the Admiralty Division.YRCP is a grassroots-led initiative where trained volunteers visit families of inmates to offer them pro-social support and assistance to help minimise their burdens while their loved ones are incarcerated. Under the YRCP, Mr Wong helps families of inmates by assisting them with televisits at the ACE Community Centre in Admiralty, allowing inmates to chat with their loved ones through video conferencing. He also conducts home visits to help them with their daily needs.The passionate 68-year-old believes, People should help one another whenever possible. Life is not a bed of roses. There are also thorns. We must take life as it comes and be optimistic that good days will come.For his dedication and passion to help others, Mr Wong was named a YRCP Champion, and together with his team at Admiralty, they received the 10-Year Division Award at the Yellow Ribbon Community Project Awards & Appreciation 2021.With the close partnerships between our CaptainsOfLives and YRCP volunteers, our inmates will have a greater chance for successful reintegration into society and we can prevent inter-generational offending!BeyondPrisonWalls BehindPrisonWallsSG4SecondChances
Seasons greetings to all from the Singapore Prison Service!

The Outstanding Captains of Lives (OCOL) Award is conferred to individuals who displayed professionalism in their work and are exemplary role models to those around them. Chief Warder (CW) Thomas Chow is one of the seven Captains of Lives conferred with the award. As a Programme Officer for Institution B5, a Drug Rehabilitation Centre (DRC), his primary duty includes planning and scheduling of programmes for DRC inmates. The programmes, which are based on the inmates assessed risks and needs, can include psychology-based correctional programmes, family programmes, employability skills training and religious programmes and services. Over the years, he has learnt that communication is key in making informed decisions. Knowing when to be firm, but also understanding when a more compassionate approach is needed to ease tensions among inmates, is a crucial skill as a CaptainOfLives. Thomas recounts, Theres an emotional side of the inmates which we dont normally hear or see. Once I escorted an inmate for a compassionate leave and saw how he teared because he wasnt around when his loved one passed on. Later, the inmate shared that he felt remorseful and regretted for what he did to end up being in prison. As a CaptainOfLives, Thomas derives a sense of satisfaction from helping inmates reintegrate into society by ensuring that they attend their rehabilitation programmes, and inculcating life skills and values to them so that they will be responsible citizens. During his off days, Thomas likes to keep fit and especially enjoys a game of badminton! CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

On 18 December 2021, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) held its virtual Volunteer Awards Ceremony 2021 to honour 316 individual volunteers, befrienders, and Social Service Agencies for their support towards the rehabilitation and reintegration of inmates and ex-offenders. These volunteers provide religious, secular and social services to inmates, ex-offenders and their families. Volunteers who have been volunteering with SPS for three, five or ten years and beyond, were presented with Long Service Awards. Amongst the recipients, four received the 30-year Long Service Award! Tokens of Appreciation were also presented to organisations for their support. This year, the 10-Year Journey Plaque was also introduced to recognise organisations that have been partnering SPS for an extended period of time. Thank you to all our community partners and volunteers for your unwavering support throughout the years! SPS will continue to enforce safe custody of inmates and rehabilitate them for a safer Singapore. CaptainsOfLivesBehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

Mr Bala Muraly retired earlier this year on 21 April 2021 after an illustrious 29-year career with the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) as a former Senior Reintegration Officer. For Mr Bala, his years as a CaptainOfLives were some of the best years of his life because he was able to improve the lives of the inmates and ex-offenders that he supervised. Despite having retired, Mr Bala continues to keep in touch with his former SPS colleagues. The apple does not fall too far from the tree Mr Balas passion is echoed by his daughter, Ms Previtha Jay. She decided to follow her fathers footsteps and joined SPS. She is currently a Senior Prison Officer trainee and undergoing the Prison Officers Course. Ms Jay, who always wanted to become a uniform officer, grew up listening to inspirational stories from her father on how Prison Officers contribute in rehabilitating and improving inmates lives. She feels lucky to have her father by her side to guide her as she sets out to chart her own legacy as a CaptainOfLives. PressPlay and tune in to our rendition of The Road Ahead, a collaboration between Music and SPS, which features Mr Bala alongside our SPS staff, community partners and beneficiaries as part of commemorating SPS 75th anniversary! Mr Bala Muraly retired earlier this year on 21 April 2021 after an illustrious 29-year career with the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) as a former Senior Reintegration Officer. For Mr Bala, his years as a CaptainOfLives were some of the best years of his life because he was able to improve the lives of the inmates and ex-offenders that he supervised. Despite having retired, Mr Bala continues to keep in touch with his former SPS colleagues. The apple does not fall too far from the tree Mr Balas passion is echoed by his daughter, Ms Previtha Jay. She decided to follow her fathers footsteps and joined SPS. She is currently a Senior Prison Officer trainee and undergoing the Prison Officers Course. Ms Jay, who always wanted to become a uniform officer, grew up listening to inspirational stories from her father on how Prison Officers contribute in rehabilitating and improving inmates lives. She feels lucky to have her father by her side to guide her as she sets out to chart her own legacy as a CaptainOfLives. PressPlay and tune in to our rendition of The Road Ahead, a collaboration between Music and SPS, which features Mr Bala alongside our SPS staff, community partners and beneficiaries as part of commemorating SPS 75th anniversary! () ( ) 75. In the seventh and final leg of our TitansofSPS series, we pay homage to Mr Desmond Chin. Mr Chin worked his way up as a Prison Officer to become the 10th Commissioner of Prisons, from 2016 to 2020.He spearheaded SPSs Learning Prison initiative, which allows inmates to take greater ownership of rehabilitation from the onset of incarceration, with our CaptainsOfLives supporting inmates in their learning and rehabilitation journey. Under his leadership, SPS attained the Singapore Quality Award (Special Commendation) for the second time in 2019, in recognition of its commitment to organisational excellence.In 2020, after 30 stellar years in service, Mr Chin handed over the reins to Ms Shie Yong Lee, who is the current Commissioner of SPS.Today, Mr Chin is the Commissioner of Charities (COC) and Executive Director of the Registry of Cooperative Societies and Mutual Benefit Organisations (RCS), where he continues to drive the importance of charity work in building a caring community to provide help and support to those in need.SPS75 TransformingLivesWithYou SPSHeritage CaptainsOfLives

President joined us on 1 December 2021 to commemorate SPS 75th Anniversary during the SPS75 Virtual Commemorative Event 2021. It has been 75 years since SPS was formally instituted in 1946 as a government department to oversee the management of prisons.The event also recognises the efforts from our past and present Captains of Lives and the unwavering support from community partners in transforming the lives of offenders and supporting second chances.During her speech, Commissioner of Prisons, Ms Shie Yong Lee paid tribute to her predecessors, former Directors and Commissioners of Prisons, who shaped SPS into what it is today - a leading correctional agency which enforces safe and secure custody, delivers evidence-informed rehabilitation programmes and carries out effective community supervision of released offenders.To mark SPS75, our CaptainsOfLives rallied each other for the SPS Cares Fundraising initiative to raise $75,000 for the Presidents Challenge 2021. SPS also collaborated with to launch a set of commemorative stamps.Happy 75th anniversary, SPS!SPS75TransformingLivesWithYou SPSHeritage

() Commissioners of ( ) 75.Our sixth TitansofSPS is Mr Soh Wai Wah, who was a former Police Chief-Of-Staff before serving his appointment as the Director of Prisons from 2009 to 2016. During his tenure, Mr Soh initiated the Prison Without Guards strategy, which leverages technology to automate work processes and enhance operational efficiencies and effectiveness. He also launched the Prison Without Walls strategy to expand community corrections to facilitate inmates reintegration into society in a safe manner.He actively encouraged SPS officers to adopt a positive outlook in discharging their duties, believing that even small acts of kindness can leave a lasting impact. He also took pride in sharing success stories of ex-offenders, hoping to inspire others to live better lives. After leaving SPS in 2016, Mr Soh went on to become the Principal and CEO of Singapore Polytechnic, where he continues to play an integral role in moulding the future of Singapore. SPS75 TransformingLivesWithYou SPSHeritage CaptainsOfLives

Our heartiest congratulations to our very own CaptainOfLives, Ms Rafidah Mohamed Ayob, who received the Promising Social Worker Award 2021! As part of the annual Outstanding Social Worker Award 2021, which is organised by the Singapore Association of Social Workers (SASW) .sg and supported by the Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF) , the Promising Social Worker Award is awarded to young up-and-coming social workers who have made a difference to the lives of their clients, as well as the community. This year, the award was presented by President Halimah Yacob (). Ms Rafidah is a Lead Specialist. She provides case management services, conducts offender assessment and formulates intervention plans for drug offenders undergoing the community-based programmes. Indeed, her enthusiasm for her work has been an inspiration to those around her throughout her seven years with the SPS.Beyond SPS, Ms Rafidah was also part of the team that founded the Criminal Justice Social Work (CJSW) Chapter under SASW on 18 Sep 2020. Together with other like-minded colleagues, friends and volunteers, she helps to organise webinars, learning journeys and networking sessions to advocate on issues related to social work in the criminal justice sector. The CJSW Chapter aims to promote criminal justice social work, build stronger collaborative relationships between the various stakeholders and create opportunities for learning.Ms Rafidah understands the importance of being empathetic while working with offenders, their family members and the various community partners. She believes that every seed of change that is sowed within inmates and ex-offenders can cause a ripple effect that extends beyond the individuals and empowers those in the community to create an inclusive society for inmates and ex-offenders.You can catch the full ceremony here! BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

For her relentless enthusiasm, professionalism and being an exemplary role model, Ms Quah Feng Ling was conferred The Outstanding Captains of Lives (OCOL) Award. A Lead Specialist at Psychological & Correctional Rehabilitation Division, Feng Ling works with a team of Correctional Rehabilitation Specialists to design, assess and implement rehabilitation programmes for inmates in prisons. She also works closely with Prison Officers to provide training and counselling support.I think appreciation comes in many forms if we know where to look. Sometimes it's a simple thank you, sometimes it's hearing a caseworker sharing what they learnt from our sessions. I recall a session where we were talking about strengths and an inmate mentioned "Patience", "like how you showed us" pointing towards me. This was a total aww moment for me because, the inmate had been very reserved and wanted to drop out of the sessions initially.Since that breakthrough with him, he has been actively participating in sessions, sharing his goals and opinions. It may not seem like much, but for me it was a huge win and it's moments like this that keeps me going.Outside of work, Feng Ling particularly enjoys reading through Reddit threads, often contributing content in the popular online forum herself! CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

: Henry (not his real name) was caught and imprisoned in his late 20s for participating in gang related activities. Now at 30, he is focused on becoming a better role model to his two-year-old daughter and a responsible husband to his wife. To do this, Henry decided to proactively participate in several psychology-based correctional programmes in prison.Some of these programmes included the Social Skills Training Programme, which is designed to help inmates improve their communication and relational skills with their loved ones, and Thinking for Change Programme which is developed to raise ones awareness and target thinking patterns that led to anti-social and criminal activity behaviours.This year, Henry decided to participate in the National Youth Achievement Award (NYAA) programme. Together, with the support from SPS, community partners and his peers, he crafted handmade cards as part of a collaboration between SPS and a local non-profit organisation Be Kind SG.Henrys Personal Supervisor, RO Gwan Wei Lin recalls, When I first met Henry, he was quiet and likes to keep to himself. After encouraging him to join the NYAA programme, Ive seen a lot of positive change in him. He knows what he wants for his future and has also developed leadership skills through the programme.Henry also actively participated in the 3M Move @ South East 2021 initiative, where for every 20 minutes of exercise he performed, the South East Community Development Council would donate one 3M product to the underprivileged. I found the sporting activities during NYAA Programme meaningful because I can relate to them. From such activities, I also learnt about life skills such as teamwork and better communication. I will definitely continue to carry these lessons with me, even after I leave prison! - HenryNYAA2021 BehindPrisonWalls SecondChances

The National Youth Achievement Award (NYAA) 2021 Ceremony was held on 17 November 2021 at the Prison School and concurrently at Cluster A and B to comply strictly with the safe management measures. There were 33 Gold, 32 Silver and 17 Bronze awards given to the inmate participants.The theme for NYAA 2021 was STEP Up to Reach Out, highlighting participants accomplishments in four areas - Service to Community, To Aspire and Dream, Excel through Learning, and Pave Your Own Path.Guest-of-Honour Mr Chan Chun Sing, Minister for Education, commended the efforts of inmate participants in demonstrating their resilience to complete the NYAA programme in the face of adversity, as well as the dedication of SPS, the NYAA council and partners who persevered during the COVID-19 pandemic to provide opportunities for inmate participants to make a positive impact to society while still serving their sentences in prisons.BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

Deepavali Festive Greetings to all celebrants from the Captains of Lives.

() ( ) 75. Our fifth TitansofSPS is Mr Ng Joo Hee, who served as the Director of Prisons from 2007 to 2009. He helmed several key posts in the Singapore Police Force and was the Director of the Police Intelligence Department, before being appointed as the Director of Prisons. Under his leadership, Mr Ng oversaw the expansion of Changi Prison Complex, with the operationalisation of Cluster B. He was also instrumental in the planning of the new Prison Headquarters.After the stint at SPS, Mr Ng was appointed as the Commissioner of Police which he served till 2015. He is currently the Chief Executive Officer at the Public Utilities Board, Singapores National Water Agency. SPS75 TransformingLivesWithYou SPSHeritage CaptainsOfLives

The Outstanding Captains of Lives (OCOL) Award is conferred to individuals who displayed professionalism in their work and are exemplary role models to those around them. DSP Desmond Tan Teck Kiat is one of the seven Captains of Lives conferred with the award. DSP Tan is Officer-in-Charge (Training & Development) at Cluster C, where he leads a team in the planning and administration of training and well-being activities for staff in Cluster C. My motivation has always been to do something that makes a difference in the life of someone. You never know when you may touch someones life. In my role, it will be my colleagues and inmates. A simple Thank You keeps me going throughout my years in Singapore Prison Service and serves as a fuel for my journey here. DSP Tan also shares a little insight into his hobbies beyond the uniform. I like collecting foreign currencies when I go travelling. I am particularly fond of the Swedish Krona, as Sweden was the farthest place I had been in my travels. CaptainsofLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

Singapore Prison Training Institute (SPTI), the training arm of Singapore Prison Service (SPS), plans, develops and conducts courses that support the training and development of Prison Officers, also known as CaptainsOfLives. One of the courses developed by SPTI is the Prison Officer Course, which is conducted for newly recruited Prison Officers.The Prison Officer Course incorporates correctional, scenario-based, physical and tactical skills training that enable Prison Officers to achieve SPS mission to enforce secure custody of inmates and rehabilitate them to be responsible citizens. All newly recruited officers must complete the Course before embarking on their foundational postings in the prisons.In 2020, SPS undertook a review of the Close Quarter Defence Techniques (CQDT). It is one of the tactical skills training taught to Prison Officers to use as one of the options to disengage an aggressive inmate and gain a safe separation. These defence techniques were subsequently refined to make them more intuitive to execute for all Prison Officers, regardless of their physical abilities. BehindPrisonWalls

Calling all aspiring CaptainsOfLives join us today for a rewarding and meaningful career to keep Singapore safe and secure!A job as a Prison Officer may be challenging at times, but if you are inspired to transform the lives of offenders, the job satisfaction will be worth it!- SGT Koh Zhi Xiang.For more info on the role, click the link in our bio!BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

During the Criminal Justice Social Work Chapter sharing session on 14 October 2021, ASP Randeep Singh and CW Muhammad Haikal shared about the Empatherapy Programme, a Restorative Practices (RP) project conducted for inmates by the Singapore Prison Service.Empatherapy is a pilot programme designed to build a sense of community amongst inmates by leveraging proactive circles to facilitate a purposeful space for inmates to be given a voice to be heard. They express their feelings and thoughts without the fear of being judged.RP is incorporated into daily practices to foster a sense of community in the prison environment where relationships are valued, and inmates are aware that they are accountable for their own actions.RP builds on inmates strengths. With structured support and supervision, inmates can better reintegrate into society upon their release.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

17 years ago, RO Chan Qiwen, joined the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) as a Prison Officer, also known as a Captain of Lives. He was always intrigued with how SPS rehabilitates and eventually supports the reintegration of inmates into society to restart their lives on a positive note. RO Chan shares how empathy, care and concern are innate qualities of Prison Officers who are at the centre of the ripples of change for inmates under their charge. These qualities, according to RO Chan, affects all aspects of his life, and not just his profession.As a Staff Officer with the Provost Division, RO Chans job requires him to investigate disciplinary matters in SPS. Apart from his core duties, he is an active advocate for innovation, and is constantly looking out for ideas to streamline work processes at his workplace. A few months ago, he gave an opportunity to an intern who is differently abled to fix electrical works in his home although it took a longer time than a professional electrician. The intern had given his time and tried to learn a new set of skills. I thought it would be a good opportunity for him to put his skill sets to good use, said RO Chan. We should not shut the door on people who are hoping to be given a chance to prove their worth in society, especially when they have taken the first step to prepare themselves for new opportunities in life.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

() ( ) 75. Our fourth TitansofSPS is Mr Chua Chin Kiat, who served as the Director of Prisons from 1998 to 2007. He held many key appointments in the Singapore Police Force and was the Director of Criminal Investigation Department, before being appointed as the Director of Prisons.During his time as the Director of Prisons from 1998 to 2007, Mr Chua led SPS in its transformation journey from a custody-focused mindset to a rehabilitation centred culture. The change in mindset transformed the entire prison system. An evidence-informed approach in inmates rehabilitation was introduced and Prison Officers were also equipped with knowledge and skills to engage inmates purposefully. Mr Chua also coined the term Captains of Lives to describe Prison Officers. After completing his tenure as the Director of Prisons, Mr Chua served as CEO of AETOS Security Management Pte Ltd from 2007 to 2011. He chaired the Board of Centre for Enabled Living Ltd (now known as SG Enabled) from 2008 to 2013, and also served as a board member at the Agency for Integrated Care from 2009 to 2018. In July 2011, he was appointed as the Chairman of the Enabling Masterplan Steering Committee, which supports people with disabilities by helping them fulfill their potential as integral and contributing members of society.SPS75 TransformingLivesWithYou SPSHeritage CaptainsOfLives

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) leverages technology to augment our capabilities as CaptainsOfLives. The Virtual Reality (VR) training allows Prison Officer trainees to build expertise and familiarise themselves with the various Standard Operating Procedures in a real but virtual environment before they are deployed to start their foundational postings in the prisons.The VR training complements the current trainer-led scenario-based training and provides trainees with a more intuitive, realistic and immersive experience. In groups of up to four, trainees will be put in different scenarios and tests to hone their operational judgement skills. Before VR technology was adopted, the scenario-based training sessions were conducted physically by trainers. The trainers would serve as role players (i.e. inmates, responding staff) and re-enacted various scenarios that Prison Officers would experience on the ground.BehindPrisonWalls

The Psychiatric Housing Unit (PHU) is a collaboration between the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) and the Institute of Mental Health (IMH). It was established in 2011 with the aim to provide evidence-informed psychiatric treatment and rehabilitation to offenders with mental disabilities (OMDs) in prisons, and to prepare OMDs for reintegration into mainstream prison institutions, or to the community after their release from the prisons. OMDs will be provided with services and interventions to improve their functioning skills and have insights to their mental illnesses. Through clinical management and therapeutic interventions by IMH Psychiatrists, Nurses and Occupational Therapists, OMDs will undergo programmes such as occupational therapy, psychiatric nursing care and counselling, to help them cope with symptoms of their mental illnesses.Managing such a unique inmate population is no easy task. Prison Officers working in PHU undergo regular training to upskill their abilities to manage OMDs safely and effectively.On World Mental Health Day, CaptainsOfLives, ASP2 Tessa Mae Sim, and SGT3 P Mathavan P Paramasvaran, from the Psychiatric Housing Unit, share their thoughts on mental health and managing OMDs.Disclaimer: Some photos were taken prior to COVID-19.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls WorldMentalHealthDay

My son and I were very close. He would follow me everywhere and even wait for me outside the toilet at home. When I was taken into custody, my wife shared that my son would call out my name in his sleep every night for the first few weeks, shared Nathan (pseudonym), a father of two, who has been incarcerated for five months. Due to their incarceration, inmates who are parents, like Nathan, are not able to be physically present with their children on Childrens Day.To foster healthy familial bonds and lessen the impact of incarceration on children of inmates, Singapore Prison Service works closely with community partners and volunteers to help inmates maintain meaningful bonds with their children. This also ensures that inmates return to supportive family networks upon their release, minimising the likelihood of re-offending.Today, however, as Nathan participates in a Childrens Day activity, he expresses hope for the future because he continues to maintain a strong relationship with his children. When asked about the first thing he would do upon release, his eyes lit up. Of course, to give my sons a very big hug! I cannot wait to hold them and never do things that will separate them from me again! BehindPrisonWalls HappyChildrensDay

It was a feat worthy of the occasion. On 3 September, two Prison Officers ran for 13 hours in the shape of a Yellow Ribbon to commemorate the Singapore Prison Services (SPS) 75th anniversary. At the same time, they showed support for second chances for the inaugural Yellow Ribbon Virtual Run 2021.Meet RO Mustafa Kamal and CW Amir Hamzah, who both ran 75km, while being supported by RO Hazlan Bin Said, who acted as their safety officer on a bicycle halfway through the race. Together, the trio journeyed past former prison sites as a tribute to the rich history of SPS and made the effort to ensure that their routes formed the shape of the Yellow Ribbon a symbol of support and hope for ex-offenders. When asked how the three officers felt after the race, they shared the importance of perseverance when it comes to running or cycling long distances. It is akin to their roles as Prison Officers where they never give up on inmates despite having some of them return to prisons repeatedly. Besides ensuring the safe and secure custody of inmates, they continue to provide rehabilitation opportunities for inmates to prepare them for their reintegration into society.We are always reminded of our mission through those ex-offenders who genuinely want to change and those who managed to turn their lives around for the better, for themselves and their families. They sometimes remember us and greet us when they see us outside. Seeing them doing better makes our efforts to help them all worth it, said RO Mustafa Kamal. BehindPrisonWalls YRVR2021 YRChallenge SG4SecondChances CaptainsOfLives

The Yellow Ribbon Community Project (YRCP) is a grassroots-led initiative that provides proactive support and assistance to the families of offenders. To appreciate the commitment of the grassroots in supporting YRCP and the families of offenders, the Yellow Ribbon Community Project Awards and Appreciation Ceremony was held virtually on 2 October 2021. The Ceremony also commemorates the 11th anniversary of the Project, which continues to help more families every year. This year, YRCP volunteers reached out to 16,798 families, the highest since the Project was established in 2010, and an increase from the 15,070 families approached in 2020.Graced by Minister for Culture, Community and Youth and Second Minister for Law , 65 YRCP volunteers were awarded the 10-year Service Award for their contributions. Various grassroots divisions were also presented awards to appreciate their 3, 5 and 10 years of service.Congratulations to all the YRCP Award recipients and volunteers. Your efforts go a long way in creating ripples of change in the lives of offenders and their loved ones.BeyondPrisonWalls BehindPrisonWallsSG4SecondChances

YouKnowMeh Outram Prison, once located on Pearls Hill, was referred to as Outram Road Gaol or Outram Road Prison. It was divided into two sections: Military Section and Civilian Section. The Military Section came under purview of the Judicial Department of the Southern Area Army.It was chosen due to its proximity to town and the nearby police barracks. The area had adequate land for new buildings and could also accommodate subsequent expansions.Throughout the years, Outram Prison went through various states of changes. In January 1937, its long-term prisoners were transferred to the new convict prison in Changi. Outram Prisons jail subsequently held offenders serving short sentences.In 1963, Outram Prison was demolished and its site was later redeveloped into a housing estate.SPS75 TransformingLivesWithYou CaptainsOfLives SPSHeritage

Mobile Interactive Training Application or MITA is a Training Application designed by the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) that allows Prison Officer trainees to experience real situations, in a safe and controlled environment during the Prison Officer Course (POC). These trainees are newly recruited Prison Officers who have to complete the POC which also includes correctional, tactical and physical training, to be full-fledged Prison Officers. MITA supports the learning of younger officers by appealing to their enjoyment of learning, which enhances knowledge retention.So how does MITA work? Trainees select different situations, avatars and choose from the seven challenges to conquer! These seven challenges come with three levels of intensity, as well as three milestone quests at the end of each level. These test trainees knowledge of concepts on topics covered in the course.Before MITA, trainees relied on classroom-based learning and training through role play. With the advent of MITA, trainees are better equipped to combat many unique situations that may arise in prisons and take their time to understand the best course of action they ought to take, at their own time and at their own pace beyond the classroom lessons.MITA has expanded SPS training methodology to better prepare our Prison Officers aka CaptainsOfLives to fulfill SPS mission in enforcing secure custody of inmates and rehabilitating them to become responsible citizens, for a safer Singapore.BehindPrisonWalls

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) welcomed 34 new graduand officers, after they successfully completed their Prison Officer Course. The newly commissioned Prison Officers have gone through months of physical and tactical readiness training, as well as completed correctional training to prepare them for their journey as CaptainsOfLives in SPS.Over the course of their POC, the trainees also underwent residential and on-the-job training to enhance their prison craft competencies and prepare them for their roles in SPS to ensure secure custody of inmates and positively influence them in their rehabilitation journey.We spoke to RO Cynthia Lim and SGT Muhammad Norhidayat, the Outstanding Trainees for Prison Officer Cohort 2/20, who shared the highlights of their training with us.I found that I am now able to express myself better. Our training was not just physical training and combat, we also had classroom lessons where the trainers created a safe space for us to share our experiences, learnings, thoughts, and feelings. Through these sessions, I learnt to put thoughts into words clearly, which would be important when interacting with inmates, RO Cynthia Lim shared.Like RO Cynthia, SGT Muhammad Norhidayat found himself improving as an individual after completing his training course.The challenging PT sessions and the daily challenges set by the trainers taught me to always be prepared for any circumstances and have a strong mental resilience, said SGT Muhammad Horhidayat. Congratulations to all our new Prison Officers from Cohort 2/2020! BehindPrisonWallsBeyondPrisonWalls

As the Team Leader of the Complex Escort Unit under the Operations and Security Command of the Singapore Prison Service (SPS), CW Mohamad Ridzal Bin Abdul Razak oversees the deployment of Prison Officers and Auxiliary Police Officers for external escort assignments. He also oversees the maintenance of Complex Escort Unit facilities. Outside his work, Ridzal is a man of many hats. He is a certified tactical trainer, training safety officer, Home Team Simulator (HTS2) instructor, Associate Evaluator for Contingency Exercises, and a Caring Action in Response to an Emergency (CARE) officer. He also volunteers with the Yellow Ribbon Community Project in Woodlands Division and is also currently upgrading himself by pursuing a Diploma in Correctional & Management Studies.During my house visits, I always remind ex-offenders to never ever give up hope as there will always be a ray of light at the end of the tunnel. I also advise them that they should not be choosy when it comes to their first job after release if it meets their basic needs. There will always be other job opportunities, CW Ridzal opined.The 43-year-old officer believes that officers can be inspired from inmates too. He recalls an interaction with an inmate that prompted him to restart his own education journey. "He (the inmate) told me one day that, Sir, if an inmate like me can restart my education at this age, you can too! His constant reminders, along with my colleagues and Commanding Officer's encouragement, led me to decide to finally take the plunge and get my Diploma! CW Ridzal was conferred the Outstanding Captains of Lives (OCOL) Award, which recognises individuals who displayed professionalism in their work and are role models to those around them.CaptainsOfLives BeyondPrisonWalls BehindPrisonWalls

() ( ) 75. Our third TitansofSPS is Mr Poh Geok Ek, who served as the Director of Prisons from 1992 to 1998. Before his appointment as the Director of Prisons, he was serving as the Director of the Central Narcotics Bureau.The Tanah Merah and Changi Womens Prison were completed under the guidance of Mr Poh. He also introduced the use of technology in the prisons, and SPS has since leveraged technology to enhance operational efficiency. After retiring in 1998, Mr Poh continues to be an active advocate within the anti-drug community. He served as the President of the Singapore Anti-Narcotics Association (SANA) from 2005 to 2013. SPS75 TransformingLivesWithYou SPSHeritage CaptainsOfLives

YouKnowMeh In the past, prison teachers had to travel to different institutions to provide education for inmates. As institutions were located in all parts of Singapore, travelling proved to be a pain point for some. The Kaki Bukit Centre Prison School, with its visionary philosophy of School First, Prison Second, was opened on 26 July 2000 by Mr Wong Kan Seng, then Minister for Home Affairs, with facilities comparable to the national schools. To prepare inmate students for their eventual reintegration to society, they were taught moral education and underwent social skills training to rebuild themselves holistically. By 2011, there were 40 teachers teaching GCE N, O and A levels, as well as courses certified by the Workforce Development Agency, and various vocational certifications. During the same year, the Kaki Bukit Centre Prison School moved to the former Tanah Merah Prison, where the prison school still remains today.SPS75 TransformingLivesWithYou CaptainsOfLives SPSHeritage HappyTeachersDay

Good Morning Teacher! Meet Ms Shirley Ng, who teaches inmate-students the newly introduced Computer Applications course at the Prison School! The course was introduced as a subject to promote digital literacy and prepare inmate-students to be technologically ready upon their release.The former Ministry of Education (MOE) teacher shared that she joined the Prison School as an educator so that she can be part of the inmates rehabilitation journey. She believes that learning is a two-way street and has learnt the importance of perseverance, among other things, from inmates. Ms Ng shared the main difference between teaching in mainstream schools and Prison School, In mainstream schools, age profiles are pretty much consistent, but in Prison School, I have students from varied age brackets that range from 20s to 50s. My students learn and revise diligently, and their tenacity is paying off because I see them making progress and gaining confidence, she shared. An inmate-student once came up to me and shared that during his younger days, he could never concentrate and focus in class, but now thanks to my guidance, hes able to focus and progress on the course! It warmed my heart to hear this. SPS wishes all teachers a Happy Teachers Day!BehindPrisonWalls HappyTeachersDay

[ ]As a Reintegration Officer, CW Khairul Bin Sanif monitors the progress of supervisees undergoing the Mandatory Aftercare Scheme (MAS) in the community. He helps the supervisees to overcome their social issues and engages them purposefully to facilitate their reintegration into society after being released from prisons. He attended training sessions conducted by the Singapore Prison Service to prepare him for the work in the community as the competencies required to work in the prisons and community are different.CW Khairul was conferred the Outstanding Captains of Lives (OCOL) Award, which recognises individuals who displayed professionalism in their work and are role models to those around them. I always put in my best effort to persuade my supervisees to persevere and complete the programme, shared CW Khairul. During the course of working with them, I've also learnt soft skills that help me to communicate more effectively."CW Khairul is grateful to his team members and mentors in the MAS team, who have provided strong support and guidance to him. When not at work, CW Khairul enjoys watching Korean dramas. He shared that his favourite dramas are Mr Queen, Vincenzo, Taxi Driver and Sell Your Haunted House. When asked about a lesson that he took away from his drama binging sessions, CW Khairul shared, We should persevere in whatever we do despite the trials and tribulations in life.CaptainsOfLives BeyondPrisonWalls BehindPrisonWalls

YouKnowMeh Drug abuse was rampant in the 1970s and the government initiated Operation Ferret to round up the drug addicts from the streets to undergo treatment and rehabilitation programmes. As a result, several Drug Rehabilitation Centres (DRCs) were set up very quickly to provide treatment and rehabilitation programmes to the drug addicts who were arrested and thereafter detained in the DRCs. The Sembawang DRC was opened in 1979 and could accommodate up to 1,000 inmates. The facility provided custodial care and rehabilitation to the drug inmates. In 2009, the facility ceased operations after its inmates were moved to Cluster B at the Changi Prison Complex. SPS75 TransformingLivesWithYou CaptainsOfLives SPSHeritage

: DidYouKnow? Computerisation was introduced to the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) in the early 1980s and was then used mainly to automate administrative functions, such as finance and personnel administration. By the 1990s, a Strategic Information Technology (IT) Masterplan was developed to help SPS leverage on IT to support its corporate objectives and operational demands. A key component of the Masterplan was the Prison Management System (PMS), introduced in 1999. This was essentially a database that stored information of inmates from the time of their admission to the time of release from the prisons. Before PMS, information of inmates were kept in hardcopy files. PMS enabled fast and accurate processing and retrieval of inmate information.In 2009, the PMS was replaced by the Prisons Operations and Rehabilitation System (PORTS). A mobile version of PORTS (aka mPORTS) was subsequently developed in 2010. This web-based application allowed Prison Officers to access information via touchpad devices and complete various tasks on the go. Such technology advancements in computerisation have helped SPS to be more efficient in the management of inmates data and information. That in turn gives the Prison Officers more time to engage the inmates in their rehabilitation journey to prevent re-offending, for a safer Singapore.SPS75 TransformingLivesWithYou SPSHeritage CaptainsOfLives

Remember SSGT Noor Aisha, our expectant mother, from our Mothers Day feature this year?We are happy to announce the mum of two gave birth to her third bundle of joy, a baby girl, on 9 August 2021! I am overwhelmed, happy and excited. Even though it's not going to be easy as my two children have their own personalities, having Delysha Aurelea is still a big blessing to my family, shared the Personal Supervisor. Her work requires her to ensure the safe custody of inmates under her care as well as engage these inmates purposefully to influence them positively in their rehabilitation process so that they do not re-offend and become responsible citizens for a safer Singapore. As a CaptainOfLives, Aisha shares a little more about the happy coincidence of giving birth to her daughter on National Day. Serving the nation is my primary duty as a public servant and now welcoming my daughter on National Day makes it even more special. There is a sense of satisfaction and patriotism and now, we will definitely look forward to every National Day even more eagerly! Our heartfelt congratulations to Aisha and her family!BehindPrisonWalls

On National Day, SSGT Mohammad Faizal, a Prison Officer from the Singapore Prison Service's Complex Escort Unit (CEU), welcomed his baby girl. As an officer with the Prisons CEU, Faizal ensures the safe and secure custody of inmates when they need to be brought out of prisons for court hearings, hospital appointments, or any other movements outside of prisons. He has to remain vigilant and ready to respond to any situations when escorting the inmates outside of prisons. BehindPrisonWallsCaptainsOfLives
