() ( ) 75. Our second TitansofSPS is Mr Tee Tua Ba, who served as the Director of Prisons from 1988 to 1992. Prior to his stint as the Director of Prisons, Mr Tee was in Officer-In-Charge of the Marine Police (now known as Police Coast Guard).Under his directorship, SPS developed its first service mission, operations and management philosophy, which was to strive for excellence and professionalism in support of the Singapore criminal justice system in the safe custody, humane treatment and successful rehabilitation of offenders, in preparing them for return to society as law-abiding citizens.Mr Tee also played an instrumental role in setting up the Prison Scheme of Service to boost staff morale and attract new recruits of high calibre to join the service. SPS75 TransformingLivesWithYou SPSHeritage CaptainsOfLives

YouKnowMeh The Lloyd Leas Day Release Camp housed the first batch of 50 inmates under the Day Release Scheme in 1979.Under the Day Release Scheme, inmates who had the resolution to change were given the option to leave the camp in the day for work and return after their work hours. This scheme allowed inmates to re-adjust to the society and helped them secure employment before completing their sentences.Today, research shows that rehabilitation takes place best in a real-life environment. Thus, suitable inmates are emplaced on Community-based Programmes, where they serve the tail-end of their sentences in the community, during which they are provided with structured aftercare support, under the supervision of SPS. SPS75 TransformingLivesWithYou CaptainsOfLives SPSHeritage

Heres to a friendship that has weathered the test of time. On International Friendship Day, we share the story of Joo Eng, Thila, Aishah and Soon Gim - four Prison Officers who became friends as Captains of Lives, and continue to remain BFFs till today, many years after their retirement. The four joined SPS in the 1980s and remained dedicated to their work as CaptainsOfLives for 27 to 37 years, working with inmates and contributing to their rehabilitation to prevent re-offending for a safer Singapore. They find meaning in their jobs and had fond memories which were filled with laughter and joy.I remember seeing them for the first time when they joined SPS. Little did I know that our first meeting would build a connection that would last me throughout my career in SPS and even beyond, Joo Eng fondly recalls how the friendship between the four of them started.InternationalFriendshipDay SPS75 TransformingLivesWithYou*Note: Photos were taken before Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) measures.

[ ]The Outstanding Captains of Lives (OCOL) Award is conferred to individuals who displayed professionalism in their work and are exemplary role models to those around them. The first of the seven recipients of the OCOL Award this year is ASP Ng Riying! ASP Riying, a Staff Officer at the Staff Development Division (SDD), oversees the posting of all civilian staff and junior officers. She works closely with the different clusters and departments to ensure that information for COVID-19 related operations are up to date and accurate. Besides that, she also organises dialogue sessions to provide CaptainsOfLives a platform to exchange their views and learn from one another. I find my work at SDD meaningful. The various postings allow our officers to be exposed to different work environments, that eventually chart the course of their careers within the Singapore Prison Service. ASP Riying revealed that the most challenging period for her was during the COVID-19 pandemic last year. I was new to my post and felt overwhelmed with the work and the changes around. What pulled me through was the support from my colleagues. They are the real giants here. Today, when I look back and see how much Ive grown, it is because of their support. Despite facing challenges in her new role, she believes in the power of teamwork, and has never once allowed work to overwhelm her. Its not all-work-and-no-play for the 36-year-old. I enjoy going for Muay Thai classes, and I have recently started attending Brazilian Jiu Jitsu classes! BeyondPrisonWalls BehindPrisonWalls

() ( ) 75. Our first TitansofSPS is Mr Quek Shi Lei, the first local Director of Prisons. He was also the longest-serving Director of Prisons, serving from 1973 to 1987. Starting as a Welfare Officer, he worked his way up to become the Director of Prisons.The late Mr Quek is credited for achieving the most with the least. With limited resources, he led his team to establish and operate several drug rehabilitation centres practically overnight, when Operation Ferret was started in 1977 to contain the growing drug problem in Singapore then.Thereafter, he moved on to become the first Chief Executive Officer of the Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE), which is now known as SPS75 TransformingLivesWithYou SPSHeritage CaptainsOfLives

YouKnowMehRose Lodge, also known as the first Female Prison, housed female inmates who were sentenced to imprisonment for all types of criminal offences or detained for drug consumption/inhalant abuse. It was first established at Outram Prison and later moved to a semi-open facility, which was converted from the Prison Officers Clubhouse in Moon Crescent. In 1994, all the inmates were moved to a purpose-built facility at Changi Womens Prison/Drug Rehabilitation Centre, which had a capacity of 600. It was later relocated to Institution A4 of Cluster A in the Changi Prison Complex in 2017.SPS75 TransformingLivesWithYou CaptainsOfLives SPSHeritage--------------------------------------------SPS75 - Commemorating SPS's 75th anniversary. Witness our transformation here: go.gov.sg/sps75-heritage-video

To commemorate our 75th anniversary (SPS75), join us over the next few months as we shed light on interesting anecdotes that are part of our rich heritage in our YouKnowMeh series!--------------------------------------------YouKnowMehQueenstown Remand Prison was built to house persons on remand and short-term offenders after Singapore became independent. It was officially opened by the late Mr Othman Wok, then Minister for Culture and Social Affairs, in 1966 and at that time, could accommodate up to 300 inmates!The prison eventually ceased operations in 2009 and its inmates were transferred to Cluster B at the Changi Prison Complex.SPS75 TransformingLivesWithYou CaptainsOfLives SPSHeritage

Having always been passionate about working with inmates, Dr Chan developed two innovations that aided rehabilitative programmes! Swipe to learn more about these innovations! Dr Chan reveals that she lives by the philosophy If one cares enough for the people, one will think deep! Not known to many, most of the ideas that are conceived in her head have roots in her heart! She credited her husband and her four children for honing her creative skills and for empowering her ideas.The Home Team Innovation Award is awarded to candidates who offer fresh and new perspectives, and the use of creative ways to come up with solutions within their job roles. For the year 2020, Dr Joyce Chan, Manager (Release on Supervision) from Cluster C of the Singapore Prison Service, had recently been conferred the prestigious award.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

To commemorate our 75th anniversary (SPS75), join us over the next few months as we shed light on interesting anecdotes that are part of our rich heritage in our YouKnowMeh series!------------------------------------YouKnowMeh Changi Prison was built in 1936. Its iconic telephone pole design has been widely adopted by prisons worldwide. As the last prison built by the British Colonial government, Changi Prison was a state-of-the-art maximum-security penal facility during its time!In 2016, the Changi Prison Entrance Gate, wall and turrets were gazetted as Singapores 72nd National Monument.SPS75 TransformingLivesWithYou CaptainsOfLives SPSHeritage

Senior Chief Warder (SCW) Teng Jan Kim, who has been a CaptainOfLives for the past three decades, had always known he wanted a meaningful career that can make a positive impact on the lives of others. This cemented his resolve to join the Singapore Prison Service (SPS). Little did he know that 27 years later, his son would follow in his footsteps and become a CaptainOfLives too. This FathersDay, Rehabilitation Officer (RO) Teng Pang Ann shares his inspiration behind joining SPS and dedicates these special moments to his dearest, Pa.

Singapore Prison Service (SPS) is humbled to receive the Service Delivery Excellence Award from the Public Sector Transformation Awards 2021 for DIRECT! DIRECT, or Digitalisation of Inmate Rehabilitation and Corrections Tool, was introduced in 2019 to provide our inmates with access to a suite of applications that facilitate their rehabilitation and self-learning. This helps CaptainsOfLives to engage inmates meaningfully so that the inmates can focus on their rehabilitation journey.DIRECT replaces hardcopy materials (such as inmates letters and reading materials, including books and newspapers) with electronic versions. SPS aims to continue improving the features available on DIRECT.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

The Yellow Ribbon Webinar (YRW) is one of the ways to strengthen Singapores correctional networks by initiating conversations about rehabilitation and reintegration. Held in May 2021, the webinar was attended by our community partners from the Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-offenders (CARE) Network, New Life Stories, as well as our international counterparts.SPS representative Mr Loh Eng Hao spoke about the social impact that drug abuse can have on families. The webinar also emphasized the integral role that families play in the inmates journey of desistance, and how SPS works with other community partners to support the inmates families so that the inmates can focus on their rehabilitation.BeyondPrisonWallsBehindPrisonWallsCaptainsOfLives

[ 3 8 ] The Jamiyah Halfway House, one of our community partners, works closely with us to ensure successful rehabilitation and reintegration of offenders as theyre completing their sentences. Family support is everything, explained Faizal Abas, Head of Jamiyah Halfway House (JHH). Thats why some residents are also granted overnight home leave to spend time with their family during Hari Raya.During these festive occasions, residents may also create artworks under JHHs Art Therapy rehabilitative programme and send them as well-wishes to their loved ones. These small gestures go a long way in helping them rebuild their relationships with their families.These are just some of the rehabilitation programmes available for JHH residents. Find out more about the programmes in the photos. BeyondPrisonWalls

This Mothers Day, SSGT Noor Aisha Binte Mohd Azam, a Personal Supervisor working with the Singapore Prison Service, takes the spotlight!The pregnant mother of two, who has been with SPS for nine years, is five-months pregnant with her third bundle of joy.As a mother and a Captain of Lives, I have the opportunity to be a role model to not only my children, but also to the inmates under my care. Learning qualities such as compassion, kindness and empathy are crucial to both for inmates looking to make better life choices and for my children, so they can grow up to be wonderful human beings.We salute Aisha for being an endearing mother and, at the same time, a passionate CaptainsofLives. Happy MothersDay to all Mothers and Mothers-to-be!HappyMothersDay

This time last year, my loved ones were telling me that they were looking forward to my speciality Fish Curry and Laksa, during Raya. This year however, Raya is going to be different. I will not be cooking my speciality because I am in prison while my loved ones will be celebrating outside. It is said that in the month of Ramadan, whatever you ask for, is granted. Throughout my life, I have never pledged for anything, but this time round, in Ramadan, I have made a decision. The moment I go home, I will kiss my 72-year-old-mums hand and seek forgiveness and pledge to change. No more drugs. No more depriving my mum of her son and my siblings their brother. I will be taking part in the Gang Renunciation Programme soon and Im determined to leave my past behind and mix with better company.If I can offer advice to a younger Ridwan, I would tell him to love himself more. Love is a powerful force and if you love yourself enough, change happens....Ridwan (pseudonym), 55, is currently 11 months into his 36-month sentence for drug related offences. He is now part of Toki Formation, a pottery-based programme by Awful Grace, which allows not only for a kinesthetic experience, but teaches him valuable lessons of character formation and life skills. Singapore Prison Service prevents re-offending by working closely with inmates families and the community to support inmates in their rehabilitation and reintegration.BehindPrisonWalls DrugFreeSG SG4SecondChances

I often chart the time and wonder what my mum and siblings must be doing out there. Especially during Ramadan. At 4.30am, they would have woken up for their pre-dawn meal and at 6pm, they would be busy preparing for . This Ramadan, all I pray for is the strength to be a better son to my mum. Back in January 2019, when I was in prison for another drug offence, I spoke to my father over the phone. I was due to be released and told him I was looking forward to seeing him soon. A few days later, I got the news that my father had passed away. My biggest fear right now is to receive yet another phone call and this time its my . I will not be able to handle that blow.If I could tell my one thing this Ramadan, it would be to say Im very sorry. Sorry for all the heartaches and sorry for all the mistakes I made. During my daily prayers in this special month, I pray for His forgiveness and strength to make better choices when I am released. The real test is when I am out (of prison) and Im ready for that test....Jaffar (pseudonym), 40, is currently serving a 36-month sentence for drug related offences. He is due to start his Community Based Programme, where he will serve the tail end of his sentence under supervision by the Singapore Prison Service in the community. Community corrections help provide released inmates with structured support and supervision to prevent re-offending for a safer Singapore.BehindPrisonWalls DrugFreeSG SG4SecondChances

24 hours a day, seven days a week, prisons continue to function! Our CaptainsOfLives pledge to keep Singapore safe by ensuring the secure custody of inmates and rehabilitating them to prevent re-offending!HappyLabourDay

Have you ever wondered what a Prison Visit Management (PVM) Officers job entails? Lets hear from RO Hariram S/O Thanasegara Rajah and find out more about his job in the Singapore Prison Service (SPS)!On a day-to-day basis, I ensure the smooth operations of the visit sessions between inmates and their family members. A PVM officers main job scope is to ensure that the daily visit operations run smoothly. Within visit operations, there are many facets such as registration of visitors, booking, and scheduling of visits, processing of documents etc. We must be quick to address any issues to prevent any disruptions to the visit processes.RO Hariram shared that over the course of his duty and the challenges he encountered, it was the COVID-19 pandemic that required the PVM Unit to think differently and develop quick new processes with safety at the forefront for staff, inmates, and family of inmates! Being agile and tactful was a necessity. During circuit breaker, all tele-visits and face-to-face visits were ceased. However, keeping in touch with loved ones and knowing that they well became crucial during the pandemic as both inmates and their families were worried about each other. Hence, we swiftly arranged for a phone-visit system that ensures visitors can continue to communicate with their loved ones in the prisons. Both inmates and their families were appreciative of such arrangement.As a correctional agency, enforcing the safe and secure custody of inmates is not the only role we play. Allowing both inmates and their families to maintain and strengthen their ties are also key as part of the inmates rehabilitation and reintegration journey from prisons into society.CaptainsofLives BehindPrisonWalls

The Selarang Park Complex (SPC) was built as an integrated hub for the throughcare rehabilitation of inmates to provide greater aftercare support for ex-offenders. The low-to-medium security in SPC has the infrastructural capability to support rehabilitation and reintegration programmes, as well as provide vocational training opportunities for over 3,000 inmates and supervisees. Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law, graced the opening ceremony of the SPC today and shared that the opening signals an important step in the transformation of prisons. Improvements in infrastructure, coupled with the considered use of technology, will help our officers and our community partners as they help offenders rehabilitate and reintegrate into society. In line with SPSs Prison Without Guards strategy, the development of SPC presents new opportunities to leverage technology for greater operational effectiveness and efficiency that enables not only prison officers but also inmates to be more focused on rehabilitation. Speaking of rehabilitation, Ms Chang Xin En, Correctional Rehabilitation Specialist at the Drug Rehabilitation Centre, shared that inmates learn to identify their unhealthy thinking patterns and how to correct them when they attend psychology-based correctional programmes. Practical life skills like communication and emotion regulation skills are also introduced to inmates. This will help them to build up a skill set that will help them to lead a drug-free lifestyle when they are released.SUPT Terence Ong Choon Teck, Superintendent of Institution S1 added on, Inmates face challenges in reintegration, such as maintaining employment and staying away from anti-social peers. Inmates who are motivated to change will benefit the most from the rehabilitation programmes offered to them. SPS will continue to work with our community partners such as halfway houses, volunteers and employers to provide inmates with structured support and supervision to prevent reoffending.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

The 64th session of the United Nations (UN) Commission on Narcotic Drugs (CND), was held in Vienna, Austria from 12th to 16th April 2021.Singapore organised a virtual side event on 14th April, titled Inspiring community action in the rehabilitation and reintegration of offenders, to provide a platform for the sharing of community approaches undertaken by international correctional administrators to rehabilitate and reintegrate offenders. The event was attended by over 125 international participants from various countries, as well as local community partners of the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) and Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG), such as social service agencies from the Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-offenders (CARE) Network.SPSs representative, Ms Valerie Chiang (Senior Assistant Director, Community & Family Policy) shared about the Yellow Ribbon Project which aims to raise awareness of the need to give second chances to and generate acceptance of ex-offenders and their families in the community. She also shared about SPSs strong partnership with over 80 agencies and more than 3,600 individuals supporting the rehabilitation and reintegration of offenders.The strong support of community partners is crucial in supporting inmates in their rehabilitation and reintegration into society.BeyondPrisonWallsBehindPrisonWalls

The Selarang Halfway House (SHWH) was established by the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) in 2019 to provide a rehabilitative environment for inmates in the community to break the cycle of re-offending and help them successfully reintegrate into society.Karen Lee, Director of Community Corrections Command, shares the importance of aftercare support in an inmates rehabilitation journey. The programmes at SHWH aim to reiterate and reinforce key learning points from the pre-release programmes in prisons and focuses on the application in real-life situations such as work, studies and training. SPS adopts a Throughcare Approach in rehabilitation which supports the inmates journey from the time they come into prison (incare) to their pre-release stage and finally the time when they are released from prisons (aftercare).Lee shares, When they come into SHWH, there is a one-month intensive programme where they go through a refresher of the psychological-based correctional programme which they attended during their incare phase. At the same time, we also work with the Career Coaches from the Yellow Ribbon Singapore for job matching for the residents and send them for courses outside the SHWH.Besides inmates taking ownership and having the desire to change, successful reintegration also depends on other factors such as support from families, community partners, and employers, and acceptance and second chances from the broader community. We work with the different agencies in providing the support that they require. Support from employers to give sufficient employment opportunities is important as well. Last but not least, we are also working with their families to welcome them back, concluded Lee.BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

In celebration of WorldArtDay, we speak to Louis Woo, Officer-in-Charge of the Visual Arts Hub (VAH) at the Changi Prison Complex, Institution B4, to find out more about art rehabilitation programmes in prisons.Having been in charge of the VAH for the last five years, Louis revealed that art is a way for inmate artists to express their artistic qualities and demonstrate their resolve for positive change. Through the therapeutic and self-reflective nature of art, inmate artists have learnt to express their penned-up thoughts and emotions in a positive manner, shared the prison staff of over 14 years. Art is used to complement the rehabilitation programmes in prisons to enhance the inmate artists art competencies and also as a form of self-reflection and improvement. Louis further elaborates that, Inmate artists undergo training in basic fine art, pottery and batik painting techniques in the VAH and through the therapeutic and self-reflective nature of art and the patient mentoring of our volunteers, they are given the opportunity for extensive soul searching and realise that their attitudes and mindsets need to change for the better. And this is often reflected in the contemplative art pieces.The VAH, alongside with community partners, use art as one of the ways to complement Singapore Prison Services rehabilitation and reintegration initiatives. Partnership with the community and community support for second chances are crucial factors that contribute to successful reintegration for offenders.BehindPrisonWalls

The final recipient of the 2020 Outstanding Captains of Lives Award (OCOL) award goes to ASP Tan Yew Chuan! This prestigious award is given to those Singapore Prison Service (SPS) staff who displayed professionalism in their work and are exemplary role models.Revealing that his curiosity about what goes behind prison walls was the main reason that motivated him to join the service, ASP Tan reminisced, I was given the privilege to be deployed in one of the Maximum Security Prisons the old Changi Prison. As a Singapore Prisons Emergency Action Response (SPEAR) officer, I had the opportunity to train with local elite Military and Law Enforcement Units, as well as attend study trips to Correctional Departments in Hong Kong, U.S.A and Australia. Looking back from where I started as a Sergeant to where I am today as a Housing Unit Officer (HUO) and a SPEAR detachment officer in Cluster C, my journey has truly been eye-opening thus far.ASP Tan reveals how he overcomes challenges and often finds them to be a blessing in disguise, It is all about getting past your comfort zone because the longer you stay there, the tougher it is to get out. I always tell myself that challenges and problems are opportunities to help us become better, not bitter.At the end of the day, ASP Tan is proud to be working in an organization that enforces the safe and secure custody of inmates and provides rehabilitation programmes for them.CaptainsofLives BehindPrisonWalls

Brother-sister duo DSP Chen Congyi and RO Chen Shuyi shed light on what its like working together in Singapore Prison Service (SPS) as we commemorate internationalsiblingsday!Before joining the SPS, the duo aspired to have careers that were meaningful and challenging, but were in jobs that proved to be unsatisfactory. After coming across a career advertisement about SPS in the newspaper, DSP Chen realized that working in SPS would help him realize his goal and decided to take the plunge before convincing his sister to do the same. While it took DSP Chen two years to convince his sister to join SPS, his efforts proved to be worth it. "I told her, since you cannot find what you like, give Prisons a go! It will be worth the try! DSP Chen recalled. Initially, RO Chen was skeptical as she felt that she lacked the qualities required to be a prison officer but seeing the satisfaction her brother derived from his job, she took a leap of faith and joined SPS as well. After working in SPS for a period of time, the siblings appreciate that they are able to rely on one another for support. If [I] have an issue, I can actually go to him for advice. I am happy to have a familiar pillar of support at work said RO Chen. To all siblings out there, whether you work together or not, we wish you a Happy International Siblings Day! CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

Brother-sister duo DSP Chen Congyi and RO Chen Shuyi shed light on what its like working together in Singapore Prison Service (SPS) as we commemorate internationalsiblingsday!Before joining the SPS, the duo aspired to have careers that were meaningful and challenging, but were in jobs that proved to be unsatisfactory. After coming across a career advertisement about SPS in the newspaper, DSP Chen realized that working in SPS would help him realize his goal and decided to take the plunge before convincing his sister to do the same. While it took DSP Chen two years to convince his sister to join SPS, his efforts proved to be worth it. "I told her, since you cannot find what you like, give Prisons a go! It will be worth the try! DSP Chen recalled. Initially, RO Chen was skeptical as she felt that she lacked the qualities required to be a prison officer but seeing the satisfaction her brother derived from his job, she took a leap of faith and joined SPS as well. After working in SPS for a period of time, the siblings appreciate that they are able to rely on one another for support. If [I] have an issue, I can actually go to him for advice. I am happy to have a familiar pillar of support at work said RO Chen. To all siblings out there, whether you work together or not, we wish you a Happy International Siblings Day! Today, we welcomed 60 new graduands who have successfully completed their Prison Officer Course.The Prison Officer Course comprises physical training, tactical readiness and academic components to prepare our new CaptainsofLives for their foundational postings as Housing Unit Officers and Personal Supervisors.They went through residential and on-the-job training that will enhance their competencies and prepare them for their roles in the Singapore Prison Service to ensure secure custody of inmates and positively influence them in their rehabilitation journey.A word of advice from the Commandant Justin Paul Vikneswaran to these officers, Dont be overwhelmed, you are not alone, the trainers are not here to break you down, but rather to bring you up. The most important thing is to keep an open mind and an open heart, and continue to learn and not to give up.Congratulations to all our new prison officers from Cohort 1/2020! BehindPrisonWallsBeyondPrisonWalls

On 30 March 2021, Mufti Dr Nazirudin visited the Tanah Merah Prison School to give a motivational talk to inmate students. At the same time, the session was screened virtually to benefit inmates from other prisons. This is part of the religious programmes offered in prisons, which help to steer inmates in the right direction by providing spiritual guidance for them to break away from the cycle of re-offending.In collaboration with our community partners and volunteers such as FITRAH, inmates family members are also given support while the inmates are serving their sentence in prisons. Besides facilitating inmates rehabilitation in prisons, FITRAH also assists ex-offenders in their reintegration into society.BehindPrisonWallsBeyondPrisonWalls

The Singapore Prison Service works with eight halfway houses under the Halfway House Service Model to provide support for offenders who are serving the tail end of their sentence in the community to undergo the Community-Based Programmes. In part one of our Halfway House Series, we visited The Helping Hand (THH), a Christian halfway house that seeks to transform the lives of offenders through a holistic rehabilitation programme. The rehabilitation programme in THH incorporates a structured timetable for residents where they rise early to spend some time for reflection, have their breakfast and begin their assigned work. Having a timetable for their daily activities encourages residents to build discipline and cultivate positive habits in their everyday life. To successfully reintegrate into society, offenders need the assistance of a supportive aftercare system. Halfway Houses play an important role in the rehabilitation journey of an offender as they provide accommodation and offer residents rehabilitation programmes to help their residents develop a healthy lifestyle. Ultimately, once the residents have gotten use to independent living in a halfway house, they would be better prepared to kickstart an independent lifestyle after they are released into society. CaptainsofLivesBehindPrisonWalls

The first time I visited him in prisons, my son said, I thought that my parents didnt want me anymore, Fatin shared.We spoke to Fatin, mother of an ex-offender, Adam, to find out more on how she stood by her sons side during his incarceration.Family support is essential in an offenders rehabilitation and reintegration journey. The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) encourages offenders to take greater ownership of their rehabilitation by leveraging on their families as a source of motivation for change.Adams turning point was the moment he realized his parents unwavering love for him. That was when he decided to pursue a goal to take up education in prisons. As a stark contrast to the past, Adam, who was barely interested in books when he was younger, requested for his parents to buy him reading materials whenever they visited him. To no surprise, the 27-year-old now has a Diploma in International Supply Chain Management and is currently pursuing a bachelor's degree in logistics and supply chain management.A piece of advice from Fatin to the family members of the incarcerated, Never give up on your children no matter what they have done. Our kids need the support of their parents in their reintegration journey. Throughout all these years, I have never missed any chance to visit my son, except once when I was sick and could not walk, Fatin gleamed.CaptainsofLivesBehindPrisonWalls

As a trainer in the Singapore Prisons Emergency Action Response (SPEAR) Force, Chief Warder (CW) Ang Kian Heng trains SPEAR officers to be operationally ready to deal with any disturbances that could occur in the Changi Prison Complex.CW Ang was conferred with the Outstanding Captains of Lives Award (OCOL) in 2020, a prestigious award for Singapore Prison Service (SPS) staff who displayed professionalism in their work and are exemplary role models. Since SPEAR officers are the elite force within SPS, we asked CW Ang to share how he managed to sustain the tough training during the SPEAR Basic and Advanced Tactical course.CW Ang quipped, My greatest challenge was completing the 4-month SPEAR Basic and Advanced Tactical Course back in 1999. Although that was many years back, I still remember it very well. The course was very demanding, both physically and mentally, but none of us took the option of ringing the bell to give up. The tough challenge trained our persistence and mental resilience, and that is how I am still with SPEAR today.BehindPrisonWallsCaptainsofLives

For International Womens Day this year, we shed light on SUPT Koh Zhi Mian from Institution A3 and asked her questions on her role as a female Superintendent in the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) where about 80% of the staff strength are males. - ?We are not limited by our gender. When we put on our uniform, it is always duty before ourselves. I never really feel limited just because I am a female. I feel challenges are how we perceive them. If we choose to believe that being a woman in a male-dominated environment is a limiting factor, then that thought will limit us and create obstacles for us. ?I wanted to join a profession that is of service and helps others. When you help an inmate, you not only help them but their family as well. Its a whole ripple of change. ?It was my professor who taught me during my Master's programme. His perseverance in putting his duty as a professor before himself stuck with me. It was that perseverance that anchored in my mind and I still tap on that in my job as a prison officer. ?Go for it! Its a very fulfilling job and youre not limited by your gender. There is no glass ceiling - as long as you have the right mindset, want to be at the center of facilitating change in individuals, and have a genuine interest in the job, you will excel!CaptainsofLives BehindPrisonWalls CelebratingSGwomen

As an only child, he took on the responsibility of taking care of his family and it proved to be too overwhelming. He eventually picked up the habit of abusing drugs as a way to cope with his negative emotions. In 2020, Ethan was arrested for drug-related offenses. This also meant that he had to give up his job in a law firm to serve his sentence. Ethan was assessed to be suitable to undergo the Community-Based Programme (CBP) where he was allowed to serve the tail-end of his sentence in the community. However, he had to abide by the conditions such as electronic tagging, curfew hours, and undergo regular sessions with his Reintegration Officer and Correctional Rehabilitation Specialist. Today, the 32-year-old is taking charge of his life and has decided to make amends for his past. My step-father said that everyone makes mistakes, but youve got to learn from your mistakes and not repeat them again. How many times do you want to go back to prison? His words ran through my mind repeatedly. Ethan also expressed his appreciation to his Reintegration Officer, CW Mariana Binte Karim and Correctional Rehabilitation Specialist, CW Sadhana Rai, who have helped him throughout his reintegration journey. I felt that the officers and counsellors were very helpful, steering me towards the right direction always, Ethan said. During my last week of incarceration, I received news that he (his step-father) was hospitalised with cancer. If it was not for the CBP, I would not have been able to see him one last time, Ethan uttered.As for his future plans, Ethan is looking forward to complete his Law Diploma followed by a degree and eventually move on to practise law. The journey of a thousand miles begins with one step, however (it has to be) in the right direction. My goal is to finish my studies and for that to happen, I have to stay out of trouble and to stay drug-free. CaptainsOfLives BeyondPrisonWalls SG4secondchances DrugsFreeSG
Rain or shine, our officers will always enforce secure custody of offenders for a safer Singapore.CaptainsOfLives

The role of a Prison Officer is more than just a custodial function. In order to help inmates rehabilitate and reintegrate into society effectively, Prison Officers also mentor and provide guidance to the inmates under their charge.Through various rehabilitation programmes such as psychology-based correctional programmes, vocational skills training, work programmes, family-based programmes and religious counselling, Prison Officers, Career Coaches and volunteers play pivotal roles in facilitating change and motivating inmates to make better choices for their future.As Captains of Lives, Prison Officers are trusted to keep Singapore safe by ensuring the secure custody of inmates and rehabilitating them to become responsible citizens.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls

As a Reintegration Officer at the Community Corrections Command (COMC), CW Hing Su Wan ensures supervisees who are emplaced on the Mandatory Aftercare Scheme receive adequate support upon their release from prisons. Her daily role involves engaging with her supervisees on their well-being and reintegration efforts.CW Hing Su Wan was awarded the Outstanding Captains of Lives Award (OCOL) in 2020, a prestigious award for Singapore Prison Service (SPS) staff who displayed professionalism in their work and are exemplary role models.When asked what was her most memorable moment as a Reintegration Officer, CW Hing quipped, One of my ex-supervisees who completed his programme in 2015 called me up in 2019 to update me on his well-being. There was no need for him to do so, but the phone call was especially heart-warming when he expressed his gratitude for our efforts in guiding him through his challenges back then. CaptainsofLives

Having battled with depression for several years, Frank revealed that the happiest moment in his life was ironically the time he spent behind bars. During his incarceration, he finally saw light at the end of the tunnel and was given a glimpse of hope for his future.This is the happiest that I have been in a decade. Being in prison helped me to recalibrate and sort out my life. This is the time when you realize who is important to you and what really matters in life.Frank, who was once arrested for drug-related offenses, is the top inmate student for the GCE A-Level examination which was recently announced. As a stark contrast to his past, the 32-year-old who scored 5 As and a B, used to take drugs for recreation and was soon hooked to it. The side effects of his consumption were detrimental to his health and gradually consumed him. That kickstarted his spiral into a deep dark depression.Completing the A-Level examination is something that I should have done half my life ago. I don't think I can enter my grave without completing it, said Frank.When asked about his plans after his release, Frank exclaimed, I would definitely want to set up a social enterprise that helps people who are battling with depression. Throughout my 20s, Ive been battling depression. I want to do something for this group of people. I think I have found my purpose in life. DrugFeeSG BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

As we sat down to chat with Irfan (not his real name), the 38-year-old seemed nervous. He confessed, Its my first time doing an interview. Im a bit nervous. Irfan was interviewed to share his progress undergoing the Community Based Programme (CBP). Suitable inmates are emplaced on CBP where they serve the tail-end of their sentences in the community under the supervision of a Reintegration Officer (who is a Prison Officer) and also with the support from Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG) and our community partners.Under the CBP, Irfan is emplaced in a safe environment that provides structured aftercare support through counselling sessions, vocational training sessions and employment in order to ease his transition back into the society. Irfan also gave thanks to his case worker for engaging him in family programmes which helped to strengthen the bond between him and his family. His Reintegration Officer, CW 2 Mohammad Zailan Bin Ismail, who has been with the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) for 16 years revealed, Its easy to relapse in the case of substance-abusers like Irfan. Triggers are always around. The key here is to ease them into the real-world slowly and to ensure they have the right support system at every step of the way.Offenders often face challenges in their reintegration back into society. Its hard when people know you have been inside before. They are wary. Its not their fault, I know now only my actions can speak for myself and I am determined to change for my children, said the resolute Irfan, who is due to end his CBP on 19 February 2022.beyondprisonwalls sg4secondchances drugfreesg

The moment he got caught, he collapsed. He dreaded the fate that awaited him. That was in 2008. 13 years later, life seems a lot more hopeful for the 49-year-old student inmate Tim (pseudonym). Tim is one of the oldest student inmates in Prison School, located in Institution Tanah Merah 1. The jovial and chatty student-inmate who sat for his GCE A-Levels examinations scored Distinctions and straight As.Ive got a second-second chance at life. The first was when my capital punishment for drug offences was reduced to life imprisonment in 2012, and second was when I managed to resume my education behind bars in 2018.. said Tim, who scored 9 points after retaking his GCE O-levels exams two years ago.Today, despite being in prison, Im competing with my 19-year-old son, who is preparing to pursue a diploma after scoring a 3.9 GPA in his ITE course. The father-of-one admits that being in prison and through resuming his education behind bars has helped bridge the gap between the father and son duo. We have so many more things to talk about nowThe biggest irony is that only after coming here, at my age, Ive resumed my education, renewed my relationship with my family and found my faith once again. Rehabilitation Officer (RO) Mohd Faizal actually played an important role in that. On a day to day basis, he checks in on me, helps me where possible and actually facilitates to get my religious books for me when I need them.. Tim intends to further his learning and quest for knowledge behind prison walls and leaves us with a message for the young students on the outside, Dont focus on temporary enjoyment. Develop a passion for learning. Not just education, but learning. Change comes when you start to learn.. BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

The moment he got caught, he collapsed. He dreaded the fate that awaited him. That was in 2008. 13 years later, life seems a lot more hopeful for the 49-year-old student inmate Tim (pseudonym). Tim is one of the oldest student inmates in Prison School, located in Institution Tanah Merah 1. The jovial and chatty student-inmate who sat for his GCE A-Levels examinations scored Distinctions and straight As.Ive got a second-second chance at life. The first was when my capital punishment for drug offences was reduced to life imprisonment in 2012, and second was when I managed to resume my education behind bars in 2018.. said Tim, who scored 9 points after retaking his GCE O-levels exams two years ago.Today, despite being in prison, Im competing with my 19-year-old son, who is preparing to pursue a diploma after scoring a 3.9 GPA in his ITE course. The father-of-one admits that being in prison and through resuming his education behind bars has helped bridge the gap between the father and son duo. We have so many more things to talk about nowThe biggest irony is that only after coming here, at my age, Ive resumed my education, renewed my relationship with my family and found my faith once again. Rehabilitation Officer (RO) Mohd Faizal actually played an important role in that. On a day to day basis, he checks in on me, helps me where possible and actually facilitates to get my religious books for me when I need them.. Tim intends to further his learning and quest for knowledge behind prison walls and leaves us with a message for the young students on the outside, Dont focus on temporary enjoyment. Develop a passion for learning. Not just education, but learning. Change comes when you start to learn.. BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) works with eight halfway houses under the Halfway House Service Model to provide aftercare support for inmates as they reintegrate into society. These halfway houses provide structured aftercare support such as counselling, rehabilitation programmes and case management services, for inmates serving the tail-end of their sentence in the community. Over the next few months, stay tuned to our page, as we shed light on the work of these key community partners!BeyondPrisonWalls
Kick start the brand new week with a positive mindset and a great big smile (behind your mask, of course!) CaptainsOfLives

I met my wife in NUS in the year 1991. She was my mentor at that time, so I used that as an excuse to get her contact number! I did not think that she liked me but one day, I mustered my courage and confessed my feelings for her as we were walking towards the library. What a day that was! The only relief I felt was that I was not punched or slapped! And thats how our story started. SUPT Shahlan Bin Rashid recalls while glancing at his wife, SUPT Hamisah Bte Tomari.Actually, I heard about him even before we met. He was the popular guy on campus - smart and talented! I belonged to the type of girls who would find talented boys intriguing especially one that could draw and write poems, SUPT Hamisah laughed.When asked what its like to work in the same organisation as your spouse, SUPT Hamisah revealed, We understand the demands of our jobs and have equally accepted that both of us would always want to be there for our teams. We must be grateful for the opportunities we have, no matter how tough it can be. SUPT Shahlan chips in, I once remember cancelling our family dinner at the last minute because I was activated to report to work. As she worked in the same organisation, she understood the demands of my job, including such unexpected activations. Before we wrapped up, we asked them if they had any special plans for Valentines Day this year, to which SUPT Shahlan quickly responded, I have a 12-hour shift. SUPT Hamisah interrupted, He must make it up to me the following week!Happy Valentines Day from CaptainsofLives!

I am Mohammad Firdaus Abdul Aziz, a Personal Supervisor from the Reformative Training Centre at Institution Tanah Merah 1, and this is my story.My father was my inspiration since young so it didnt take long for me to decide what my ultimate career would be a prison officer.An occurrence with an ex-offender reinforced my decision. I remember being at a shopping mall with my fiance (now wife) once, and an ex-offender approached me shouting, Sergeant Firdaus! at the top of his voice! As he approached me, I recalled that I had submitted a disciplinary report against him for misconduct when he was in prison, and yet today he greeted me with a friendly smile. He thanked me for being firm with him as it helped him learn from his past mistakes. He went on to share that he is pursuing his education once again and is now working part-time to support himself. That truly shed light that my actions today could have a ripple effect on inmates tomorrow. Along the way, Ive learnt that despite their current circumstances, we must constantly support them and guide them towards the right path and believe that change will happen. Maybe not today or tomorrow, but our efforts will pay off some day eventually.CaptainsOfLives

In conjunction with Wisma Geylang Serai (WGS)s 2nd anniversary celebration, artworks by inmate artists from the Visual Arts Hub (VAH) will be displayed at WGS Level 1. This exhibition is open to the public from now till 24th January.Since its inception in 2009, VAH has had more than 150 inmate artists in its programme. Art provides a platform for inmates to express their thoughts and showcase their artistic passions. Through their daily application in arts, they learn to think out of the box, recover their self-confidence and gradually take on important values such as perseverance, discipline, and purposefulness.Through such collaboration with community partners, inmate artists are given opportunities to showcase their talent in their own ways, which will help them with their reintegration process after they are released. So dont forget to head down this weekend to support our inmate artists and check out their unique and meaningful creations!BehindPrisonWalls

The last time she broke down was in 2016, when her lawyer advised that the time she was looking at for her crime was close to 20 years behind bars. Two days ago, Anna (pseudonym), 29, wiped away tears once again. But this time, it was different. She wiped away her tears while holding her GCE O-Level certificate displaying straight As. Anna emerged as the top inmate student! She then walked back to her cell and scribbled I did it! in her diary. Its been six years since Anna started her prison sentence, but it was in her fifth year that she decided to retake her exams. When asked why it took her time to finally decide to retake her exams, she shared that she wanted to be 100% certain that she would give it her best and not take the opportunity lightly. Opportunities like this dont come easy, I would never take it for granted. Since then, with pure grit and determination, she spent her days studying. Despite the circumstances that surround Anna, today is a good day. One should recognise their own capabilities and have more faith. Believe you can do it, shared Anna. Inmate students like Anna, learn discipline, focus and gradually begin to trust their own abilities and skills when they resume their education behind bars. Anna credits her results to her Math and Form Teacher Ms Jayme, She treated me like an adult student. She pushed me and encouraged me every step of the way.When asked about her dreams, Annas eyes reflect a sense of longing. She shared that she often dreams of the time when she is released and takes the train home, I imagine myself standing at the platform and taking the train back from the East all the way to Jurong and simply watching people.. It might be a while till she rides the train back home, but today, as she gets up to leave, we notice a little bounce in her step. Walking us out, Rehabilitation Officer (RO) Lee Sang Hui shared how despite the length of her sentence, Anna remains focused and knows what she wants to achieve in her time in prison. Anna is currently serving a 22-year sentence for drug offences. She has chosen to sit for her GCE A-Level examinations later this year. CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls

Having played truant since young, Ahmad (pseudonym) was expelled from school in Secondary 2. His teenage years were spent in the chaos of drugs and gangs. However, the pitfalls of his youth are a faint representation of the Ahmad today, aged 36, an inmate student who was one of the top performers in Prison School, located in Institution Tanah Merah 1, with all As and a B for his GCE O-Level 2020. I never thought I would be able to hold an O-Level certificate. This is long overdue., an overwhelmed Ahmad expressed. He shared that at his age, he thought it was an impossible dream. However, his English teacher, Mr Lim Jien Hwee, was not surprised with Ahmads performance as he had always worked hard and was consistent in his performance throughout last year. Having served five years of his thirteen-year sentence, Ahmad shared that he wanted his time behind bars to be spent meaningfully and resuming his education will secure a brighter future for him after release. When asked about his daily routine and what kept him motivated to study, Ahmad credited his desire to make his family and his children, an 8-year-old son and 13-year-old step-daughter, proud. He also fondly recalled how Chief Warder (CW) Mohammad Rashids encouragement helped him. He pointed us to CW Mohammad Rashid across the auditorium with a thumbs up and shared that CW Rashid always mentored him.Education is a stepping-stone for inmates like Ahmad to build a better future for themselves when they are released back to the society. Importantly, inmate students also pick up positive values and soft skills, such as resilience, perseverance, stress management and time management, which are important values and skills to have when they are released from the prisons.Looking forward, Ahmad remembered his childhood dream of being a Software Engineer. But before that, he will take his GCE A-Level examination first. CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls

As the Night Duty Team Leader in Cluster A, CW Abdul Hafiz Bin Abdul Wahab ensures the safe and secure custody of inmates under his care. He also encourages them to take ownership of their own rehabilitation through positive interactions. CW Abdul Hafiz was conferred with the Outstanding Captains of Lives Award (OCOL) in 2020, a prestigious award for Singapore Prison Service (SPS) staff who displayed professionalism in their work and are exemplary role models. Recalling an inmate under his care, CW Abdul Hafiz found out that the inmate had a poor relationship with his child, who did not visit or write to him during his incarceration. After several engagements with the inmate, CW Hafiz referred him to the Family Interventions and Reintegration Support Team (FIRST). At FIRST, case managers understood the needs of this inmate and his family and worked with them closely. Over time, their relationship improved and started showing positive results. This spurred the inmate to continue working towards strengthening the relationship with his child, and to turn over a new leaf for good.CW Abdul Hafiz also shared that at times, it can be quite disappointing to know that inmates under his charge have relapsed and are reincarcerated. However, he reminds himself that as long as he has given his best, there is no need to feel bad. You will never know when the little things that you do might be the stepping stone for an inmate to change. So keep trying.CaptainsofLives

Together with other artists in the Malay community, inmate artists from the Visual Arts Hub (VAH) participated in the SeniKita exhibition by . This exhibition also marks the second year of participation by our inmate artists. Art exhibitions like SeniKita allow inmates to gain experience and have the opportunity to showcase their talents to a wider community. Arts also provides an avenue for inmates to express themselves and demonstrate positive behaviours such as discipline, focus, perseverance and patience, which aid in their rehabilitation.Limitations in Adaptations is a ceramic piece inspired by the inmate artists growth after facing setbacks, whereas Fighting the Micro Microscopic Guerilla was inspired by another inmate artist on the challenges faced following the spread of COVID-19 in Singapore.BeyondPrisonWalls

After going through the H.E.R.O programme, I can now recognise my hidden emotions and manage them in positive ways. It has also helped me to build positive thoughts whenever I face problems. Fai (pseudonym) Honour, Empathy, Resilience, Ownership (H.E.R.O) is a 6-month needs based violence intervention programme led by psychologists from the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) for inmates with violent offence(s). H.E.R.O aims to target cognitions related to violence as well as equip inmates with relevant skills and behavioural strategies to refrain from violence. Personal development activities are also scheduled for inmates to help them develop a repertoire of prosocial interests and hobbies to use their time productively.Since 2019, SPS has partnered Singapore to engage inmates productively through sport activities, led by ActiveSG Sport Champions.Sports is for all! Beyond promoting an active lifestyle, ActiveSG hopes that the introduction of sporting activities can help our inmates to manage their emotions better, reflect on life lessons and build confidence in themselves. With the success of this pilot project, it strengthens our resolve to scale this programme to benefit more inmates together with SPS. - Chief ActiveSG, Sng Hock Lin.

Out of the 68 inmate students who sat for their GCE 'N' Level examination this year, 45 of them scored 19 points and below, and will be promoted to Sec 5 N(A) to sit for the GCE 'O' Level examination in 2021. Three inmate students even scored 5 distinctions while 16 of them scored 3 distinctions or more!Congratulations to all our inmate students for putting in their best effort despite the disruption caused by the pandemic this year! BehindPrisonWalls

2020 marks the largest number of inmate participants to receive the highest honour in the National Youth Achievement Awards (NYAA) - with 80 inmates achieving the NYAA Gold!The NYAA programme was first introduced in prison for inmates aged between 16 and 25. This year, the age limit was increased to 30, which allowed more inmates to benefit from the programme. To date, more than 2,000 inmates have completed the NYAA programme since it started in Singapore Prison Service in 2000. In line with this years theme, Dare Explore, Lead ur Dreams, Strive Succeed, Better ur Society, NYAA participants initiated several outreach projects even in the midst of the nations battle against the COVID-19 pandemic. This included developing posters about the virus that were used within prison institutions to educate fellow inmates, and making personalised cards to show their appreciation to our frontline healthcare workers. President Halimah Yacob, who was the Guest-of-Honour for this years ceremony, also commended the awardees in her speech.This year marks a key milestone, as we celebrate the 20th year of NYAA in Prisons. To each one of you who embarked on your NYAA journey, you can be proud of yourselves for making this effort to change. Your NYAA experience will stand you in good stead, and I look forward to you making a positive impact on our society. BehindPrisonWalls

The Outstanding Captains Of Lives (OCOL) Award is a prestigious award for Singapore Prison Service (SPS) staff who displayed professionalism in their work and are exemplary role models. This month, the spotlight is on OCOL Award recipient CW Charles S/O Pangkeas! As a Senior Personal Supervisor in Cluster B, CW Charles ensures the safe custody and discipline of inmates under his charge. His role also includes engaging inmates in meaningful interactions and providing guidance to help them break the cycle of re-offending. Being a person who enjoys challenges, CW Charles shared that he listens to the problems that inmates have and tries his best to help in any possible way. I would remind myself that every problem has a solution it depends on how you handle it. Solve the problem or leave the problem, do not live with the problem.When asked how he knows that this job is his calling, CW Charles recalled, I met an ex-offender while I was attending a church service with my family. He came over to introduce me to his family as a Prison Guardian Angel. I was at a loss for words, as I did not realise that I had made such a big impact in his transformation into a sincere and responsible family man. That was a memorable day for me as my children told me they admired me and my job as a CaptainsOfLives even more.

On 11 December 2020, in conjunction with the CARE Network 20th Anniversary, Singapore Prison Service (SPS) with the support of Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG), presented the first Yellow Ribbon Webinar series - Desistance: Beyond Recidivism.The webinar introduced the idea of desistance and how desistance research and community partners can play a part in strengthening policies and rehabilitation programmes to help ex-offenders live a crime-free life. Guest of Honour, MOS Faishal also spoke on the topic of desistance, adding that, A society thats conducive for successful desistance can only be built up through the collective effort of the entire local correctional network. That is why it is important for every single one of our community partners and agencies to embrace desistance as a way of helping to rehabilitate and reintegrate our offenders in partnership with SPS and YRSG.Thank you to all who joined us in this session! BeyondPrisonWalls

Following the virtual bonding session between inmates and their children in November, we sat down with Superintendent of Institution B3, SUPT Avryl Tan and co-event organiser, Head of Centre For Fathering (CFF) Engagement & Outreach, Mr Eruandee Prayitna to hear their thoughts on being part of the Childrens Day events in prisons, which were carried out via Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic.Speaking of the importance of family programmes, SUPT Avryl Tan shared that, These programmes help to increase inmates knowledge, skills, and confidence in maintaining ties and building stronger relationships with their family members. It helps to facilitate their reintegration back to a supportive family network upon release and mitigate their risks of re-offending.Mr Eruandee shared that the participating inmates are part of a larger programme where they learn soft skills such as learning how to listen to and speak with their children effectively. He opined that Mothers and fathers play a unique role in bringing up children. Activities like this will aid in providing familial bonds between parent-inmates and their children. When they are released, the bond helps sustain the relationship and hopefully, guide the child.Enhancing familial relationships is part of an important rehabilitation journey for our inmates as it reduces the impact of incarceration on their families, especially children, and therefore mitigate the risks of re-offending. CaptainsofLives BehindPrisonWalls

Meet our CaptainsOfLives, Chief Warder (CW) Mohamad Ridzal Bin Abdul Razak, who has been with the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) for 22 years!With 22 years experience as a prison officer, CW Ridzal has seen the transformation of not only inmates rehabilitation, but also SPS as an organisation. As the Team Leader of SPS Complex Escort Unit at the Operations & Security Command, he manages the deployment of officers who perform external escort assignments.It was in his 19th year in the service that CW Ridzal decided to do more for the inmates when they are released from prison. He became a volunteer with the Woodlands Division of the Yellow Ribbon Community Project (YRCP) in 2018. The grassroots-led initiative, with the support of Yellow Ribbon Project (YRP), aims to provide support to ex-offenders and families who are affected by the incarceration of their loved ones through regular house visits and outreach events.It was during one of these home visits that CW Ridzal encountered an ex-offender living in a small flat with 12 other family members. This left a lasting impression on him on the difficult circumstances ex-offenders faced when released. Since then, CW Ridzal goes for weekly home visits and facilitates welfare support for such families. During the Circuit Breaker, he continued to check-in with the offenders families virtually so as not to lose touch.Thinking back CW Ridzal recalled, I was always curious to see what happens to ex-offenders when they are released (from prisons) and why some keep coming back. As a volunteer with YRCP, I am not only able to keep ex-offenders motivated and encouraged (them) to stay on the right path, I am also able to encourage their young children to look towards a brighter future.

Our second recipient out of the seven recipients of the Outstanding Captains of Lives (OCOL) Award in 2020 is Chief Warder (CW) Ho Yeow Nam, Dennis! The OCOL Award is a prestigious award for Singapore Prison Service (SPS) staff who displayed professionalism in their work and are exemplary role models.As an Admin & Personnel Officer at Operations & Security Command, CW Dennis Ho shared that he enjoys constantly coming up with new and innovative methods to understand inmates better and ultimately impressing change upon them. Our job involves helping inmates to change for the better, but change has to come from the inmates. There is no one-size-fits-all solution as inmates come from various backgrounds and they face different struggles. The challenge is understanding what would motivate them to make a change. The job is indeed rewarding!CW Dennis Ho recalled that there was once he saw an inmate having difficulties breathing and clutching his chest. He immediately called for an ambulance and together with his colleagues, carried him on a stretcher and rushed down a flight of stairs. The inmate eventually recovered and was extremely grateful to him. Its through little moments like this that make me feel my job is meaningful, and I actually have the ability to make a difference., shared the Captain of Lives.Thank you to CW Dennis Ho for your relentless pursuit to make a difference in the lives of offenders! CaptainsOfLives

Children's Day is a day held dear for children and families. For some of them, they might be unable to celebrate this special day and other milestones together with their loved ones.This year, Singapore Prison Service worked with The Salvation Army Prison Support Services - Kids In Play (TSA PSS-KIP) and the Centre for Fathering (CFF) to organise six virtual bonding sessions over Zoom in October and November, where inmates were able to bond and engage in fun game activities together with their children. witnessed one of the sessions organised by CFF at the Prison Link Centre on 5 November 2020 and shared his hopes for the inmates to change for the better and return to a strong, supportive family.Family support programmes are crucial in enhancing familial relationships and reducing the impact of incarceration on family members, especially children of those incarcerated. By working closely with community partners to provide these programmes, we aim to bridge the gap between the inmates and their children and strengthen their family ties. This will go a long way in their reintegration process when they are released eventually.CaptainsOfLives

Did you know that the YR Industries (YRI) Laundry Workshop at Institution A5 is one of the largest health care laundries in Southeast Asia? Its also the biggest workshop in Changi Prison Complex (CPC)! In our conversation with SCW James Lew, who is also the Team Leader at the laundry workshop, we found out how he supports inmates and finds time to meaningfully engage them during working hours. He shares, I maximise the small pockets of time during the inmates tea break and find opportunity to engage inmates in spontaneous conversations. These small blocks of interactions help me cultivate relationships with them over time. To me, this is a subtle but effective way of engagement with inmates to influence them positively and encourage them to turn over a new leaf.Besides ensuring that the operations are running smoothly and efficiently in the Laundry Workshop, SCW James Lew and his team have a bigger role inspiring the inmates at every chance towards a society without re-offending! CaptainsOfLives

Amiable and adventurous with a quick wit and rollicking sense of humour, Rehabilitation Officer (RO) Sherman Kwang is always busy; and even more so during the past few months since he was casted as the main lead for Captains of Lives (COL) recently debuted short film, The Test. With a passion to make a difference to society, he pursued a degree in Criminology and Security at the Singapore Institute of Technology and joined the Singapore Prison Service as a Prison Officer after his graduation.Going beyond just supervising and creating a safe environment for inmates in Changi Prison Complex, RO Sherman and his fellow colleagues act as role models for them during their daily interactions. When inmates display negative emotions, instead of getting angry at them, we show them how to control their own emotions and handle such situations with patience, said RO Sherman, who plays a vital role in the rehabilitation of the inmates as a Housing Unit Officer in Institution A1. No aspirations shared by the inmates is ever taken lightly, We take their requests seriously and find every opportunity to refer them to the right avenues to increase their chance of having a successful reintegration into society."Going the extra mile to engage each inmate individually, RO Sherman shared with us the importance of doing so. Only through individual engagement without any other inmates or staff around will they feel more comfortable to talk naturally and bare their hearts out. When asked about his proudest moment as a CaptainsofLives, he recalled the time when an inmate who was about to be released approached him to thank him for bringing him comfort whenever he needed a listening ear. He made me realise that as a prison officer, sometimes, all we need to provide is a listening ear, and ask them how they feel. Wondering how Captains Of Lives like Sherman make a difference in the lives of those serving their sentences? Watch the latest short film The Test by Singapore Prison Service on our IGTV!

Introducing CaptainsOfLives, DSP Khairuddin Bin Alias, who has been in service with the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) for 31 years! When asked about his motivation on being with the service for 31 years, he quipped, I have impacted the lives of several young boys at the Reformative Training Centre (RTC) and found it heartwarming to receive letters from them after they were released. I hope to continue excelling in my job and make a difference in the lives of the inmates in our custody.When he is not at work, DSP Khairuddin engages in his hidden talent doodling! Right from the time he was handed his first pencil and paper, DSP Khairuddin started doodling. Doodling acts as a platform for him to express his thoughts, ideas, and feelings, and more importantly, a stress reliever after a long day at work!Swipe to see some of his recent artworks reminding Captains Of Lives on the importance of wearing face mask correctly! Don't forget to WearMasksProperly!

I am Alicia Tan, a Correctional Rehabilitation Specialist, at the Psychological and Correctional Rehabilitation Division (PCRD). I provide group and individual interventions to inmates in Cluster B. Besides direct work with the inmates, I also work closely with prison officers to support individuals with behavioural and psychological issues in the housing units. The pandemic changed the way we work significantly. From going into the institutions in Changi Prison Complex (CPC) to conduct face-to-face assessments or intervention programmes for the inmates, to working predominantly from home when the Circuit Breaker was enforced. To ensure that our intervention programmes with the inmates will continue, my colleagues and I came together to produce videos for the psychology-based correctional programme for drug offenders, within three days! Besides that, I was also tasked to man the Virtual Family Assistance Centre (VFAC) along with my colleague Andre Paul, who is also a Correctional Rehabilitation Specialist. The VFAC was set up so that family members of inmates can call to enquire about the well-being of their incarcerated loved ones during the Circuit Breaker period. At the end of the day, I am proud to be able to be part of the VFAC team during the pandemic, where I assisted and reassured the family members of the inmates. As long as we stay united, we can overcome the COVID-19 pandemic together.CaptainsOfLives

In view of the World Mental Health Day today, we would like to shed some light into the Psychiatric Housing Unit (PHU) within prisons which supports inmates who have mental disorders. The PHU conducts intervention programmes to strengthen the inmates rehabilitation potential and prepare them for their reintegration back to society. SWIPE through these photos (taken before COVID-19) to know more about some of the programmes in PHU. As family support is crucial in the rehabilitation and reintegration journey of an inmate, the PHU Family & Community Day offers family members of inmates a chance to interact with mental health experts and key community partners. When the family members better understand what the inmates are going through, the inmates social support system will be strengthened and this helps them in their recovery and rehabilitation journey.In the Indoor Gardening Therapy Programme in PHU, inmates are given the opportunity to have a sense of responsibility by taking care of their own plants and this helps them to build their confidence.At times, inmates face difficulties expressing how they feel through words. Hence, the Art Therapy in PHU allows them to express their feelings through a creative platform. Besides that, Art Therapy also helps to raise the inmates self-esteem and discover latent artistic talents they might possess. worldmentalhealthday

Education is one of the ways to facilitate successful rehabilitation and reintegration for inmates. Making the decision to resume studies behind bars equips them with the academic qualifications to explore opportunities to pursue their dreams and lead a crime-free life after their release. As our inmate-students gear up to sit for their national examinations, CaptainsOfLives would like to extend our well wishes to all students in Singapore too. Good luck and all the very best for your upcoming exams!

Meet Norain'ni Binte Abd Aziz, who was one of the seven SPS staff awarded with the Outstanding Captains of Lives (OCOL) Award in 2020! The OCOL Award is a prestigious award for SPS staff who displayed professionalism in their work and are exemplary role models. As a Correctional Rehabilitation Specialist at the Singapore Prison Service (SPS), she shared that her motivation in SPS was to help inmates become better sons, brothers or fathers to their families. She strongly believes that they can be better citizens and will be able to contribute back to society once they are back on the right path.Norain'ni quipped that it was not easy to work with resistant inmates who had little motivation to change. Id tell myself that change takes time, and this is not the time for us to give up hope but to push on. Working closely and sharing the struggles with the inmates Personal Supervisor helps in our intervention, she shared. She feels that all the efforts and hard work pay off when she chances upon ex-offenders who are out in the community and are doing well. Hearing about their progress and the positive impact on their families makes her feel that she has made the right career choice to be a Captain of Lives.Thank you Norainni for your hard work and dedication towards SPS and making a difference in the lives of the inmates and their families! Look out for the other OCOL award recipients and hear their stories!CaptainsofLives

I am Sharlotte Liew from Cluster B, Programme, in the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) and this is my story.My role in SPS is to have an oversight on the rehabilitation and reintegration needs of the inmates so that I can better manage the programmes made available for them and make referrals to the Yellow Ribbon Community Project for their families As technology starts to play an increasingly important role in SPS, I am delighted to be given the opportunity to venture in the automation field and participate in the development of the Robotics Process Automation (RPA). RPA is a great step for SPS towards digitalization to make our job more efficient so that we focus on other higher-value work. With the help of RPA, my colleagues and I have more time to communicate with the inmates, understand their challenges and identify resources to better address their needs. I am glad for the opportunity to impact the inmates lives and facilitate their change to become better citizens after their release from prisons. Together, we can overcome this pandemic!CaptainsofLives

Not everyone will be gifted an opportunity to make a difference in an inmates life, but I am glad that I could. I am Gill Saul - an art teacher at the Visual Arts Hub (VAH) in Changi Prison Complex. I conduct fine art training for inmates at the VAH and guide them on how they can use art as a platform to express themselves.Initially, it was tough to get the inmates to open up and share their life experiences with me. But I shared with them that they are a blank canvas to me, and I have no preconceptions about who they are just because they happen to be incarcerated. It took some time for them to trust me completely before they eventually let me in to their lives. This was an eye-opening experience for me as I had the privilege to listen to their hopes, dreams, struggles and what they wanted to achieve after they are released. The inmates look up to me not only as an art teacher, but also as their teacher in life. Whenever they share their struggles with me, I will try to give them a different point of view that will enable them to reflect on their choices. I am also a direct mentor to one of the ex VAH inmates and am responsible for checking up on him from time to time and steering him in the right direction in life. Being a volunteer art teacher at the VAH is one of the most meaningful choice that I have made. Im grateful that I had the chance to listen to different life stories and play a part in the rehabilitation journey of the inmates. My ambition for the inmates is that they grow to become art and life mentors themselves. All of us come from different backgrounds, but we are able to stay connected through a common platform ART. CaptainsOfLives wishes Ms Gill Saul, Prison Teachers and all teachers a Happy Teachers Day!
