How does working in the Transformation & Technology Division (T&TD) of the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) contribute to the fight against COVID-19? I am SUPT Cem Sim and this is my story on how my colleagues and I have contributed to the fight against COVID-19 in SPS.My team had to quickly gather requirements, procure handphone sets, sim cards and set them up within less than five hours after the cessation of visits between the inmates and their families was announced. The visit sessions were suspended during the Circuit Breaker period as part of our measures to prevent COVID-19 transmission in prisons. After the suspension, we explored alternatives to facilitate our inmates and their families to continue communicating with each other as they would be worried about their well-being during the Circuit Breaker period. We reviewed our operational processes and facilitated the five to ten-minute phone calls privileges for our inmates so that they could still communicate with their families during the Circuit Breaker period.One of the biggest challenges was finding a way to hold meetings virtually. The entire team rallied together and thats when I worked closely with SCW Ian Yeo, who helped to coordinate the technological support required for the staff at the Prisons Headquarters to work from home. With dedicated efforts from our staff who worked overtime, we were able to turn things around and set up VPN and video conferencing capabilities for our colleagues. It was personally fulfilling for me when we set up the video conferencing tools so that the inmates could still see their counsellors or teachers virtually and there would be no disruption in their rehabilitation programmes or school syllabuses. The use of technology plays an essential role in SPS, now more than ever. We are proud to have supported all our staff to ensure their day-to-day operations continue with no compromise in security and safety, and our inmates could continue with their rehabilitation journey.CaptainsOfLives SGUnited

When most of the measures are eased and lifted in the community for Phase 2 of the post Circuit Breaker, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) is still stringent on its measures to manage the newly admitted inmates - they are segregated for 14 days away from the general inmate population. Meet CW Ramesh Menon, one of our frontliners who is managing these inmates in the Changi Prison Complex! Its not easy being a frontliner as we have multiple roles to execute. I also have to put on full PPE when unlocking and supervising newly admitted inmates for their swab tests. Besides encouraging and reassuring inmates as they undergo testing for COVID-19, I must also keep an eye on the inmates to ensure that they maintain a safe distance from one another. In addition to maintaining the safe and secure custody of inmates under my charge, I also look for opportunities to influence them positively towards their rehabilitation journey.While there are added responsibilities on us as frontliners, I am grateful for the support that I have received from my family, colleagues and supervisors. It is my duty as a Captain of Lives to protect the safety of inmates and my colleagues to keep Singapore safe. Together, we can overcome this pandemic!SGUnited captainsoflives

When most of the measures are eased and lifted in the community for Phase 2 of the post Circuit Breaker, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) is still stringent on its measures to manage the newly admitted inmates - they are segregated for 14 days away from the general inmate population. Meet CW Ramesh Menon, one of our frontliners who is managing these inmates in the Changi Prison Complex! Its not easy being a frontliner as we have multiple roles to execute. I also have to put on full PPE when unlocking and supervising newly admitted inmates for their swab tests. Besides encouraging and reassuring inmates as they undergo testing for COVID-19, I must also keep an eye on the inmates to ensure that they maintain a safe distance from one another. In addition to maintaining the safe and secure custody of inmates under my charge, I also look for opportunities to influence them positively towards their rehabilitation journey.While there are added responsibilities on us as frontliners, I am grateful for the support that I have received from my family, colleagues and supervisors. It is my duty as a Captain of Lives to protect the safety of inmates and my colleagues to keep Singapore safe. Together, we can overcome this pandemic!SGUnited captainsoflives

How does working in the Logistics Branch contribute to the fight against COVID-19? I am Supt Cheam Tiong Pheng. This is my story on how my colleagues and I have contributed to the fight against COVID-19 by supporting our frontliners to carry out their duties in a safe and timely manner. Due to the pandemic, our workload has increased as there is a surge in demand for items such as Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), and disinfectants. Our job ensures that our frontliners are always protected and that is the sense of purpose I derive from my role at Logistics Branch. On a day to day basis, we work closely with other support officers like CW Rose, who is the Team Leader (Estate Management) for one of the Clusters CW Rose and officers from other Clusters help us to coordinate the logistical support required on the ground. When the Circuit Breaker first started, it was exceptionally difficult. We were encouraged to work from home, but our jobs needed us to be physically present to ensure our frontliners have what they require. We then adopted a tele-commuting system and came down only to deliver supplies to the institutions. With coordination efforts from officers like CW Rose and her team, and the split team arrangement, we ensure the safety of our team members is not compromised. As the saying goes, "alone we can do so little; together we can do so much. Logistics will always be a crucial part of ensuring the continuity of the great work our frontliners and ground staff do. If our frontliners are well equipped while on duty, we have helped to minimize the risk of COVID-19 outbreak in prisons. It is exciting to be part of a dynamic work environment - nothing feels better than providing support to our frontline officers to carry out their duties to protect the safety of our inmates and inspire them to become responsible citizens. Stay tuned to a series of stories featuring our CaptainsofLives who have carried out their duties diligently behind the scenes to support our frontliners in the battle against COVID-19!

Hi everyone, this year happens to be my eighth year with SPS but my first year being a father! I have an eight-month old son Syazil,who has brought joy to me and my wife since he came to this world. This is my story of being a first-time dad in the current COVID-19 situation. CaptainsofLives wishes all fathers, especially those who are braving the frontlines in the fight against COVID-19 - a HappyFathersDay! Meet Muhammad Syafiie Bin Imran, a first-time father, who works as a Reception Operations Officer in Cluster B with the Singapore Prison Service (SPS). First order of business when Im at work I will don my Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) as a precautionary measure before I interview the newly admitted inmates. Being a frontline officer and now a new dad, I am not only responsible for my safety, but also safety of the inmates, my colleagues, and ultimately my family. Its a huge responsibility to protect the safety of our inmates and colleagues we need to strictly adhere to every process and measure put in place to minimize the risk of COVID-19 transmissions in prisons. I take my job seriously as any lapse in the work process could have a dire consequence. Thus, I understand the position taken by SPS to be gradual and cautious in easing and lifting any measures even though Phase 2 of Singapores reopening has started.Initially, my wife was concerned about my safety as well as the safety of our eight-month old son. After I shared with her on all the precautionary and safety measures at my workplace, she now feels more assured and confident of my safety. Becoming a father has definitely spurred me to be a better role model, not just to my son but also to the inmates. I try to put myself in the shoes of the inmates to understand them better.By listening to their life stories and giving them encouragement, I hope that it will motivate them to kick-start their rehabilitation journey.Both my wife and I want our son to grow up as a curious and adventurous learner. We believe that he will learn best through the exposure to nature and exploration of the world around him. For now, my wife and I are grateful for the health of my son. Stay safe everyone!

There is always a brighter day after a storm. This was a heartfelt message penned by one of the 431 inmates from Cluster C for all staff at the Changi General Hospital. We believe these notes of gratitude speak for all of us across Singapore, and hope that those at the frontlines can draw strength from them during this difficult period. Even though its a festive season with our Muslim friends celebrating Hari Raya Aidilfitri, many of our frontliners are still hard at work. So on behalf of all of us here at the Singapore Prison Service, THANK YOU to all the frontliners for keeping us safe and secure!

Captains of Lives wish all Muslims Selamat Hari Raya Aidilfitri! Fasting in the month of Ramadan (Muslim calendar) is ending and celebrating Hari Raya this year will be different. It will be a reflective one but full of gratitude for the frontliners who are always ready to keep us safe, and our communities which support others who are in need during this crisis.Lets meet one of the frontliners from Singapore Prison Service, CaptainsofLives Mas Radinawati Binte Mazlan (Mas), and walk with her and her colleagues through their journey in the COVID-19 crisis. Tap to read!I am an Escort Officer at the State Court Lock Up (SCLU) within the Singapore Prison Service. Ive been with the Prisons for the past 11 years, but this year has been particularly different. From the time COVID-19 came into the picture, our processes and the way we work had to change, pronto! My colleagues and I had to take our temperatures twice daily to ensure that we are well when at work. We also had to implement social distancing measures at SCLU to ensure that our inmates and staff are safe.When the state court hearings were happening, we had to safeguard our inmates as well as our colleagues. To ensure inmates safety, we started to disinfect mechanical restraints and fetters after every use, amongst many other social distancing measures we put in place. We took the cleaning seriously to ensure the cleanliness of these items before being used by inmates. Prisons is a closed and high-density environment where viruses can spread easily if we are not vigilant in our work. We need to ensure the cleanliness and hygiene of the security equipment before they are used.Fasting from dawn till dusk during crisis is the ultimate test of my patience. However, I am glad to have supportive team members who will share the responsibilities with me so that I could break my fast. Great teamwork has made my job more bearable during this crisis. Ramadan has taught me the importance of perseverance.Although Hari Raya would not be the same for all of us this year, Im happy and proud that I am able to contribute in ensuring the safety of our inmates from being infected with COVID-19.

13 years with (not in) Prisons is a long time! But it has been a meaningful journey. As an Officer-in-Charge of a Housing Unit comprising about 400 inmates, my team and I manage inmates awaiting trials, and it has been challenging but yet rewarding. Some inmates felt lost and thought that life was over when they were admitted to prisons. I see it as my responsibility to engage and help them look for opportunities to turn over a new leaf while waiting for the outcomes of their trials. Those who heeded my advice became more settled in prisons and demonstrated positive behaviors.Then COVID-19 came into the picture! It has made my job even more demanding. As CaptainsofLives, we are frontliners working hard to prevent an outbreak in prisons. Many precautionary measures had to be put in place to ensure the safety of our staff and inmates.To be honest, it has not been easy. This pandemic has disrupted not just our day-to-day life but also the operational routines in prisons. Being nimble, agile, and vigilant at all times has helped us cope with the situation to keep our prisons safe and secure. Its not just the safety of our inmates or colleagues we are responsible for, but also our families we return to at the end of our long day at work. When my family found out that I had to work during the Circuit Breaker period, they were extremely supportive and that kept me motivated.Its always been duty before self. Once the crisis is over, I am looking forward to a celebration with my family and my teammates, who have been supportive and giving their best for the past few months.Together, we will overcome COVID-19! SGUnited

Meet our CaptainsOfLives Syarifah a dedicated mum of four and also a Personal Supervisor at Institution A4 to find out how she maintains work-life harmony amid the COVID-19 situation.3Ps - Passion, Patience & Positivity - are the values she holds being a frontliner at work and a super mum at home. Syarifah confided, its not easy to be in an essential service at this moment, but my kids are my motivation. They always remind me to wear my mask and be safe. They also make it a point to say, Mama, Im proud of you and that really keeps me going. Juggling between her long hours at work and having kids at home is challenging but she shared her secret on what keeps her family bonded during these times. Once she reaches home, she makes a point to gather her kids and chat about their days while enjoying some food. No topics are out of bounds and it's moments like these that are sacred to her and make her feel her sacrifices are worth it in the end. Over the past 17 years, Ive had inmates confiding in me and I try my best to provide a listening ear to them. Being a mum of four, I do that all the time at home too, so its not new to me. I feel that supporting inmates at every step of their rehabilitation journey is so important because it gives them hope for a better future. We salute all Mothers around the world, and especially those who are working hard to keep Singapore safe and secure during these unprecedented times. Thank you and we wish you a happy MothersDay!SGUnited SPSUnited

No topics are out of bounds and it's moments like these that are sacred to her and make her feel her sacrifices are worth it in the end. Over the past 17 years, Ive had inmates confiding in me and I try my best to provide a listening ear to them. Being a mum of four, I do that all the time at home too, so its not new to me. I feel that supporting inmates at every step of their rehabilitation journey is so important because it gives them hope for a better future. We salute all Mothers around the world, and especially those who are working hard to keep Singapore safe and secure during these unprecedented times. Thank you and we wish you a happy MothersDay!SGUnited SPSUnited

Interested applicants may submit your application by 29 February via this link:

Meet Chief Warder Joann and Chief Warder Cleve she's a Senior Personal Supervisor at Institution A4 and he's a Team Leader at the Singapore Prisons Emergency Action Response (SPEAR) Force. Over a decade ago, they bumped into each other in a lift at the same HDB block they live in and today, theyve been happily married for 9 years!When asked about how its like working together within the Singapore Prison Service, Joann said, I think its great because not many people understand the line of work we do and to have someone who understands what I'm going through I am grateful for that, as we are able to share and learn from each other." Even though their paths crossed at work, Cleve says, "We are able to remain professional and deconflict. We do not mix work and personal matters when we are together." Akin to any other couples, ValentinesDay celebrations are a yearly ritual! This year, a simple dinner date after work is in the works for this couple, as they believe that the company is what matters! We cant help but agree whether your significant other is from work or elsewhere, have a Happy Valentines' Day!

As a repeated offender and drug abuser, Rahman (not his real name) has been in and out of prison since 2007. He is currently in the Drug Rehabilitation Centre (DRC) for drug consumption.Rahman expressed that the rehabilitation programmes he has undergone this time at the DRC have helped him gained better emotional control. He said, "The group counselling sessions that I attended have helped me manage my emotions... and identify my trigger points... and helped me open up to people when I need help." BehindPrisonWalls

There were 2,415 offenders placed on community corrections programmes at the end of last year about 20% more than the year before. This increase is part of the Singapore Prison Services (SPS) step-down approach to help offenders transit more smoothly back to society after their release, while still being supervised. During the same period, the in-care population in SPS also showed a slight drop. The support of the community goes a long way to help in their reintegration. BeyondPrisonWalls SG4SecondChances

When Rehabilitation Officer (RO) Mohamed Faizal Bin Abdul Hamid was younger, he knew that he wanted to pursue a career that was stable, which led to him joining the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) in 2008. "Before joining the service, I was playing Soccer professionally. After achieving my goals and dreams, I decided to pursue a job thats stable and I decided that I wanted a career in the uniform service. "After looking through the job requirements, I decided to become a Prison Officer and I must admit that the tagline 'Captains Of Lives' did play a part in my decision to join the SPS. "It has been 12 enjoyable and enriching years. Each time I bump into any of my ex-inmates, seeing them do well with their families and thanking me for taking care of them, makes me feel that all the hard work I've put into my work is worthwhile," said RO Faizal.

Earlier this month, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) and Singapore Police Force (SPF) clinched the top spot in a Hostage Negotiation Competition. The annual competition, held from 13 to 16 January at the Texas State University in the US, brought together teams from 40 different law enforcement and correctional agencies across the US and other countries to handle a simulated hostage situation. The Singapore team comprised five officers from the Prison Negotiation Unit (PNU) and two officers from SPFs Crisis Negotiation Unit (CNU). This is the third year in a row that PNU has taken part in the competition, and the first time that CNU has taken part in the event. In winning this years competition, the combined team from SPS and SPF had successfully validated their hostage negotiation capabilities. At the same time, the experience had allowed the team to learn and gain new knowledge from their overseas counterparts.

Swipe and join us as we challenge our prison officers to experience half a day in the Singapore Prisons Emergency Action Response Tactical Course (STC) to see how far they go!After being selected for the SPEAR force, trainees undergo a 4-month Tactical Course that equips them with skills such asRappelling, Close Quarters Riot Control and High Risk Escort.Only trainees who have successfully completed the STC will be able to don the prestigious SPEAR insignia, a winged emblem worn exclusively by SPEAR officers.

When she first started teaching at Prison School in 2014, Ms Sem Hui Leng did not know what to expect. At first, she was apprehensive about being able to get the inmate students to pay attention to her class, but her fears were unfounded when she walked into a class full of warm and attentive inmate students on her first day of teaching in Prison School.Learning in Prison School is also kept at a much faster pace than the normal secondary school curriculum. "The 4 years of secondary school curriculum is compressed to a shorter time frame of 9 months before our students sit for the GCE 'N' and 'O' Level at the end of the year," said Ms Sem, who is the Head Studies, Administration and Character & Citizenship Education at Prison School.Despite the challenges that inmate students may face in adjusting to the rigorous and taxing study routine, Ms Sem said: "[The students] never fail to complete and submit their homework by the deadlines. The levels of diligence, tenacity and perseverance they have demonstrated are highly admirable." BehindPrisonWalls

What I do as CaptainsOfLives: "I am responsible for the smooth running of operations and manpower deployment and to oversee external movement of inmates." Mr Lau Tai Leong, Chief Cluster Control Centre Officer (Cluster A)

What I do as CaptainsOfLives: "I am responsible for managing external movement operations and overseeing staff motivation and development." Mr Choo Chee Wah, Team Leader (Complex Escort Unit, Operations & Security Command)

Mr Achik Bin Ithnin has been a volunteer with Singapore Prison Service (SPS) since 2004. He provides religious counselling six days a week to Muslim inmates through Fitrah - Family and Inmates ThRoughcare Assistance Haven. "Receiving this award from SPS makes me want to work harder because it means that the prisons appreciates the work that I have put in," said Mr Achik who was a recipient of the Long Service Award (Gold) at the SPS Volunteers Awards Ceremony 2019.Through his volunteer work, Mr Achik said, "I do observe changes in offenders, in terms of their character and their thinking, but such things takes time to change and cannot be rushed." BeyondPrisonWalls

What I do as CaptainsOfLives: "I am responsible for liaising with vendors on family resource services and programmes, and handling administrative matters for prison visits." Ms Siti Fatimah Binte Mohamad Nor, Assistant Executive (Family Policy), Rehabilitation & Reintegration Division

As a Staff Officer for the Community & Family Policy Branch, Rehabilitation & Reintegration Division, ASP 2 Muhammad Ali Bin Mochtar supports the throughcare journey of offenders by working closely with various community partners. "It is natural for a volunteer to feel anxious about not knowing the profile of the offenders. They may think that prisons is a depressing place and offenders may be dangerous, but our volunteers will be sensitised to all of this through training. They are also encouraged to tag along with experienced volunteers so that they will be familiar and comfortable with the environment," said ASP Ali. BeyondPrisonWalls Volunteers Befriender

What I do as CaptainsOfLives: "I uphold the SPS brand by creating high quality visuals and documenting key milestones in SPS." Mr D'Cruz Bruce Russell, Digital Media Officer (Corporate Communications & Relations Division)

Through Mr John Lee's work as a defence counsel, an interaction with an inmate motivated him to volunteer with Singapore Prison Service (SPS) through Prison Fellowship Singapore. Now at 70, he has spent 35 years offering religious programmes to inmates at Changi Prison Complex. "As a volunteer, I befriend [the inmates], talk to them and listen to whatever is troubling them. If you give them a listening ear, they will be open to connecting with you. Our idea is to work with them from inside and follow up with them when they leave the prison," said Mr Lee, who was a recipient of the Long Service Award (Gold) at the SPS Volunteers Awards Ceremony 2019. BeyondPrisonWalls
What I do as CaptainsOfLives: "I explore opportunities to involve families and community agencies in supporting the reintegration of offenders." MX11A Jessie Wong, Assistant Director (Family Policy)

It was October 3rd when alarms were blasting the entire Institution B1 of Changi Prison Complex. A group of "rioters" had damaged and taken control of a prison workshop. Almost immediately, a team of prison officers were assembled to manage the situation while another team situated themselves in the Institution Operations Room, plotting plans to prevent the "riot" from escalating further. A eight-man team from the Singapore Prisons Emergency Action Response (SPEAR) Force responded and swiftly quelled the mock prison riot by subduing the "rioters" with non-lethal pistols and launchers that fire pellets. In a matter of seconds, all the "rioters" were subdued. SUPT Ng Kim Seng, Assistant Commander (Operations) for Cluster B, said: "Riot is considered a major incident in prison because it can lead to a high number of casualties, and inmates would start to damage our prison properties, which would threaten the secure custody of the prisoners," "When a riot happens, the ground officers will try to minimise casualties and manage the incident to the best of their abilities. If the situation goes out of control, they will escalate upwards to seek support from other units such as SPEAR and K9 to come in and help quell the riot." BehindPrisonWalls

In a matter of seconds, all the "rioters" were subdued. SUPT Ng Kim Seng, Assistant Commander (Operations) for Cluster B, said: "Riot is considered a major incident in prison because it can lead to a high number of casualties, and inmates would start to damage our prison properties, which would threaten the secure custody of the prisoners," "When a riot happens, the ground officers will try to minimise casualties and manage the incident to the best of their abilities. If the situation goes out of control, they will escalate upwards to seek support from other units such as SPEAR and K9 to come in and help quell the riot." BehindPrisonWalls

What I do as CaptainsOfLives: "I ensure that services or goods are supplied in accordance with the contractual requirements in operations-related contracts to support the continuity of services and smooth operations." MX12 Emma Sow Yok Khee, Executive(Operations Services & Contracts)

It was time to appreciate those who have taken time out to give back to society. This years Singapore Prison Service (SPS) Volunteers Awards Ceremony saw 350 awards presented to community partners, individual volunteers and organisations who have dedicated their time to support the rehabilitation and reintegration of offenders and ex-offenders. Themed Kaleidoscope of Heroes, the ceremony was graced by Senior Parliamentary Secretary for Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of Health, Mr . With your diverse skills and backgrounds, you are better able to reach out to offenders, [who] also come from different situations and backgrounds. He added, It is most rewarding to see how your individual contributions come together beautifully, like the patterns you see when you look through a kaleidoscope, said Mr Amrin.Congratulations to all the awardees, and thank you to all the community partners and volunteers for the hard work!BeyondPrisonWalls

This year, 30 inmate volunteers at Changi Prison Complex participated in packing 50,000 funpacks for the general public. We thank for including inmates in this year's National Day Parade celebrations. We would also like to wish Singapore a Happy 54th National Day! BehindPrisonWalls NDP2019 OurSingapore ALittleMoreSG

The Singapore Prisons Emergency Action Response (SPEAR) Force participated in the annual Mock Prison Riot (MPR) in May this year at the decommissioned West Virginia Penitentiary in Moundsville, United States. The team of five SPEAR Force officers, consisting of CW Ang Kian Heng, CW Tow Chee Choy, CW Muhammad Noor Bin Farid, SSGT Toe Hengli and SGT Muhammad Sadikin Nurfaqih Bin Ahmad, pitted their skills against 35 law enforcement and correctional agencies around the world. The elite SPEAR Force tactical team competed in five events and managed to emerge first place in two of the eventsTeam Obstacle Course and Hostage Rescue Open Air Initiated Resolution. SSGT Toe said: We trained very hard prior to this competition, especially for the Team Obstacle Course. We had a winning mindset and were determined to win every event.Through participating in the MPR, the SPEAR Force were also able to learn about other correctional agencies strategies and techniques when it comes to preparing and responding to prison contingencies. CaptainsOfLives BeyondPrisonWalls

In line with this years National Day message of inclusivity, the celebration outreach committee felt that it was important to include Singaporeans from all walks of life to celebrate Singapore's National Day.The Reach Out project gives inmates at Changi Prison Complex the opportunity to show their love for Singapore by volunteering to help pack the NDP funpacks for the general public.Lieutenant-Colonel (NS) Hoe Kok Wei, Chairman of the NDP Celebration Outreach Committee, said: From the perspective of the committee, we actually took the opportunity to ensure that the celebration is not confined to the mainstream, and every Singaporean [gets to] participate in this celebration.We actually serve to use the NDP platform and the celebrations as an avenue to bring different groups of people in Singapore to come together, regardless of their background.BehindPrisonWalls NDP2019 OurSingapore ALittleMoreSG

ASP2 David John George, Senior Inspectorate Officer CaptainsOfLives

As part of this years National Day Parade (NDP ) celebrations, Reach Out gave inmates the chance to pack the NDP funpacks. It is one of the community service initiatives undertaken by inmates, allowing them to participate in meaningful activities that benefit the community.Senior Chief Warder 1 Illamaran Thamizhkkothai, Chief Personal Supervisor at Institution B5 of Changi Prison Complex, oversees the inmate volunteers who are helping to pack the NDP funpacks. The inmates here feel very proud and honoured to take part in this funpacking. They feel that they are part of Singapore [and by] doing this for the people and the country, it is very meaningful for them, said SCW Thamizhkkothai. She also shared that the inmate volunteers are generally in high spirits and very enthusiastic during their shifts, as they are motivated to hit their goal of packing 50,000 funpacks by July. CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls NDP2019 OurSingapore ALittleMoreSG

What I do as CaptainsOfLives: "I lead my team to work hand in hand with the Night Duty Officer to maintain order and security for smooth night operations." CW2 A Mariadas S/O Arokiasamy, Night Duty Team Leader CaptainsOfLives

John (not his real name) is one of the 30 inmate volunteers who participated in the "Reach Out" project. The project, an initiative under the National Day Parade (NDP ) outreach campaign, aims to give inmates a chance to make a meaningful contribution for Singapores National Day. I volunteered because first and foremost I am a Singaporean, and its really a chance for me to get involved in NDP because my closest involvement was just watching it on television. But this time around, I get to actually contribute to it and be a part of the National Day Parade, which is not something that many Singaporeans can say [they did], said John. Over the span of five weeks, John and the other inmate volunteers took on six-hour daily shifts on weekdays, to pack an estimated 3,000 funpacks per day for the upcoming NDP. As this is also Johns first time participating in a community outreach programme, he said: The work makes me feel very productive, and it just makes me feel like I am growing as a person. BehindPrisonWalls NDP2019 OurSingapore ALittleMoreSG

What I do as CaptainsOfLives: "I engage our beneficiaries to achieve mutual understanding of the concerns raised and develop intiatives to advance the level of service excellence in SPS." ASP Liang Xiaowen, Staff Officer (Quality Service, Corporate Communications & Relations Division) CaptainsOfLives

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) works with various religious organisations such as Fitrah - Family and Inmates ThRoughcare Assistance Haven (FITRAH) to support Muslim inmates and ex-offenders in their rehabilitation and reintegration journey. "FITRAH is something which is new [and spearheaded] by the Islamic Religious Council of Singapore (MUIS) its a coordinating body that work with other community partners within the Malay-Muslim organisations like MENDAKI Singapore , People's Association Malay Activity Executive Committees Council (MESRA) to provide weekly Muslim religious programmes and services for inmates in incare, said SUPT Faisal Mustaffa, Superintendent at Institution B4 of Changi Prison. Additionally, FITRAH offers aftercare assistance BeyondPrisonWalls by reaching out to ex-offenders upon their release at the prison gate and issuing a Back-To-FITRAH package that helps ex-offenders begin a new life. This is symbolic of a new start in their lives and the beginning of a journey of reintegration into society.

What I do as CaptainsOfLives: "I enforce the discipline amongst the Administrative Segregation Regime (ASR) inmates - it may be challenging at times but I'm proud to be part of the united ASR team." CW2 Sim Keh Soon, Chief Personal Supervisor CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls

What I do as CaptainsOfLives: "I am involved in budget planning to ensure that SPS has sufficient budget to carry out current operations, as well as to build capabilities for future needs." ASP1 Muhammad Rahmat Bin Sulaiman, Staff Officer(Resource Planning) CaptainsOfLives

This Fathers Day, the Singapore Prison Service recognises that familial support is important in the reintegration journey of inmates. Life in prison is tough, but it is especially difficult for inmates who live apart from their families. By introducing family programmes in prison, we seek to strengthen bonds between inmates and their family even from behind bars. With this, inmates will be prepared for a life after prison and re-connect them with their family whom they have been apart from for some time.To all fathers out there, wed like to wish you a HappyFathersDay! BehindPrisonWalls

As CaptainsOfLives, this is how we keep Singapore safe and secure: "I contribute to the rehabilitation of inmates by using evidence-formed psychological approaches to address their criminogenic and mental health needs." HTS Rashida Mohamed Zain, Assistant Director (Psychological Services Branch) BehindPrisonWalls
Selamat Hari Raya to all our Muslim friends, from CaptainsOfLives!

[4/4] OBSERVING RAMADAN BEHINDPRISONWALLS: We spoke to Rehabilitation Officer (RO) Mohamed Faizal Bin Abdul Hamid on the challenges of keeping Singapore safe and secure, while fasting. "When we fall in for briefings, our Head Ops would remind us to be vigilant during our tour of duty. Similarly, in the Housing Unit, my colleagues and I would constantly look out for and remind each other to remain alert," said RO Faizal. Even though fasting while on duty may sometimes be challenging for RO Faizal, he is thankful for his kind and understanding colleagues who help make his day better. He said: Some of our non-Muslim teammates would offer to take on more tasks. In fact, most of them are sensitive towards our situation, as they dont eat and drink in our presence, which we find really considerate and thoughtful." CaptainsOfLives Photo: Muhamad Darwisy Haroon

[3/4] OBSERVING RAMADAN BEHINDPRISONWALLS: Ramadan is known to be a month of fasting, prayer and reflection for Muslims. We asked Rehabilitation Officer (RO) Mohamed Faizal Bin Abdul Hamid what changes he observed in the inmates under his charge. During this time, we can see an increase in their religious obligations like reading the Quran and performing terawih (non-obligatory prayers) in their cells," said RO Faizal. Inmates can also attend weekly religious classes and prayer sessions conducted by volunteers. By interacting with these volunteers, inmates are introduced to pro-social networks which they can depend on upon their release. During conversations with the inmates under my charge, I can sense their regret and resolve to ensure that this will be their last Ramadan in prison, as they reflect on how their actions have led to them being taken away from their families." CaptainsOfLives Photo: Muhamad Darwisy Haroon

By interacting with these volunteers, inmates are introduced to pro-social networks which they can depend on upon their release. During conversations with the inmates under my charge, I can sense their regret and resolve to ensure that this will be their last Ramadan in prison, as they reflect on how their actions have led to them being taken away from their families." CaptainsOfLives Photo: Muhamad Darwisy Haroon

[2/4] OBSERVING RAMADAN BEHINDPRISONWALLS: We spoke to Rehabilitation Officer (RO) Mohamed Faizal Bin Abdul Hamid on the challenges of keeping Singapore safe and secure, while fasting. One of the obvious challenges during Ramadan is not being able to eat and drink while performing our duties, said RO Faizal. "Our shifts last up to 12 hours, during which, we are required to be vigilant to keep the housing units safe and secure." During Ramadan, there are additional operations to help facilitate inmates who are observing the holy month. For example, some staff will be detailed beyond their working hours to help supervise the issuance of medication. Some daily routines are changed to accommodate the Muslim inmates who are fasting," explains RO Faizal. "The lights and water are turned on earlier and turned off later so that inmates can have their pre-dawn meals and prayers. The kitchen staff also have to start prepping dinner earlier for Muslim inmates who are breaking fast in the evening. CaptainsOfLives Photo: Muhamad Darwisy Haroon

[1/4] OBSERVING RAMADAN BEHINDPRISONWALLS: During the holy month of Ramadan, Muslims around the world abstain from drinking, eating and are encouraged to increase acts of worship such as reading the Quran. But how is Ramadan observed in the Drug Rehabilitation Centre at Institution B5, Changi Prison Complex BehindPrisonWalls? Stay tuned as we show you the challenges that Rehabilitation Officer Mohamed Faizal Bin Abdul Hamid goes through as he carries out his duties to keep Singapore safe and secure, all while fasting. CaptainsOfLives Photo: Muhamad Darwisy Haroon

The Singapore Prison Service recognises that good family support is essential in the inmates rehabilitation and reintegration journey. We seek to encourage inmates to take greater ownership of their rehabilitation, by leveraging on their families as a source of motivation for change in their reintegration process, and finding ways to maintain and strengthen familial bonds. To ensure the success of our efforts, it is vital for us to work in collaboration with our community partners and agencies specialising in family services. - Ms Jessie Wong, Assistant Director (Family Policy), Rehabilitation & Reintegration Division. BeyondPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

SGT Muhammad Nurhakeem Bin Sukor was one of the 61 officers who graduated from the Prison Officer Course last week. In attendance, was his proud mother who removed the white training bands from his epaulette, signifying the start to being a CaptainsOfLives.This Mothers Day, SGT Nurhakeem is grateful to his mother who has always taught him to be an honest man in everything he does. He said, Integrity is a core component of the job. My mother advised me never to cut corners and always follow processes diligently, even if there might be an easier way out. As a prison officer, I strive to be an honest man who can help inmates in their rehabilitation journey, I believe I can only achieve this if I am true to myself. Wishing all mothers a HappyMothersDay! Photo credit: Muhd Darwisy Haroon

Humbled by his National Youth Achievement Award (NYAA) Gold award win, Ahmad (not his real name) shares how he has bonded with his trainers and changed for the better. "The [NYAA programme] was fun because I gained a lot of new experiences and knowledge such as first aid skills. I was also given the opportunity to lead a class. I don't really know how people see me but I do think I have some leadership skills in me and I want to help others as well." Under the supervision of his officers, Ahmad was able to conduct a lesson in rope tying to the rest of his class. Having displayed initiative and gaining newfound confidence, Ahmad is looking forward to his upcoming release date and going home to his mother's home-cooked food. BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

The annual Singapore Prison Service (SPS) - SCORE (Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises) Corporate Advance was graced by Guest of Honour, Mrs Josephine Teo, Minister for Manpower and Second Minister for Home Affairs earlier today. The theme 2Gather Effecting Change, Transforming Lives reiterated the importance of working with the community to achieve better rehabilitation and reintegration outcomes for offenders and ex-offenders. This years Corporate Advance focused on SPSs family programmes and SCOREs employability enhancement initiatives, which were realised with the strong support from the community partners.SPS will continue to collaborate with the community to enhance rehabilitation and reintegration outcomes at various stages of inmates incarceration to create an ecosystem that provides seamless support for offenders and ex-offenders. CaptainsOfLives BeyondPrisonWalls

About 128 inmates aged 25 and below received the National Youth Achievement Awards (NYAA) yesterday. This year, the inmates produced exemplary results and there were two Gold award winners.A new addition to the NYAA programme was the introduction of the Train-the-Trainers model. This initiative enabled the prison officers to be more involved in the NYAA Programme by imparting them with skills and knowledge, and served as an opportunity for them to build stronger rapport with the inmates.Guest of Honour Senior Parliamentary Secretary, Ministry of Social and Family Development & Ministry of Education, A/P Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim congratulated the award winners and commended their efforts in developing qualities of self-reliance, perseverance and a sense of responsibility to themselves and the community.Kudos to our NYAA award recipients this year who have done us proud! BehindPrisonWalls

Art plays a central role in our rehabilitation efforts, helping inmates develop and cultivate their creative talents. More than 800 inmates have participated in various rehabilitative art programmes at the Visual Arts Hub since its inception in 2007. Inmates with good conduct, have a keen interest in art and committed to their rehabilitation can apply for the three-month long programme where they will be exposed to subjects such as batik painting, pottery and acrylic painting. These programmes aim to nurture the artistic potential, encourage creative insights and facilitate positive change in the mindset. Ultimately, art can help ex-offenders unlock their potential in employment, education and eventual reintegration into society. BehindPrisonWalls

This is Mr Elijah Teo, currently the Deputy Executive Director, Selarang Halfway House (SHWH). During the official opening of the halfway house we managed to speak to him about how different SHWH is from the other halfway houses and what are some of the ways they help ex-offenders. "Most of the residents we take in have already found employment, some are medically unfit and some are in transition as they have just been released. SHWH also helps to facilitate job searches for the residents who have just been released. Working alongside correctional rehabilitation specialists, reintegration officers and the rest of the programme staff, we journey with the offenders to the best of our ability." BeyondPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives YRConfessions

INSIDE THE WOMEN'S PRISON: As Rehabilitation Officer (RO 1) Ng Kia Yi reaches the end of her shift, another squad falls in for a briefing to take over her shift. Despite feeling the physical exhaustion, RO 1 Ng Kia Yi says this of becoming a CaptainsOfLives: I decided to join as a Captain of Lives as it not only fulfills what I was looking for in a job, it is also a meaningful career to be a catalyst of change and where I can see myself being in for the long-term. [5/5] INSIDE THE WOMEN'S PRISON: We ask Rehabilitation Officer (RO 1) Ng Kia Yi what is the biggest misconception about CaptainsOfLives and what are the unique challenges of working in a women's prison. RO 1 Ng Kia Yi: "I think the biggest misconception is that being a Captain of Lives (COL) is just about locking and unlocking of inmates and it is a simple job. Actually, we play a multi-faceted role as a COL - being coaches, disciplinarians and mentors to the inmates under our charge. As women are more expressive, one of the main challenges is learning how to handle and guide them in processing their emotions. Rehabilitation also has to be gender-specific as men and women respond differently in similar situations." BehindPrisonWalls

[4/5] INSIDE THE WOMEN'S PRISON: We spoke to Rehabilitation Officer (RO 1) Ng Kia Yi on her challenges performing a 12-hour shift during the Lunar New Year, and if she was expecting changes in inmates' behaviour due to the festive season. RO 1 Ng Kia Yi: There are some inmates who are more emotional during festive seasons because of various reasons such as missing their family and that they are unable to celebrate CNY with their loved ones. My colleagues and I are always on the lookout for changes in behaviour in our inmates and finding out if they require someone to talk to. BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

[2/5] INSIDE THE WOMEN'S PRISON: While many of us are surrounded by our loved ones during Lunar New Year, Rehabilitation Officer (RO 1) Ng Kia Yi from Institution A4 will be performing a 12-hour shift to keep Singapore safe and secure. We spoke to her on how her sacrifices and those of other CaptainsOfLives keep Singapore safe while everyone else is on holiday. RO 1 Ng Kia Yi: I was looking for a job that was less desk-bound, something that gives me the opportunity to interact with others. Being a uniformed officer, I was always prepared to have to work on CNY if necessary. Hence, I guess I did not feel as bummed about missing out on part of CNY. Colleagues of other races are always willing to swap shifts or cover their Chinese colleagues. We try our best to allow our colleagues to have the PH off to celebrate their festive holiday. Working on CNY will mean that I will miss out on some gatherings and meals with my family and friends. However, I am thankful that my family and friends are understanding enough and are willing to work around my work schedule to accommodate me."BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

We spoke to her on how her sacrifices and those of other CaptainsOfLives keep Singapore safe while everyone else is on holiday. RO 1 Ng Kia Yi: I was looking for a job that was less desk-bound, something that gives me the opportunity to interact with others. Being a uniformed officer, I was always prepared to have to work on CNY if necessary. Hence, I guess I did not feel as bummed about missing out on part of CNY. Colleagues of other races are always willing to swap shifts or cover their Chinese colleagues. We try our best to allow our colleagues to have the PH off to celebrate their festive holiday. Working on CNY will mean that I will miss out on some gatherings and meals with my family and friends. However, I am thankful that my family and friends are understanding enough and are willing to work around my work schedule to accommodate me."BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

We would like to wish everyone a Happy Lunar New Year! Here's to a New Year spent among your friends and loved ones. To all our staff working this Lunar New Year, thank you for your contributions in helping to keep Singapore safe and secure.CaptainsOfLives

As a Personal Supervisor in charge of casework, I manage DRC inmates from admission to release. I conduct orientation briefings and facilitate referrals to get them the help they need. When they are due for release, I assist them by making sure they have a place to stay. Part of my work involves engaging their family members and exploring ways to involve them in the reintegration journey. As a Captain of Lives, I help inmates break the cycle of addiction and reintegrate into society. - CW1 Muzakir Bin Mohamad Ariff, Personal Supervisor BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

Hey there, my name is ASP Venu Arsh and I am a trainer in SPEAR Force and I oversee tactical re-certification for HQ officers and SPEAR Tactical Course. I am very passionate about training others. I take responsibility in ensuring all my fellow COL's are tactically proficient and physically fit to carry out duties regardless of the institution. I also help to train our prison officers to make tactical decisions and operational judgement in different environment in either Cluster or external settings. During our training, we learn from each others mistakes and are toughened through hard knocks but had good coaches who guided us in tough times.I am still a passionate and proud COL after 10 years and I want to be the positive change in the lives of my fellow COLs. Time flies and I still enjoy every moment as a COL with the Singapore Prison Service. BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives 10YearsChallenge

Back in 2009, I was new in service and was working with Institution A4 Reformative Training Centre boys who were around my age. There were so many challenges attending to them and trying to understand them. I remember feeling disheartened at times and questioned myself if I could perform well for SPS. I had so much to learn since I was a young, inexperienced officer. Fortunately, I was very thankful to have colleagues who guided and motivated me and ensured that I carried out my basic jailcraft as a Prison Officer dutifully. Fast forward 10 years to today and I am still in A4! But this time around, I am managing women offenders which come with its own set of challenges. Ive learnt so much in the past 10 years and really feel Ive become a thinking officer while instilling fairness in my duties. I hope that I will continue serving SPS for the next 10 years as I believe it will be an exciting story to tell in 2029 especially now that we are moving towards Transformational Environment. So hello, 10yearschallenge, I think Im ready for you thanks to all the experiences I have gained and gone through to become the proud CaptainsOfLives I am today! - Chief Warder Herdawati BahriBeyondPrisonWalls

Last week, Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law, Mr K Shanmugam graced the official opening of the new Singapore Prison Service headquarters. The new headquarters, which is located within the Changi Prison Complex, allows for better synergy between staff and ground officers while enabling better command and control over prison operations. Harnessing technology to operate a secure and exemplary prison system, our uniformed officers and civilian staff work together to steer offenders towards becoming responsible citizens with the help of their families and the community.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls

To provide greater aftercare support for ex-offenders, the Selarang Halfway House is the first Government-run facility to provide structured aftercare support for selected ex-offenders who are emplaced on the Mandatory Aftercare Scheme.The newly operationalised facility is designed to provide a conducive rehabilitative environment for ex-offenders after their release from prison. They will attend counselling sessions and are allowed to work or attend vocational training during their stay there. Staff from Selarang Halfway House will work with the residents to address their reintegration challenges, adopt more prosocial behaviours and facilitate their progress in the reintegration journey. Through these efforts, we hope to help them break away from their cycle of re-offending and continue living crime-free lives in the community. CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

"Volunteers are a positive source of influence that inmates and ex-offenders can turn to upon their release or if they need help," said Superintendent (SUPT) Valerie Chiang, who is also the Senior Assistant Director of the Community & Family Policy Branch.She shared that volunteers come from all walks of life including secular and religious groups, and play an important role in supporting our initiatives and rehabilitation. "Volunteers really value-add to the rehabilitative efforts that SPS is putting in as pro-social support is something that is very important and isn't readily available. Community partners such as Volunteer Welfare Organisations and SPS befrienders offer a source of positive influence that these inmates can turn to upon their release. By meeting people who can journey with them, this positive influence can lead inmates to the path of the straight and narrow. " she said. While we believe that inmates need to take charge of their own rehabilitation, prison volunteers and community partners also play a vital role in supporting inmates rehabilitation and reintegration into society. This helps us in our vision of a society without re-offending.CaptainsofLives BeyondPrisonWalls

PART 4/4: SPEAR SelectionThe end is near when the candidates moved on to the final stage of the SPEAR selection, the panel interview. Make it or break it? This is their last straw.The 10 candidates were all gathered in a room, while they catch their breath and prepare for the final call. Their heartbeat got faster each time the SPEAR trainer walks into the room and calls out the name of a candidate to attend the panel interview.We took the time to speak to then-SPEAR Commander, Ong Aik San, on what traits do the Elite force look out for in a SPEAR Officer. The candidate has to be strong and disciplined. After they finish the initial training to be a SPEAR officer, it is up to them to maintain their fitness and tactical level. captainsoflives behindprisonwalls

Christmas is the season to celebrate family ties, forgiveness and love. It is a special day for reconnecting with loved ones and striving for improvement in the year to come. From the Captains of Lives, we wish everyone a Merry Christmas and a happy new year!

To enhance the employability of inmates, the Singapore Prison Service partners with the Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) to offer a WSQ (Workforce Skills Qualifications) Advanced Training under the WSQ Culinary Skills framework. Inmates will undergo up to seven WSQ-certified modules at the Hope Caf, a training facility within the Changi Prison Complex . This will equip them with vocational skills that are highly sought-after by potential F&B employers. As Captains of Lives, we believe that with the right opportunities and support from employers, inmates with relevant training can reintegrate well into the society and contribute to the workforce.CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) and the Association for Muslim Professionals (AMP) recently launched a new Throughcare Programme targeted at providing additional support to Malay-Muslim offenders serving their detention at the Drug Rehabilitation Centre.Assistant Superintendent Muhammad Ali Mochtar, who works closely with community partners, emphasised the importance of the Malay-Muslim community coming forward to support these offenders and their families, adding that the foundations of rehabilitation start inside prison but support from the community must extend beyond prison walls. "Research has shown that offenders face reintegration issues upon their release, and that the family and community play an important part in supporting their rehabilitation.The Throughcare Programme aims to make reintegration less challenging for these offenders by offering them community support from the onset of their incarceration and the period after." BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

For the first time, prison inmates, like Alex Tan, 32, now have a chance to study for a diploma. The signing of a Letter of Understanding by the Singapore Prison Service and Ngee Ann Polytechnic signifies a new chapter at the Prison School which traditionally only offered inmates N, O and A level courses while they served their sentences. The Diploma in Business Practice (International Supply Chain Management) will equip students with knowledge and skills in logistics, supply chain management and business management. Students can carry on with the remaining modules at NPs Continuing Education & Training Academy after their release. Upon graduation, they will be able to pursue employment in industries such as third party logistics companies and supply chain solution providers.Alex, who enrolled for the diploma course, said: Im grateful to have the opportunity to pursue this diploma with Ngee Ann Poly. The learning curve has not been easy for me, but the lecturers do their best to explain to the class. I want to be able to continue with my studies and pursue employment in the logistics field when I am released. BehindPrisonWalls captainsoflives

PART 3/4: SPEAR SelectionAfter Lunch: Wearing thick suits, the candidates wore facemasks and navigated through the obstacles. Breathing becomes restricted with masks on but they persevered. We spoke to second-time candidate for the SPEAR Selection Ik Kee, who mentioned that he completed the individual segment last year but did not meet the time requirement. "Joining SPEAR force has always been my dream. Even though I did not make it for the selection last year, I was determined to conquer it this year. I increased the frequencies of my training, prepared myself mentally and physically before I came for this selection, says Ik Kee.It was not long before the candidates were tested on their team camaraderie. Working as a team, the candidates lifted dummy casualties, each weighing as much as an adult and made their rounds along the parade square. The pouring rain had no effect on the candidates as they managed to muster enough energy to complete the group segment.BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

In this season of giving, nothing can be more precious than giving the family members of the Performing Arts Centre (PAC) inmates the chance to catch them live in concert.After the performance, they handed over a handmade card filled with their thoughts to their family members and were treated to an open visit, where they could hug and talk to their family members. While some shared their deepest remorse with their parents, others were delighted to hear about new additions in their family.As Captains of Lives, we recognise that family support is crucial in the rehabilitation journey of inmates. By providing targeted rehabilitation along with family support, we can ensure the seamless reintegration of ex-offenders into society. captainsoflives behindprisonwalls

To tackle the over-representation in crime and drug statistics of the Malay-Muslim community, the Development and Reintegration Programme for Malay-Muslim inmates was developed by the Singapore Prison Service in collaboration with the Association of Muslim Professionals (AMP). The programme provides interventions for Malay-Muslim inmates in the Drug Rehabilitation Centres and their families, for a period of up to 12 months after the inmates' release. Despite not having experience in aftercare work, AMP rose to the challenge by recruiting and training case workers to work closely with inmates and their families to address their reintegration needs.AMP spokesperson, Mdm Hameet Khanee J Hussain, a senior manager at AMP who heads the social services division, said: One of AMPs core focuses is to empower the underprivileged and help them to take charge of their lives. By offering a holistic intervention and addressing the concerns the inmate has while he is incarcerated, he can then focus on his rehabilitation and reintegration journey. The Malay-Muslim population in prison is disproportionally high and we must, as a community, come forward to lead and to support them in their reintegration and rehabilitation needsBeyondPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

During the recent Letter of Understanding (LOU) signing between Ngee Ann Polytechnic and the Singapore Prison Service, we sat down with Superintendent (SUPT) Edwin Goh for a quick chat about how this new offering by Prison School could change things for inmates and ex-offenders in a big way. The Diploma in Business Practice (International Supply Chain Management) is the new course in addition to the O, N, and A Levels currently available at the Prison School for inmates serving their sentence. Through this course, student inmates will gain relevant knowledge and skills in both international supply chain and business management to support these industries. "We do believe in education and life-long learning", SUPT Goh said. "This course enables the students to find better jobs upon their release and gives them a seamless transition to the community."CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls

PART 2/4: SPEAR Selection.The candidates moved on to the next segment, the standard obstacle course involving components like a low wall and Jacob's ladder. Before the start of each segment, SPEAR trainer Irwan Kurniawan demonstrated the correct way to complete the obstacle course so as to minimise injury..It was finally time for the candidates to tackle the standard obstacle course. During the start, everything went smoothly as the candidates were swift and ran from one obstacle to another. Towards the end, fatigue set in and sweat trickled down their faces while they pushed themselves to conquer the last few obstacles. Team work was also apparent when some of the candidates offered help to their fellow candidates when they needed it..Finally, the candidates could rest while they proceeded to the psychometric test. The test assesses candidates on their skills, personal aptitude and knowledge. The remaining four candidates looked seemingly less tense as they finally have time to catch their breath before going on to the next vigorous segment of the SPEAR Selection..BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

Did you know prison volunteers play a key role in helping to reduce re-offending? To recognise their efforts, 405 individual volunteers and Voluntary Welfare Organisations were given awards for supporting the rehabilitation of inmates and ex-offenders at the Singapore Prison Service Volunteers Awards Ceremony 2018. The event was graced by Guest-of-Honour, Senior Parliamentary Secretary for Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of Health ..The awards highlight the dedication of the 1,900 volunteers whose unwavering support have made significant contributions in the lives of inmates, ex-offenders and their families, and is a testament to the communitys continuous support. Together with the support of our community partners, we can inspire everyone towards a society without re-offending..BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) and Ngee Ann Polytechnic (NP) signed a Letter of Understanding for the Diploma in Business Practice (International Supply Chain Management) earlier today. For the first time ever, students at the Prison School will now be able to attend a diploma course which equips students with knowledge and skills in logistics, supply chain management and business management..Students who are enrolled in the diploma course in Prison School will be able to continue their remaining modules at Ngee Ann Polytechnic upon their release..As Captains of Lives, we recognise that education opportunities help raise employability, which in turn reduce the risk of re-offending. We will continue to expand the spectrum of academic courses available for inmates who are motivated to learn and change themselves for a better future..BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

Mr Amrin Amin, Senior Parliamentary Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of Health, launched the Development and Reintegration Programme earlier today at Wisma Geylang Serai. The programme is a collaboration between the Singapore Prison Service and the Association of Muslim Professionals and aims to provide additional support to Malay/Muslim inmates and their families in the Drug Rehabilitation Centres..First piloted in 2017, inmates under the initiative will undergo the Personal Development Programme, while their families will be enrolled in the Family & Youth Development Programme to promote self-reliance and enabling financial stability..As Captains of Lives, we recognise that family and a strong support network play an important part in supporting an inmates rehabilitation. The Development and Reintegration Programme will provide community support from the onset of their incarceration while guiding them through each stage of their rehabilitation and reintegration journey..BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

Hope Cafe doesn't just serve food, it also serves hope for a brighter future..Mrs Josephine Teo, Minister for Manpower and Second Minister for Home Affairs visited the Hope Cafe yesterday and saw a cooking class in action. Hope Cafe is a training kitchen by Singapore Prison Service and the Singapore Corporation Of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) to provide inmates with F&B skills before their release..While serving their sentence, inmates can undergo Workforce Skills Qualifications (WSQ) certified modules ranging from basic food preparation to quality control procedures..About 200 inmates are trained at Hope Cafe each year, who will then go on to be employed by F&B establishments. Vocational training programmes such as these are important to equip inmates with relevant job skills and prepare them for work upon their release. Together, we can inspire towards a nation without reoffending. CaptainsOfLives BehindPrisonWalls

Wishing all our Hindu friends a Happy Deepavali with your families and friends.Lets not forget our Captains of Lives who are keeping us safe during this festive season.captainsoflives

The Yellow Ribbon Conference (YRC) was held recently, with the aim of providing professionals in corrections a shared platform to share best practices and discuss upstream prevention, rehabilitation, and reintegration of inmates and ex-offenders. Themed Creating Ripples of Change at Every Level, topics such as Youth Criminal Conduct and Substance Abuse Treatment, Families and Incarceration, and Offender Rehabilitation and Community Corrections will be discussed by a variety of industry professionals at the conference. These include psychologists and Correctional Rehabilitation Specialists (CRS) from the Singapore Prison Service, the Central Narcotics Bureau, Ministry of Social and Family Development, as well as aftercare professionals from Singapore Anti-Narcotics Association and Trybe. We spoke to Dr Gabriel Ong, Chairperson, YR Conference and Principal Psychologist with the Singapore Prison Service. Dr Ong shared that he would assess the risk of inmates and recommend suitable programmes to change their attitude. The inmates will then be able to weigh the pros and cons of their actions and this will increase their motivation to change.Dr Ong emphasized on the importance of employer and community support in the rehabilitation journey of ex-offenders. The ex-offenders need to practice the skills they acquired in prison in a natural environment, for instance, their workplace, Dr Gabriel Ong, Chairperson, YR Conference.When asked what he hoped to achieve from this conference, Dr Ong mentioned that he hopes to be inspired by the best practices of the world and share the Singapore Prison Services correctional policy with leaders all over the world.CaptainsofLives BeyondPrisonWalls

"The female inmates are always improving and they aspire to be a better version of themselves, this is the attitude that we should have in all aspects of our life, Charlotte Stephen.We sat down with Charlotte Stephen, Senior Assistant Director, Correctional Rehabilitation Specialist (Women), Psychological and Counselling Rehabilitation Division to find out more about her role and how it helps women inmates deal with issues.Women inmates face a whole new set of challenges as compared to male inmates. Other than being the sole caregiver of their families, they also tend to be more emotional than men. The counselling programmes provided by the Singapore Prison Service helps women inmates keep their emotions in place, identify negative thoughts and focus on positivity. CaptainsofLives BehindPrisonWalls

We sat down with Randeep Singh, who was recently promoted from the unified career scheme. He joined the Singapore Prison Service as he wanted to work closely with some of the most vulnerable people in our communities, build on their strengths and truly make a contribution to their lives.Randeep is grateful for the unified rank structure as it empowered him to take up more leadership roles and responsibilities. Throughout the different job postings in SPS, he has managed to discover his own strength and weaknesses. The leadership training played a crucial role in helping me to react and respond to challenging situations. What is more important is the ability to transfer and build these experience through practice rather than in theory. These courses provided adequate preparation for me to tackle any situation that may arise in the course of my work, Randeep Singh S/O Jagindar Singh, Housing Unit Officer.At Singapore Prison Service, we constantly encourage the development and growth of our Captains of Lives. We take pride in having a sense of mission to positively impact inmates and assist them through their journey of rehabilitation.

We spoke to Wong Tian Lee, who was recently promoted to RO1 in the unified rank structure. As a trainer at the Prison Staff Training School, she has impacted the lives of many officers and shared that the officers have also impacted her in one way or other.Benefiting from the unified rank structure, she is thankful for the opportunity to complete the training in Prison Staff Training School and to constantly challenge herself. The training that I underwent was not easy but it allowed me to see things from the ground and understand it from the officers' point of view. The wide perspectives of what leaderships are, gave me a better idea of how a leader should behave and what a best leader should be like", Wong Tian Lee, Housing Unit Officer.As a Captain of Lives for 19 years, she shared that the Singapore Prison Service has progressed to an institution that harnesses technology. With the use of technology in prison institutions, prison officers have been freed to do more higher order work, increasing the interaction between them and the inmates. Photo Credit: Muhammad Darwisy Harooncaptainsoflives

Selamat Hari Raya Haji!Wishing all our Muslim friends a blessed Eid with your friends and family. During this celebration, let us keep in mind our Captains of Lives and all those who help keep Singapore safe and secure every day.CaptainsofLives

President Halimah Yacob visited the Changi Prison Complex this morning and warmly engaged with women inmates from Institution A4. As the only womens prison, Institution A4 offers a wide range of rehabilitation programmes catered to address the unique risks and needs of women inmates.President Halimah Yacob was given a tour of the various vocational training facilities such as the hairdressing workshop and bakery to see how we work closely with SCORE to enhance the employability of inmates. She also visited a classroom where a counselling session was taking place to see how SPSs team of Psychologists and Correctional Rehabilitation Specialists work closely with prison officers to conduct evidence-based psychological and counselling programmes for these inmates. Thank you Madam President for taking time to visit us today and for inspiring our inmates to take charge of their own reintegration journeys. BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

Technology empowers inmates to take charge and be responsible for their own rehabilitation an important mindset change needed for them to successfully reintegrate into society when they leave prison. For example, they can purchase canteen items from a vending machine automatically, and also engage in self-learning on tablets. The test-bedding of technology in A4 has also allowed our prison officers to be more than just guards. They can be Captains of Lives mentors, coaches and role models to inmates, guiding them to become contributing members of society when they leave prison. says SUPT 1A Angeline Chua of Institution A4, which houses over 1,000 female inmates. As the Second Superintendent, SUPT Angeline oversees the smooth running of operations at Institution A4.Institution A4 has demonstrated how technology can transform the way our prisons are run. A key benefit of introducing these technologies would be to improve the work of a prison officer many routine and manual processes would be eradicated, enabling the officers to focus on purposeful interactions to better manage the inmates and facilitate their rehabilitation.SUPT Angeline continues to feel inspired as a Captain of Lives and she continues to be driven by the motivation of making an impact on the lives of inmates and their families. BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

In the wee hours of the morning, ten candidates assembled at the Singapore Prisons Emergency Action Response (SPEAR) Base, ready to test their mental and physical breaking points. They know that not all of them will make it through the day. But there is a strong desire to survive the selection. For the 10 candidates from Cluster A, B, and C, it means a place in the grueling 20-week course and hopefully, a coveted spot in the elite team. Read the full story on our Facebook page.BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

In order to help the families of those who are incarcerated the Singapore Prison Service partnered with The Salvation Army to provide support to the children and families of inmates, and to strengthen the bonds between them. Some of the common issues faced by these families are financial difficulties, as the breadwinner of the family has been incarcerated, the family will have lesser spending power. The younger kids may not fully understand the reason why they no longer see their parents at home and this may affect their performance in school, TSA Spokesperson Reynard Lye, Centre Manager, The Salvation Army.BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

ASP2 Zawani understands that the role of a prison officer is a multi-faceted one and she has worked with inmates from all walks of life, gently guiding them towards their successful rehabilitation and reintegration into society. BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

During the recent National Youth Achievement Award (NYAA), we sat down with NYAA Bronze Recipient Award, David.Under the NYAA programme, David has learnt to play the guitar and performed at the NYAA opening ceremony last year. As an audience watching the performance on stage, I nearly teared. It reminded me of what I went through and I know that ten years of practice is [encapsulated] into one minute on stage", David said.BehindPrisonWalls

As an officer with the Singapore Prison Service (SPS), Housing Unit Officer Koh Lee Fang engages inmates and supports them on their rehabilitation journey on a daily basis, overseeing their progress and participation in various rehabilitation programmes and counselling. Koh shares that her own mother was her pillar of strength and taught her the need to remain honest and humble at all times, and to treat everyone with respect. That was what propelled her to continue impacting change as a Captains of Lives.The Singapore Prison Service thanks Koh Lee Fang for her contributions to the safety and security of Singapore and we would like to wish all mothers a Happy Mothers Day!BehindPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

For the first time ever, participants from 10 countries gathered in Singapore to pit their skills against one another in the Asian Prison Lockdown Challenge (APLC). Organised by the Singapore Prison Service, the competition allows prison officers from around the region to display their tactical skills.In The Specialist segment, the team was put through a series of tough obstacles, testing their ability to act swiftly under physically and mentally stressful conditions. Stay tuned to our page as we bring you more highlights of the event!APLC2018 BeyondPrisonWalls CaptainsOfLives

At the annual Singapore Prison Service (SPS) - SCORE (Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises) Corporate Advance, SPS renewed its commitment to work closely with its network of community partners and optimise offenders employability potential. Attended by over 500 staff from SPS and SCORE, the event was graced by Guest of Honour, Mrs Josephine Teo, Minister, Prime Ministers Office, Second Minister for Home Affairs and Second Minister for Manpower. In line with our Corporate Advances theme of Preventing Re-offending, Enhancing Employability Potential, SPS will collaborate with the community to enhance rehabilitation and reintegration outcomes. BeyondPrisonWalls

"The reformative training regime equips young offenders with pro-social skills which better prepares them for a life of change to be a contributing member of society. We try to build discipline in formal and informal ways, by sending them for foot drills and ensuring that they attend programmes and get along with different people, DSP Clifford Lin, Officer-in-Charge of Housing Unit, Reformative Training Centre, Tanah Merah Prison.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

About 115 inmates aged 25 and below from Tanah Merah Prison (TMP) received the National Youth Achievement Awards (NYAA) today. Guest of Honour, Parliamentary Secretary (Home Affairs & Health) Amrin Amin, congratulated award winners and commended their efforts in developing qualities of self-reliance, perseverance and a sense of responsibility to themselves and the community.Over 1,600 inmates have participated in the NYAA programme since its implementation in 2000. Through embarking on the different components of this programme, participants were able to gain greater awareness of their roles in society.Kudos to our NYAA award recipients this year who have done us proud! BehindPrisonWalls
