Our operations are 24/7, and the job is challenging. However, this has not stopped our female officers from taking up the challenge. This InternationalWomensDay, we celebrate our fearless female officers who break traditional gender stereotypes to make a difference in the lives of inmates. Supt1 Ivy Soh, has been with the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) for 12 years, overseeing the internal and external operations in prison to ensure the safe and secure custody of inmates. As the Assistant Director of the Operations Management Branch, her role allows her to work with different departments, ensuring that key processes run smoothly and that SPSs institutions are operationally ready and prepared to respond to contingencies. These are big shoes that I have to fill because operations go round-the-clock. We are the fire-fighting department of prison as we are the first point of contact should sensitive issues arise, she added.BehindPrisonWalls
From all of us here at the Singapore Prison Service, Happy Chinese New Year everyone! May the Year of the Dog bring peace, health and prosperity to all!

Parliamentary Secretary for Home Affairs and Health, Mr Amrin Amin and Commissioner of Prisons, Mr Desmond Chin, hosted Minister for Culture, Community and Youth (MCCY), Ms Grace Fu, Parliamentary Secretary for MCCY, Mr Baey Yam Keng and other National Youth Council (NYC) members at the Community Rehabilitation Centre (CRC) yesterday as part of a learning journey.The CRC, which is managed by a non-profit organisation Trybe, provides a transformational environment for young 1st time drug offenders to take charge of their own rehabilitation and reintegration goals. Our guests learnt about the structured residential programme which allows the youth to continue with their education and employment in the day, ensuring minimal disruption to their lives. They also met with two residents who shared their stories of how they were empowered to turn their lives around.As Captains of Lives, we are committed to providing offenders with the support for them to take charge of their own rehabilitation and reintegration journey. While these offenders are capable of change and can contribute to society, we believe that family and community support is critical too for their rehabilitation. BeyondPrisonWalls

Early this year, four of our Captains of Lives took part in the Mizuno Ekiden 21.1 km corporate category. The team came first with a timing of 1 hour and 24 minutes.. The team consisted of Cleeve Mu, Ramesh Palaniandy, Yew Meng Tan and Zainul Arrifin who managed to retain their title for the second year running.. Compared to last year, the competition this year was much tougher and we were not in the top positions in the first half of the race. Thankfully, we managed to close the gap and eventually emerged as this year's champions and defend our title," said Ramesh.. We would like to congratulate our Captains of Lives for bringing their excellent teamwork and work ethic onto the running field and for doing us proud. . Onwards COLs! . ourCOLture BeyondPrisonWalls

The Singapore Prison Emergency Action Response (SPEAR) Force celebrated their 40th Anniversary today, where family members of SPEAR officers were allowed a rare glimpse into their work.. Mr Desmond Chin, the Commissioner of Prisons noted that staying relevant and operationally-ready was essential, and SPEAR must be prepared and ready when called upon.. Living by the motto of Swift, Accurate, Powerful and United, our SPEAR officers continue to uphold the culture of operational excellence so as to ensure the safe and secure custody of inmates.. ourCOLture BehindPrisonWalls

Staff Sergeant (SSGT) Mohamad Nor Rohdiansteien, a Command Control Centre officer at the Lloyd Leas Community Supervision Centre, has worked with inmates from all walks of life, gently guiding them towards their successful rehabilitation and reintegration into society. He was awarded the Excellent Service Award (EXSA) Silver, Gold and Star award and has received numerous Thank You cards from inmates whom he impacted deeply over the 11 years he has been with the Singapore Prison Service..He shared that one of his most memorable moments was when he recently came across an ex-offender who was previously under his charge. The ex-offender thanked him for his advice to think of his family whenever he felt he was about to re-offend. He added that this had driven the ex-offender to change for the better and that his family would never have to go through the ordeal of waiting for him to be released from prison again..As Prison Officers, the way that you communicate with your supervisees is important as they will hold on to your words, said SSGT Mohamad. It may be a simple word of encouragement, but you never know how much of an impact it will have on them..BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls OurCOLture
Wishing all our Hindu friends a Happy Deepavali with their families and friends. Lets not forget our Captains of Lives who are keeping us safe during this festive season.ourCOLture

The unassuming Staff Sergeant Lau Min Shen has a knack for successfully engaging inmates who are known to be hard to reach. Thus far, she has had two memorable experiences of interacting with inmates..First was when a female inmate became disenchanted with life and kept to herself all the time as her family did not contact her. Min Shen took the time to sit down with the inmate and understand her issues before she opened up. After many sessions with the inmate, she slowly changed her outlook on life, worked hard and regained her families acceptance..The second was when Min Shen was in charge of a male inmate who would push away her attempts to engage. Despite him having a tough outer shell, Min Shen sat through many sessions with him and finally gained his trust. The inmate shared his feelings and how he was worried about his mothers ailing health. In the end, a case was put up and social workers visited and assisted his mother..Captains of Lives like Min Shen not only positively impact the lives of inmates and their successful reintegration but also that of their families..BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls OurCOLture

Growing up in a difficult environment gave Mr William Sheng the compassion and empathy to reach out and help others like him..Although he just started volunteering this year, Mr William has held strongly onto his guiding principles that positive change can only come from within. Other than personal determination, Mr William credits his change to support from prison officers and volunteers whom he now considers his mentors..Having been out of the prison system for 12 years, Mr William gives back and seeks to create impact by giving inspirational talks to inmates under a volunteering programme..When I was in prison, I made peace with myself to accept peoples reactions to ex-offenders. I cannot change how they react but I can change how I react. Prison was a good training ground for me to manage myself he shared..Accepting his calling, Mr William feels that his life has led him to pass down what he has learnt and experienced so that youths can learn from him. He added, With my faith, I have come to the realisation that I should make an effort to reach out to the younger ones [inmates] who can still be positively influenced. BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls

As a Befriender, Mr Zuraimi Hussain is trained to give inmates support and guidance before and after their release.For his efforts, Mr Zuraimi was presented with a Five Year Long Service Award at the recent Singapore Prison Service Volunteers Awards Ceremony 2017.As a Befriender, his motivation is to allow participating inmates to have positive peer, social and religious support from the community so as to reduce re-offending. It is about being there for them and walking with them, he shared.Mr Zuraimi shared that such programmes are useful in allowing the community to further support and advocate rehabilitative initiatives for inmates and ex-offenders. What I found out during the journey was that the inmates are touched by the mentorship shown during in-care, encouraging more volunteers to help de-stigmatise ex-offenders while creating a ripple of acceptance throughout the community.BeyondPrisonWalls BehindPrisonWalls

Deputy Superintendent of Prisons (DSP) Mohamed Azhar Bin Zailan, co-chairperson of the Singapore Prison Service Volunteers Awards Ceremony 2017, is also an Officer-in-Charge of a housing unit in Admiralty West Prison and works closely with volunteers who provide pro-social and religious support inmates.DSP Azhar shares that volunteers are integral in helping inmates gain confidence and move forward with their lives. These volunteers also help many ex-offenders ease back into society through emotional and social support.When asked for his most memorable experience in his 10 years of service, DSP Azhar recounts how he met a male inmate who had been in prison for quite a while. The inmate shared that, Im not getting any younger and Ive learnt a lot in prison. When I am released, I hope to find a decent job as I am not well educated. I have a good set of hands for labour. Fast forwarding a few years later, DSP Azhar bumped into the same inmate again, this time driving a delivery truck for a fast food restaurant. As they caught up, DSP Azhar could not help but feel proud of how the ex-offender had turned his life around.As Captains of Lives, we take the lead in providing guidance to those under our charge and work with the community to successfully rehabilitate inmates so they can become contributing members of society.BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls ourCOLture

A total of 478 awards were presented to volunteers, Befrienders and Voluntary Welfare Organisations last week. The annual Singapore Prison Service (SPS) Volunteers Awards Ceremony was graced by Guest-of-Honour, Parliamentary Secretary for Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of Health Amrin Amin.This year, the Singapore Prison Service introduced the Gold Awards a new award category that recognises individuals who have volunteered with SPS for at least 15 years. The award highlights the dedication of volunteers whose unwavering support has made a positive change in the lives of inmates, ex-offenders and their families, and is a testament to the communitys continuous support.We would like to thank these volunteers for playing an important role in our cause and their relentless efforts to make this possible.BeyondPrisonWalls

Superintendent of Prisons (SUPT) Chan Ching Ching has been running for second chances ever since the first run in 2009. Being a part of the run for so many years, SUPT Chan shared fond memories of the first run. She shares that running side by side with ex-offenders sends the message that they are not alone. As vice-chairperson she shared her thoughts on the new category this year - Run for Second Chances Movement which consists of teams of four, symbolising how it takes many helping hands to support each ex-offenders rehabilitative journey. She also shared how the category was also opened to public registration so as to increase opportunities for the community to come together for the run and show their support for ex-offenders. Second chances can come from anyone and we as Captains of Lives should be the first to lead by example.ourCOLtureBehindPrisonWallsBeyondPrisonWalls

Missing time spent with family and friends was what Ahmad* told Parliamentary Secretary for Home Affairs and Health Mr Amrin Amin, when asked what he missed most about Hari Raya..Mr Amrin Amin, Mr Abdul Matin, Chairman of Darul Ghufran Mosque and Mr Anuar Yusop, Executive Director of the Association of Muslim Professionals, took some time out of their busy schedules to visit inmates from the Drug Rehabilitation Centre. They were there to spread some Hari Raya cheer and goodies, as well as remind the inmates that they were not alone in their reintegration journey..Encouragement and acceptance from the community and support groups are key to encouraging inmates to take part in programmes like religious counselling to assist them in their rehabilitation journey and reduce their likelihood of re-offending..BehindPrisonWalls

CW1 Muhammad Faisal Haron received the PS21 Star Service Award last month where he was recognised for the extraordinary service delivery rendered to his supervisees as a Reintegration Officer. Mr Faisal had spent additional effort to help his supervisee settle down and cope with the new environment on his first day at the hospice. He also enquired more about the supervisees day care activities from the hospice supervisor and left his contact with the hospice to facilitate himself as the point-of-contact out of his own accord. He was commended for taking the initiative to show genuine care and concern for his supervisees well-being.Kudos to CW1 Faisal for exemplifying how we, as Captains of Lives, go above and beyond the call of duty! ourCOLture
Selamat Hari Raya Aidilfitri!Wishing all our Muslim friends a blessed Raya with your family and friends. Not forgetting our Captains of Lives who are keeping us safe this holiday as well.ourCOLture
The month of Ramadan is for familial ties, self-reflection and forgiveness.Follow the link in our bio to read Daniel and Kellys Hari Raya story.BehindPrisonWalls

Earlier this month, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) outlined its strategic roadmap for 2017, focusing on Transformation through technology, data-driven operations coupled with community corrections, at the annual SPS-SCORE (Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises) Corporate Advance.To build a future-ready correctional service, SPS will be embarking on the concept of Prisons Without Guards - leveraging on technology to enhance operational effectiveness, prison officers will be freed up from guarding duties to perform higher order jobs. By equipping our officers with the technological edge, this would allow our officers to be freed up from guarding duties so that they can engage in higher order work, such as information analysis and rehabilitative interactions with inmates, said Director of Transformation and Technology, SAC Koh Tong Hai.In time, as technology plays an increasingly bigger role in SPS, the role of a prison officer will also evolve. With more quality and purposeful interactions with inmates, prison officers will be able to better rehabilitate them and in turn uphold a safe and secure prison system.BehindPrisonWalls PrisonWithoutGuards EvCOLution

About 145 inmates aged 25 and below from Tanah Merah Prison (TMP) and Changi Womens Prison (CWP) received the National Youth Achievement Awards (NYAA) yesterday the highest number of inmate participants since the introduction of the programme. Guest of honour, Parliamentary Secretary for Home Affairs Amrin Amin, congratulated award winners at the event yesterday, adding: No matter what your personal circumstances may be, with positive goals, determination and the right attitude, you can accomplish many things in life. More than 1,600 inmates have participated in the NYAA programme since the Singapore Prison Service has implemented it in 2000. The programme aims to encourage young inmates to develop personal qualities of self-reliance, perseverance and a sense of responsibility not only to themselves but also to the community. Through embarking on the different components that were held within CWP and TMP, participants are able to gain greater awareness of their roles in society and learn how their skills, talent and knowledge can contribute towards the community. Kudos to our NYAA award recipients this year who have done us proud! BehindPrisonWalls

Did you know?The late Mr Othman Wok, then-Minister for Culture and Social Affairs, graced the opening of the Queenstown Remand Prison on 23rd September 1966. In his opening address, Mr Othman noted that the aim of incarceration was no longer solely for punishment, but also for rehabilitation so as to ensure ex-offenders could successfully reintegrate into society. He called for the public to open their hearts and to create a community that would be accepting of ex-offenders. Reaffirming the beliefs of our founding fathers, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) today is still committed to ensuring that inmates receive targeted rehabilitation programmes while working closely with our community partners to achieve a society without re-offending.Images produced courtesy of National Archives of Singapore. EvCOLution RememberingOthmanWok

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) today outlined its strategic roadmap for 2017, focusing on Transformation through technology, data-driven operatio ns coupled with community corrections at the annual SPS-SCORE (Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises) Corporate Advance. The workplan was graced by Guest-of-Honour, Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law, K Shanmugam. With the theme Deepening Collaborations, Realising Transformation, SPS will continue expanding its role as a correctional agency which ensures the safe and secure custody of inmates and the rehabilitation and reintegration of ex-offenders. To build a future-ready correctional service, SPS embarked on the concept of Prisons Without Guards, where it will leverage technology to enhance operational effectiveness and automate work processes. Community partnership also remains essential in supporting rehabilitation and reintegration. SPS is working with the Association of Muslim Professionals (AMP) which will be piloting the first integrated throughcare programme for Muslim drug abusers this year. Inmates will be provided with Personal Development Programmes while they are in prison and followed through by AMPs case workers. Families of inmates can also enrol in AMPs Family and Youth Development Programme which aims to help them become financially stable and economically dependent. SPS and SCORE will continue to engage and work closely with our community partners and volunteers to support the inmates, ex-offenders and their families to face the challenges of the future.

As Head of Operations at Admiralty West Prison, Superintendent of Prisons 1 (SUPT 1) Kalaivanan s/o Visvalingam looks after the daily operational needs of the prison and heads a 70-strong team. Beyond his day-to-day responsibilities, SUPT 1 Kalaivanan is also an innovation champion and is regarded as The WITS Guru amongst his colleagues. He has won many awards for his creative inventions, such as the Quick Response Pack utility bag in 2003, which was the Singapore Prison Services first-ever patented product. Most recently, he was a PS21 ExCEL Innovation Champion (Silver) winner in 2016 for his creation of the Foreign Object Extractor (FOE) and defroster, which helps to remove impurities from rice and defrost meat while saving water.The 46-year-old recalls: My dad was my inspiration. Nothing went to waste when he built those items. Even now, I keep a lot of scrap items at home and Im glad my wife doesnt complain! After graduating from university with a finance degree and working briefly as a relief teacher, SUPT 1 Kalaivanan joined the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) in 1997 as a prison officer, bringing the spirit of innovation and quick thinking with him.SUPT 1 Kalaivanan attributes all this to his boss, who gave his full support to their initiative. My boss gave me the autonomy to lead my innovation team, and regularly joined our meetings to lend his support.Looking back on his 20-year career, SUPT 1 Kalaivanan is thankful for the role models that supported innovation and helped to create a positive workplace as SPS underwent its own transformation. BehindPrisonWalls OurCOLture

As a Trainer with the Singapore Prisons Emergency Action Response (SPEAR) Force, Chief Warder (CW) Irwan Kurniawan Bin Rahmat is passionate about ensuring the safe and secure custody of inmates, as well as looking into their rehabilitative needs. He understands the importance of being a role model for the inmates as it would create a positive change in their behaviour.He shared that there was a time when he was approached by an inmate who showed an interest in body building and fitness. CW Irwan Kurniawan shared his knowledge with the inmate and encouraged him to pursue fitness as an interest. A few years later, CW Irwan was approached by a man dressed in sports attire while shopping. He initially thought that the man was trying to sell him a gym package, only to realize that it was the inmate that he had spoken to years ago. As they chatted, the inmate thanked CW Irwan for giving him direction in life, mentioning that he had inspired him not just by words, but also being a role model that he could follow in life. At this juncture, I realized that as Captains of Lives (COL), our words can really make a long lasting impact on an inmates life, he shared. As long as we take pride in our work and always strive to maintain our professionalism, we will unknowingly end up becoming someones role model. BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls OurCOLture

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) was awarded the Watermark Award which recognises individuals and organisations for their contributions to the conservation of Singapore's water resources. Deputy commissioner of SPS, Ms Shie Yong Lee, shared that the award was an affirmation of the efforts of Captains of Lives, inmates and partners. Winning this award doesnt mean that the journey ends here. We will continue to support our water conservation and other environmental sustainability efforts." BehindPrisonWalls OurCOLture
