Mr Mohd Ismail Bin Abu Bakars aim of making a change in peoples lives was what motivated him to be a volunteer in the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) Befriender Programme 5 years ago. Like Mr Ismail, all volunteers have to undergo Prison Volunteers Training conducted by the Singapore After-Care Association (SACA) to equip them with the necessary skills to assist the inmates and ex-offenders in their rehabilitation.As a befriender, Mr Ismail has touched many lives including Mr Daniels, an ex-offender who is currently pursuing his Diploma in Marine Engineering at the Singapore Polytechnic.By befriending them, I can offer my ideas on how they can move forward after their release, said Mr Ismail. As Befrienders, we want these individuals to know that they are not alone in their rehabilitation. When they are determined to turn their lives around for the better and take responsibility and initiative for their reintegration, volunteers like us are important as we show we believe in them. Volunteers like Mr Ismail play a key role in the inmates lives, as they act as a pillar of support, by giving them sound advice and steering them towards the right direction.

Miss Lee Xuan Man was recently awarded the 10 year Long Service Award at the Prison Volunteers Appreciation Ceremony on 23 September, for contributing her time to counsel inmates as well as teach them the Chinese language at the Tanah Merah Prison School. Since young, Miss Lee had always wanted to be a police officer. However, she stopped schooling due to family issues. After working for 12 years, her hopes were renewed when she was offered an opportunity to pursue her studies again at the National Taiwan Normal University. I felt that this was a second chance given to me. When I was in Taiwan, I told myself that if I cant be a police officer, then Ill be a counsellor, she said.After completing her Bachelors Degree in Chinese language, Miss Lee returned to Singapore and was determined to achieve something in her life. Starting off as a religious counsellor, she eventually pursued a teaching career at various schools, subsequently volunteering her time at the Tanah Merah Prison School. As long as they are willing to do their work, Im willing to grade their assignment and go through their mistakes with them, says Miss Lee.Her motivation to stay as a tutor even after 10 years lies within the learning attitude of her students. Her students take their work seriously and will even ask her for assignments. This has spurred her to put in her utmost effort in order to help them. As someone who understands the meaning of second chances intimately, Ms Lee shares a strong bond of empathy with her students, who are able to wholeheartedly share their troubles with her.Volunteers play a vital role in creating an impact on the successful rehabilitation and reintegration of inmates and ex-offenders. They can create a more inclusive and safer society by providing pro-social support to inmates and ex-offenders.

Recently, Chief Warder (CW2) Nur Hannah Wang of the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) was awarded with the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) Learning Opportunities Programme (HALO) Sponsorship Award, providing her with the opportunity to pursue a full-time degree programme in the Bachelor of Arts (Hons) Criminology and Security. This was in view of her exceptional performance in her work, towards the safety and security and rehabilitation of inmates.Ms Wang shared with us that the award meant a lot to her; her performance in academics and co-curricular activities during her polytechnic days did not allow her to secure a full-time degree course. And as a wife and working mother of three, the financial responsibilities also prevented her from pursuing a part-time degree. Despite the challenges faced in both her personal and professional life, Ms Wang displayed commendable perseverance and vigilance in her work, allowed her to receive this sponsorship.With this award, Ms Wang would now be able to fulfil her wish to further pursue her studies, which will empower her with skills and knowledge that would prove invaluable in her work. Upon graduation, Ms Wang would also be emplaced on the Senior Officer (SO) scheme, where she would take upon greater responsibilities and produce higher standards in SPS.OnwardCOL

This morning, we mourn the passing of former President S.R Nathan, a man who inspired us all. As our longest serving president, he continuously and tirelessly played a monumental role in shaping Singapore to become a nation we can all be proud to be a part of.We at the Captains of Lives will miss Mr Nathan dearly, and we will seek to uphold and emulate the values he held duty before self, and caring for one another. Thank you Sir, for your unrelenting service to our country.

While we celebrate 51 years of vigilance and independence this National Day, let us look towards the future in ensuring the continuous safety and security of our homeland.Happy National Day Singapore!OnwardCOL igsg hometeamns ndp2016

At the Singapore Prison Service, emphasis is placed on the rehabilitation and reintegration of offenders, so as to reduce their chances of re-offending in the community. That is where Community Rehabilitation Specialists like Ms Katherine Peh come in. She recently shared with us her experiences working with offenders and at-risk youths. Prior to joining SPS, I often wondered if there were opportunities for prison staff to connect with the offenders in therapeutic ways, with a focus to motivate and facilitate their change.That opportunity came when I joined the Singapore Prison Service (SPS), with officers journeying with offenders in the aftercare phase. Working in the Community Rehabilitation Centre (CRC), I fostered therapeutic relationships with youths through motivational sharings, and by showing genuine concern for their well-being I was able to build rapport with the youths, facilitating change. Connecting with offenders in a therapeutic way has also significantly transformed the way I work. I continued to apply this useful way of connecting with the offenders. For example, when a supervisee attends an aftercare counselling session and has concerns about his unstable accommodation, it is important to listen and attend to his accommodation needs, before working with him on potential ways to resolve the issue. Once the connection is made, I am then able to assess and address his needs to help him not re-offend again. BehindTheBadge

At the Singapore Prison Service, officers regularly share their own personal anecdotes and stories with one another. This helps develop a deeper understanding of the myriad of roles in the organisation as well as develop stronger camaraderie within the SPS family, towards keeping Singapore safe and secure. We sat down with ASP Samuel Sia from the Strategic Planning Division as he shared his experiences with us. As a staff officer at the Singapore Prison Service (SPS), my story is not about transforming the lives of inmates, but rather to assist in the transformation of SPS to be ready for the future in the area of capability development. Maintaining a collaborative relationship with my colleagues in various departments enables us to develop meaningful solutions and smooth implementation of the development projects. This has helped us to see through the completion of some major projects, which give me great satisfaction as I know that I have contributed positively to the organisation. The Resource Planning Branch is a new unit within SPS and I am grateful for the guidance from other divisions. I hope I can continue to play my part in SPSs transformation as we progress to an organisation that harnesses technology to operate a world-class correctional agency. BehindTheBadge

At the recent Asian Prisons Lockdown Challenge (APLC) 2016, we met up with Assistant Superintendent of Prisons (ASP2) Muhammad Raizaluddin Bin Abdul Razak from Cluster C. A first-time participant this year, he shared with us his experiences and challenges faced in the event. In order to qualify as a contestant, ASP Raizaluddin shared that one has to first register their interest before undergoing a stringent selection round. Following that, they would have to engage in weekly trainings to prepare for the events. Some of the challenges ASP Raizaluddin faced while training were the long training hours, incorporating physical and tactical trainings as well as being able to find a common time where each participant could train together as a team. With conflicting schedules in their shifts, training still went on even in the middle of the day when the sun is hottest. Despite the obstacles faced, ASP Raizaluddin learnt a lot from his experience. He shared that one of his key takeaways APLC is to Always be prepared, and to expect the unexpected; scenarios can change in various ways but the most important thing is to be ready when it happens. Congratulations to ASP Raizaluddin and his team for their efforts in APLC 2016, and for their constant vigilance towards keeping Singapore safe and secure!OnwardCOL

This June, 6,693 officers from various Home Team agencies will be promoted. Among these officers is our very own Chief-of-Staff/Singapore Prison Service (COS/SPS) Transformational Projects, Shie Yong Lee who will be promoted to Senior Assistant Commissioner (SAC). As COS/SPS, Shies duties include overseeing strategic research, planning efforts and the development of staff units. Some of the Home Team's future training initiatives would involve extending prison officers' work to go beyond the prison walls and into the community, which will allow officers to further develop their capabilities and skills towards facilitating the successful rehabilitation and reintegration of offenders back into society.COS/SPS Shie was also part of the team who brainstormed the vision for SPS, which came to be "Captains of Lives", which focuses on ensuring the safe and secure custody of inmates, as well as rehabilitating them for a safer Singapore.

The Singapore Prisons Emergency Action Response (SPEAR) Force is the highly trained, elite tactical force of SPS. Only officers who have successfully completed the arduous selection process and met the requirements during the 5-month long SPEAR Tactical Course (STC) will be able to don the prestigious SPEAR insignia, a winged emblem worn exclusively by SPEAR officers.The initial phase assesses the mental resilience of potential SPEAR recruits through a psychometric test.This is to assess their aptitude, reasoning skills and suitability for the position they have applied for. Applicants who are found not suitable would then be removed from the selection pool.Following that, officers would be put through a Beep Test to gauge their cardiovascular fitness before they can go through the Individual & Team Physical Endurance Assessment (ITPEA), which ensures that they are not just able to work well individually, but collectively as a team.Last week, we had the privilege of meeting potential SPEAR recruits, and were indeed in awe of the resilience and determination that they had portrayed during the entire selection process.Stay tuned to this space as we bring you more interesting highlights of our up-and-coming SPEAR officers! BehindTheBadgeJournalofaSPEARecruit
Today, we celebrate the men and women who have worked hard to keep Singapore a safe place to work and play in. From all of us at Singapore Prison Service, Happy Labour Day! COLGreetings

During the Home Team Festival late last year, we caught up with Deputy Superintendent of Prisons (DSP) Tanny Ng, whose team received the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) Operational Excellence Award.The award recognises teams for their exceptional accomplishments and operational capabilities in significant projects, and in this case, the integration of two units to form the Community Corrections Command (COMC). COMC was formed on 1 August 2014, drawing on the expertise of prison officers from the Lloyd Leas Community Supervision Centre as well as specialists from the Correctional Rehabilitation Services Branch. This allows the aspects of post-release supervision and community rehabilitation to complement each other, further strengthening Singapore Prison Services goal towards reducing recidivism and to help inmates successfully reintegrate into society.Under the guidance of DSP Ng, the team was able to demonstrate a high level of professionalism and commitment towards the formation of the new Command, as well as bring an innovative edge into the ranks of SPS.OnwardCOL

As a correctional agency, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) works closely with various community partners to ensure the smooth delivery of community-based and aftercare programmes for inmates.One such example is the case management service offered by the Singapore Anti-Narcotics Association (SANA). Two months prior to their release, Mr Bala Subramaniam a case manager from SANA visits inmates under his charge so as to create rapport and prepare them for their reintegration journeys ahead. Working closely with Reintegration Officers from SPS, case managers also provide inmates and their families with six-months of aftercare counselling, followed by an additional six months of follow-up counselling, if necessary.Mr Bala adds that the most important factor in the reintegration journey is the motivation of the ex-offender to change for the better as well as the presence of strong family support: When they have the correct attitude, people like SANA will come into play. We dont judge, we listen and we help. So (we help them create) a better sense of awareness of what they can do, how they cope with everyday stressesAs such, it is necessary that SPS together with community partners and volunteers, strives to provide community support for newly-released inmates and ex-offenders. OnwardCOL

Prison officers maintain security and discipline. Heres a look at their training regime: Prison officers are in charge of maintaining a high level of security and discipline across the prison institutions. Hence, to ensure that they are agile during their course of work, officers undergo a rigorous training regime at the Prison Staff Training School.Trainings consist of several components, including academic, physical fitness, tactical skills, operational readiness and leadership. Officers will be put through various scenarios, which depict common disturbances and issues in mock-up environments to help prepare them to handle possible challenges they may face during their operational duties.The training is conducted primarily through classroom lectures, facilitated discussions, experiential learnings and on-the-job trainings. The training provided takes reference from the correctional landscape that we are in today, which enforces the safe custody of offenders and their rehabilitation.BehindTheBadge

Find out more about the correctional work that SPS does to reduce re-offending here:We had the opportunity to meet with Mr. Rockey Francisco Jr, Director of the Community Corrections Command in Singapore Prison Service (SPS). He shared how SPS has successfully put in place Community-Based Programmes (CBP) to ensure seamless support from inmates incarceration, release and eventual reintegration. Upon closely monitoring their personal conduct, attitudes towards reintegration and conducting a thorough risks-and-needs assessment, inmates who are at the tail-end of their sentences may be placed under the home detention, halfway house or work release schemes; all of which exemplify the importance for inmates to be productive members of society.Under each scheme, the inmates would have to adhere to strict regulations, such as electronic tagging, curfew hours as well as regularly reporting to their Reintegration Officers on their progress.Mr Rockey described the CBP as a concerted effort which encourages inmates to remain crime-free: The CBP enables SPS officers to work very closely with correctional specialists, aftercare agencies, as well as families of inmates, in unison, to provide inmates with the support that they need to rehabilitate. OnwardCOL

Apart from ensuring the safe and secure custody of our inmates, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) is also a correctional agency that delivers structured aftercare programmes to cater to different risks and needs for effective rehabilitation.Community Based Programmes help facilitate low-risk inmates in their reintegration back into the community. Through harnessing such structured aftercare programmes, the Singapore Prisons Service (SPS) strives to reduce re-offending by supporting the inmates reintegration back into community.

Employment remains a key component in the rehabilitation and reintegration journey of an ex-offender. In 2015, the Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) continued active engagement of employers across the F&B, hospitality, logistics and manufacturing sectors. Compared to 2014, there was a 7.03 per cent increase in the number of employers registered with SCORE and a 9.49 per cent increase in inmates securing employment prior to their release. The increase in the number of employers offering jobs to ex-offenders to help secure their livelihoods are a positive indication of the communitys willingness to support ex-offenders turn over a new leaf.

The Singapore Prison Service released key statistical data which reaffirmed continued efforts in rehabilitation and a stronger emphasis on community corrections. The overall recidivism rates, which tracks the re-offending rates of inmates who are released and subsequently detained or imprisoned again for a new offence within two years, fluctuate on a yearly basis and depends on various factors. The latest recidivism rates shows that recidivism from the 2009 to 2013 release cohort remains low and stable. This low and stable recidivism rate not only confirms the collaborative efforts between SPS, its community partners and volunteers in the rehabilitation and reintegration of offenders, but also acts as an encouragement to all who are involved in giving second chances to ex-offenders and helping them in their rehabilitation journeys.

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) strives to protect Singapores peace and security through the safe custody, rehabilitation and aftercare of offenders. To ensure that officers remain competent in meeting these objectives, the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) offers sponsorship awards for officers to pursue their further studies. Last year, an officer who received the MHA- Liverpool Sponsorship Programme (Bachelor of Criminology and Security) awarded by the Singapore Institute of Technology was Chief Warder (CW) Ponnarasi D/O Gopal Chandra (pictured second from left). Having been in the service for 12 years, CW Ponnarasi wanted to deepen her knowledge and appreciation of the correctional landscape.Despite foreseeing that the next three years would be highly challenging, CW Ponnarasi was certain that the support from her family, colleagues and management of SPS would carry her through. For more information on the MHA Sponsorship Awards available, do visit:

2015 was indeed a significant year for many of our Singapore Prison Service (SPS) officers. One such example was Chief Warder (CW) Ling Geok Wah, who received the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) Distinguished Star Service Award in November 2015.As a Senior Registry Support Officer, CW Ling, together with her team, processes over a hundred tele-visits for inmates daily. Understanding the importance of the bi-monthly visits for both families and inmates, CW Ling often goes the extra mile to help visitors. One such example was when she helped an inmates wife who lives in Malaysia. The inmate's wife is not well-to-do and she travels to Singapore solely for the purpose of visiting her spouse who is incarcerated. It did not make sense for her to pay so much for flights; which was why I decided to lend a helping hand, said the officer who has been in the service for over 18 years.Photo credits: Home Team News (Singapore)For more stories on the Home Team Agency, do check out Home Team News (Singapore) Facebook page.COL50Things

As an organisation which promotes a culture of continuous learning and self-improvement, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) encourages its officers to develop themselves academically.An example of an officer who may attest to this is Chief Warder (CW) Hannah Wang. Through the support and affirmation from her superiors, colleagues and husband, she decided to enroll in a Bachelors Degree course in Criminology and Security at the Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT)Before taking up the course, CW Hannahs primary duties involved collaborating with key personnel on the planning, implementing and scheduling of inmates in-care and pre-release programmes.In taking up this course, she hopes to gain a deeper level of understanding of the different aspects of criminology, as well as to hone her critical thinking skills.Even though she acknowledges the challenges of juggling studies and family, she advises officers to manage their time wisely, keep a positive mind-set and adopt a never give up attitude.We would like to wish all SPS officers furthering their education the best of luck! Photo credits: Home Team News (Singapore)For more stories on the various Home Team agencies, do also check out the Home Team News (Singapore) Facebook page. COL50Things

At Singapore Prison Service (SPS), work requires a high level of efficiency and professionalism from officers, as well as the adaptability to cope with the dynamic challenges in the correctional landscape.An officer that exhibits these traits is Chief Warder (CW) Kelvin Ang Chuean Wee, who is currently enrolled in a Criminology and Security Degree programme with the University of Liverpool.Prior to taking up his further studies, CW Kelvin executed his duties as a trainer in the Singapore Prisons Emergency Action Response (SPEAR) Force, which involved training new and existing officers in the handling of firearms and escorting procedures; as well as equipping them with the skills to handle any possible stressful scenarios during their escorts.CW Kelvin is a strong advocate for continuous learning and staying relevant in society. As such, he is very thankful for the support shown by his superiors and division to further his education, and believes that the knowledge gained from his course will be instrumental in his line of work.We would like to take this opportunity to wish CW Kelvin and all other SPS officers who are currently furthering their education, all the best. Keep up the great work in making SPS what it is today, and more!COL50Things

Officers from the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) play vital roles, not just in ensuring the safe and secure custody of inmates, but also in rehabilitating them so as to steer them onto the right path in life.During the launch of the Yellow Ribbon Community Art Exhibition (YR CAE), which took place on the 10th of December, we had the opportunity to speak with Superintendent (SUPT) Doris Ng. As Chairperson of the Organising Committee of YR CAE 2015, SUPT Ng collaborated closely with community partners such as the Singapore Art Museum (SAM) to ensure the smooth running of the exhibition and working with the inmate artists in conceptualising the theme for the exhibition. SUPT Ng added that one of the greatest highlights for her was being able to see how art has helped transform the lives of the inmate artists in little ways. Art is indeed a great way for inmates to express themselves when words will not suffice. It also helps the inmates to learn more about themselves, look positively ahead and gain hope for the future. COL50Things

As part of the SG50 celebrations, we started the 'COL50Things' campaign, where we brought you very interesting facts about the Singapore Prison Service (SPS). Today, we give you a sneak peek into our very own Singapore Prisons Emergency Action Response (SPEAR) force; the elite, tactical response force of SPS and the less lethal weaponry used.To ensure that the SPEAR officers are competent to handle any possible prison contingency, they do not only go through a prolonged selection process, but also on-going trainings to ensure they are well-versed with SPS operations at all times. Additionally, they are trained in the use of several less lethal weapons, which aid them in the handling of prison contingencies.One example of the less lethal weapon used primarily by the SPEAR force is the FN 303 Less Lethal Launcher, a semiautomatic shoulder fired launcher, which uses compressed air to launch projectiles. The FN 303 is constructed from durable lightweight polymer with comfortable ergonomics and is equipped with both flip-up iron sights and C-more sight for fast target acquisition.Do remember to click on COL50Things to read more feature stories about the Singapore Prison Service.

Performance reviews are conducted regularly to ensure that Singapore Prison Service (SPS) officers remain competent in their daily work deliverables and to evaluate if they are ready to take on higher roles and responsibilities.Similarly, Deputy Superintendent (DSP) Ng Kailin has recently been promoted as Head Curriculum and Planning, which came as a pleasant surprise for her as she had just returned from her maternity leave. Having previously led a ground operation unit in managing offenders in a Drug Rehabilitation Centre (DRC), DSP Ngs work revolved around ensuring the smooth operations within the housing unit as well as maintaining a high level of security and discipline, while overseeing the rehabilitation and reintegration needs of the offenders under her care. By excelling in her given roles and responsibilities at work, and through the support of her management, DSP Ng was promoted and given the chance to better hone her leadership skills.Today, she leads an entire staff unit in the planning of training curriculum for prison officers to better equip them for the challenges that they might face at work.With all the good work that she has done, DSP Ng has not only proven to be successful at work, but at home as well, as a devoted wife and a mother of one with another one on the way.

To ensure that employees remain efficient in the work that they do in the correctional landscape, Singapore Prison Service (SPS) strongly encourages employees to develop themselves academically.One such example is Chief Warder (CW) Muhammad Nazir Bin Abdul Hamid, who is currently pursuing his Bachelors Degree in Social Science at the Singapore Management University (SMU). Before taking up his Degree programme, CW Nazirs primary duties include performing computer forensic investigation work, planning and organising provost-related events, as well as acting as a liaison officer for the other Home Team agencies on behalf of SPS. Fuelled by his passion towards his work, CW Nazir explained that his decision in taking up the Social Science programme was primarily because of his strong interest in bureaucratic efficiency and environmental sustainability.He added that he hopes to be able to translate his knowledge to SPS upon completing the programme and returning back to work.We would like to take this opportunity to wish CW Nazir and all the other SPS officers who are presently pursuing their further studies, the very best. Continue to do the good work that you do, and make SPS proud!Photo credit: PSD Singapore

During the Singapore Prison Service Volunteer Awards Ceremony 2015, we caught up with Five-Year Long Service Award recipient, Mr Tan Han Yao.Mr Tan has been volunteering at the Tanah Merah Prison School for the last five years, providing much-needed guidance in mathematics to inmates who are preparing for their GCE O Level examinations.When asked what motivates him to continue sacrificing his Friday evenings to tutoring inmates, the 34-year old replied that the inmates earnestness to develop themselves academically keeps him inspired as an educator.Mr Tan was one of the 155 individuals recognised at the ceremony, for having dedicated his time and resources to seeing inmates change for the better.Once again, Captain of Lives would like to thank all our volunteers for their dedication and support in the rehabilitation journey of offenders To many more years and lives turned around!

At the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run 2015, several Singapore Prison Service officers were deployed to ensure the security of the participants, as well as the smooth operation of the entire event.During the event, we spoke to Assistant Superintendent (ASP) Keonz Quek Yong Qiang (first row in picture), who was tasked as the Programme In-charge, and together with his team ensured that the entire stage performance ran smoothly.Additionally, with proper planning from as early as March 2015, ASP Keonz managed to secure 46 talented performers from The Philharmonic Winds, who together with 2 inmate performers gave the audience a great performance.When asked why he had agreed to be involved in the YRP Run 2015, ASP Keonz replied that he strongly believes in giving ex-offenders a second chance in life. He added that only through the various support rendered by the community will ex-offenders be able to successfully reintegrate back into society.ASP Keonz shared that this was his second year of involvement and added that before he was involved, he had participated as a runner, together with his family.

During the Yellow Ribbon Project (YRP) Run 2015, we caught up with Chief Warder (CW) Liu Zhiqiang who was involved in the management of volunteers before and during the event.Along with the volunteers, CW Zhiqiang was stationed at the water point distributing drinks to participants who had just completed the run. When asked why he had agreed to be involved, CW Zhiqiang replied that he felt that the YRP Run is a great platform for the community to come together to show their support towards second chances.He added that it also encourages ex-offenders to better appreciate that their past is history and what is most important is that they fully make use of the present to create a better future for themselves and their loved ones. Stay tuned to this page as we bring to you more features of officers who were involved.

Last month, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) paid tribute to its Pioneer Prison Officers for their invaluable contributions in keeping Singapore safe and secure over the past few decades. Of the 184 Pioneers who attended the SPS Pioneers Appreciation Dinner 2015, we had the opportunity to speak with several of them, including Mr Suppiah Mahalingam (pictured left) and Mr Ekhuan Bin Sawal (right). When asked what it takes for someone to be a true, blue Captain of Lives, Mr Mahalingam highlighted the importance of self-confidence when carrying out the various tasks, as well as the importance of personal development through education and training. Mr Ekhuan added that it was highly necessary that prison officers remain firm, yet fair in their daily interaction with inmates, as well as the importance of proper planning before each task is being carried out.Through exemplifying integrity, resilience and strength, these SPS Pioneers have left a legacy for current and future generations of prison officers to mirror in times to come.COL50Things

During the Yellow Ribbon Prison (YRP) Run 2015, we caught up with several Singapore Prison Service Officers to find out more about their involvement during the significant event.One of the officers we met was Rehabilitation Officer (RO), Ahmad Sophan Bin Basir Ahmad, who was placed in charge of the Rehabilitation Exhibition located at the carnival.As a firm believer of the Yellow Ribbon Project, RO Sophan shared that this was the second year of his involvement in the YRP Run and added that he enjoys how the community comes together to pave the way for acceptance during the annual run. Sophan also recounted some of his personal encounters with ex-offenders who were able to change for the better, through the encouragement and support of the community and the people around them. He highlighted how through his encouragement and advice to an ex-offender to focus on learning, instead of pressurizing himself to change, the ex-offender was able to take practical actions in his daily life, which has in turn enabled him to be successful in life, having fostered strong relations with his family and is a proud owner of a cupcake business.Stay tuned to this page as we bring to you more features of officers who were involved.

Having worked with several community partners in the planning and implementation of volunteering programs, Mr Mohamed Fazly Bin Mohamed Jamaludin, Assistant Director, Community and Family Engagement, has seen how important volunteers are in the rehabilitation process of offenders and their families.To him, volunteers play a crucial role in helping offenders turn their lives around and stay crime-free after their release. He also sees them as a symbol of the communitys willingness to give offenders a second chance. Some volunteers have helped provide religious counselling and guidance during the offenders incarceration, while others have volunteered as befrienders, providing the much-needed friendship and social and emotional support for offenders before and after their release he adds.To find out more about the roles of volunteers and the volunteering opportunities available at the Singapore Prison Service, do visit:

At the annual Volunteer Awards Ceremony, Singapore Prison Service honoured over 190 individual volunteers and welfare organisations for their selfless contributions towards the lives of ex-offenders, inmates and their families.One such recipient of the Three-Year Long Service Award was Befriender, Mr Azman Bin Osman.Mr Azman started volunteering in 1989 with the Singapore Anti-Narcotics Association (SANA), providing support towards SANAs various aftercare efforts.Presently, as a befriender at SPS release centre, the 47-year old aircraft engineer takes time out of his busy schedule to meet with the inmates that he currently volunteers with. Throughout his three years volunteering with SPS, Mr Azman has worked with inmates from all walks of life, providing them with the counsel and emotional support that they need, to help them be better prepared for potential challenges that they might face after their release.When asked what keeps him going as a volunteer, Mr Azman replied, When I see the inmates that I work with change for the better, I am inspired to continue the work that I do with them.

Last week, the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) paid tribute to 155 volunteers for their unwavering support and contributions towards the rehabilitation and reintegration of offenders. The Singapore Prison Service Volunteers Awards Ceremony (PVAC) was graced by Second Minister for Home Affairs Mr. Masagos Zulkfli, who highlighted the importance of community support.In his speech, he commended the volunteers for their guidance, whether it was through religious counselling or in providing offenders with the much-needed friendship and support. He also added that Volunteers play a crucial role in helping offenders turn their lives around and stay crime-free after their release. Once again, we would like to express our heartfelt appreciation to all the volunteers who have played a significant role in the rehabilitation journey of offenders!

As part of the SG50 celebrations, we interviewed our Pioneer Prison Officers to better understand how the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) has evolved into the correctional agency that it is today, which focuses not just on the rehabilitation of offenders, but enforces their secure custody as well.Having joined the service in 1972, Mr. Leo Teng Jit served SPS for over 33 years before retiring in 2006.During his course of work, Mr. Leo has seen how SPS has progressed over the years, with the enhancement of the Changi Prison Complex infrastructure, which ensures the security of the prison compound. Mr. Leo also noted that the quality of the rehabilitation programmes and community engagements and volunteers have increased tremendously in line with the evolving needs of the inmates.Mr. Leo believes that development should not stop here, and encourages present-day prison officers to keep abreast of the changes in the correctional sector and perform their very best in the duties laid before them. Join us in commemorating the efforts taken by our Pioneers who have helped built Singapore to what it is today, a safe country for all!WhenWeWereYoung

Get up close and personal with the Home Team at this years Home Team Festival - the largest public showcase of the Home Teams capabilities! Themed Home Safe Home this year, this biennial exhibition will take place over three days from 13 - 15 November 2015 at the Singapore Expo.Find out more about the various Home Team Departments and how they work together as one, and with the community, to keep Singapore safe and secure.Follow Home Team News (Singapore) for more updates with regards to the upcoming event!

Earlier this year, several Home Team (HT) Pioneers were honoured at the Tribute to Home Team Pioneers event for their dedication in building a strong foundation for a safe and secure Singapore.It was indeed a great pleasure to have met Mr. Muthucomarasamy s/o Arumugam at the event. Having started his career as a prison officer in 1957, Mr. Muthu was involved in the setting up of the first drug rehabilitation centre, Selarang Park DRC. Despite the limited resources, Mr. Muthu understood the importance of infrastructure planning to eliminate security threats and staff management. He did his best to support his subordinates by caring for their well-being, as well as training them so that they could perform better at work. Through his dedication and perseverance, Mr. Muthu became the first Assistant Director in charge of all the Drug Rehabilitation Centres, from which he retired at age 53 in 1986. In summing up his 29 years of service, the 83 year old said that it was his belief that people could change for the better when they were provided with the right avenues that had kept him going for over three decades.WhenWeWereYoung

Mr S Iswaran, Minister, Prime Minister's Office, Second Minister for Home Affairs and Second Minister for Trade and Industry highlighted how our pioneer officers remained steadfast in carrying out their duties despite working with limited resources and makeshift facilities. Along with members of SPS senior management, he presented commemorative medallions to our pioneers for their dedicated service.

Tonight, at the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) Appreciation Night, we pay tribute to our pioneers in recognition of their invaluable contributions to our organisation. One hundred and eighty four pioneer SPS officers will be presented with commemorative medallions by Guest-of-Honour, Mr S Iswaran, Minister, Prime Minister's Office and Second Minister for Home Affairs and Trade and Industry as well as members of the SPS senior management team.

Entering his eight year of service with the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) is truly significant for Chief Warder (CW) Mohamad Faizal Bin Noh, especially since he was one of the 36 outstanding Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) officers who were recently awarded the MHA-Liverpool Degree Sponsorship Programme Award.CW Faizal mentioned that transiting back to the life of a full-time student after 12 years may not be easy for him. However, we are confident that CW Faizals deep desire for personal growth and aspirations to better his current role as Chief Personal Supervisor would motivate him to do his best.CW Faizal shared that his Coach, Assistant Superintendent of Prisons (ASP) Dylan Teo was instrumental in his decision to pursue his further studies; having given him the much-needed encouragement and timely advice. In pursuing your further studies, it is important to discuss with your close ones. The support will definitely be helpful in the journey ahead said CW Faizal, who is very excited to start his Degree programme in September this year.

Following the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) Sponsorship Awards Presentation Ceremony 2015, we caught up with the recipient of the part-time Degree Sponsorship Award, Staff Sergeant (SSGT) Fadhlur Rahman Bin Md Yat.As a Senior Personal Supervisor at the Tanah Merah Prison (TMP), SSGT Fadhlur helps create an environment that is safe and convenient for inmates to study in. Aligned with TMPs motto: Awakening hope, Rebuilding lives, SSGT Fadhlur hopes that his effort in facilitating education for the inmates would help build confidence, and in turn motivate them to be responsible citizens in the future.As a strong believer in lifelong learning, not only within the capacity of his work, but on a personal level as well, SSGT Fadhlur has chosen to take up the Bachelor of Psychology with Security Studies offered by the Singapore Institute of Management University. He believes that the course would level up his knowledge of the changes in the current correctional landscape and make him a better Captain of Lives.

At the Home Team National Day Observance Ceremony 2015 which took place yesterday, Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean paid tribute to 104 Home Team officers for their contributions in keeping Singapore a safe and secure home for all.Staff Sergeant (SSGT) Kelvin Tier was one of the many Singapore Prison Service (SPS) officers who received the Minister for Home Affairs National Day Awards; having displayed exceptional courage and selfless behavior when performing their duties.When asked how he felt about this significant milestone in his career, SSGT Kelvin humbly replied that it had reminded him of why he chose to switch careers in the first place. He also added that he wants to continue to be that change agent, inspiring the offenders under his charge to reach their potential.We would like to congratulate all our Captain of Lives who received their awards yesterday. May we continue to do our best at work, and upkeep a safe Singapore for all!

Our heartiest congratulations to the 19 Singapore Prison Service (SPS) officers who received their awards at the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) Sponsorship Awards Ceremony on the 25th of July 2015.It was truly inspiring to see them receive their awards from Second Minister for Trade and Industry and Home Affairs, Mr. S Iswaran, to the delight and cheers from their family members.We wish you all the very best.. Continue to put your best foot forward in all that you do and make SPS proud!

In light of the SG50 celebrations, we will be sharing with you a little more about how we have evolved over the years.For todays special, we are featuring the Institutional Control Centre (ICC), which oversees the institutions muster and movements of inmates during admissions, transfers and visits.The ICC also process and regulate the entry and exit of staff, service providers and visitors to and from the institutions. This adds another layer of defense against unauthorised entry and exit.To strengthen security within the institutions, much effort was placed on redesigning and reengineering infrastructure and work processes.Besides replacing the outdated CRT monitors with LCD panels, the overall ICC console setup was also revamped to enhance monitoring capabilities as well as feature a new detachability function that permits console maneuverability during contingencies.With such a retrofit, the operational response by Institution Operations Officers during contingencies has been significantly enhanced.Do stay tuned to this page as we bring you more memories from the past!WhenWeWereYoung

In light of the SG50 celebrations, we will be sharing with you a little more about our earlier days.For todays special, we are featuring the Special Action Prisons Unit, which was formed on the 1st of December, 1977.Having embodied the principles: Swift, Accurate, Powerful and United, the units role in the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) was a critical one, having quelled any possible prison disturbances quickly and efficiently.To ensure that its officers were equipped to handle contingencies such as riots, disturbances or any other situations which required the mass evacuation of inmates, much effort was placed on their training, in addition to their high standards of discipline and physical fitness.They were taught various specialist skills such as unarmed combat, fast roping, and high wall scaling (now more commonly known as rappelling). Do browse through the pictures which showcase highlights of the trainings that were conducted back then, and stay tuned to this page as we bring you more memories from the past!WhenWeWereYoung

After spending a few years in the financial sector, Assistant Superintendent of Prisons (ASP) Koh Xueliang felt that his career had become mundane with the excessive number crunching and numerous KPIs. Upon careful reflection, he decided to apply for a position with the Singapore Prison Service.Today, he not only manages a diverse group of inmates, but carefully selects various beneficial vocational training to aid these inmates in their rehabilitation journey.Some of the trainings he has successfully put in place include Information Technology (IT) and Literacy courses, with the objective of rehabilitating these inmates towards a safe society without re-offending.He shares that the greatest reward is seeing the change in inmates and their active contribution to society upon their release.The most memorable incident he recounts was when an inmate, whom he had previously selected for a barbering course had volunteered at the Hair for Hope event as a barber after his release. Koh added, I felt truly happy for him and proud of my work. This further strengthened my conviction and belief in the work that I do. COL50Things

Prison officers are in charge of maintaining a high level of security and discipline in the institutions. Hence, to ensure that they are agile during their course of work, officers undergo over seven weeks of tactical and defensive training at the Prison Staff Training School (PSTS). The tactical training includes the deployment of the Protect and Restraint 24 (PR24) baton, the Oleoresin Capsicum Delivery System (OCDS) and the use of a suite of mechanical restraint equipment, amongst other restraint and defensive techniques.Scenario-based training is a key component of the tactical training. Officers will be put through various scenarios depicting the common minor disturbances and issues in mock-up environments which simulate the actual operational settings of the prison housing units. This would help prepare them to handle challenges they may face during their operational duties.COL50Things

Entering into his sixteenth year with the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) is indeed a truly significant one for Chief Warder 2, Mohamed Israq Bin Mohamed Salim, especially since he was recently commended for his exceptional contribution and service at the SPS-SCORE Corporate Advance 2015. An award given to acknowledge officers who have maintained high standards of work excellence and well-rounded work-life balance.Receiving the Outstanding Captain of Lives 2015 Award has indeed motivated him to excel further in his work as a Tactical Trainer at the Singapore Prisons Emergency Action Response (SPEAR) force where he is not just tasked with the responsibility of training new SPEAR recruits, but also to sense the ground for development of tactics, evaluating new products, technologies and recommend it for enhancing the units capabilities.To ensure that he performs well at his given task, CW Israq lives by three simple values: performing every task with due sincerity, giving his one hundred percent at all times and ensuring that he is always kept focused on SPS vision of inspiring everyone, at every chance, towards a society without re-offending, creating a safe and secure Singapore.COL50Things

Prison officers are expected to maintain a high level of physical fitness during their course of work. This is why much emphasis is placed on physical training at the Prison Staff Training School (PSTS). As trainees progress during the course of their training, physical training gets more demanding, leading up to a symbolic 10km run for trainees to build on their endurance level, as well as to develop team spirit amongst the entire cohort.During our recent visit to the PSTS, we spoke with Assistant Superintendent (ASP) Gladys Lim Shu Yu, who shared that the physical training has not just helped her identify her strengths and weaknesses, but has also helped develop her willpower and determination.She added, I now understand what Helen Keller meant when she said: Alone we can do so little, together we can do so much. It is indeed important to work together as one and to render our help and support to one another so as to see the entire team move to greater heights. COL50Things

Last month, the Singapore Prisons Emergency Action Response (SPEAR) Force was awarded 2nd place during the United States Mock Prison Riot (MPR) Competition 2015.Rehabilitation Officer (RO) Rohaizad Bin Mohamed Athmad, Chief Warder (CW) Ang Kien Hong, Staff Sergeant (SSGT) Tow Chee Choy, SSGT Nur Effendy Bin Said, SSGT Cleve Mu Weiqiang and SSGT Yeo Bo Li made up the 6-man strong SPEAR team that participated in the 4-day competition.Held annually on the grounds of the decommissioned West Virginia Penitentiary in Moundsville, the MPR seeks to provide realistic training opportunities for law enforcement and corrections practitioners from all over the world.The competition proved to be highly beneficial to the SPEAR team, exposing them not only to a wide array of security equipment and gears, but to the various techniques employed by law enforcement practitioners across the world.Upon learning of the teams accomplishment, SSGT Cleve Mu Weiqiang shared that, In coming together with a common goal, the team managed to leverage on each others strengths and shortcomings We hope that the upcoming teams will also be inspired to follow our footsteps to success.

Following the Yellow Ribbon Song Writing Competition 2015 last week, we caught up with Superintendent (SUPT) Nikki Abdullah @ Won Tien Li, Assistant Commander, Cluster B Programme and Chairperson of the Yellow Ribbon Song Writing Organising Committee 2015.A big part of her role in the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) involves overseeing the strategic planning and implementation of rehabilitative programmes suited to the different groups of inmates. This is to help them realise their potential as responsible and productive citizens in society.Apart from providing inmates with such opportunities to help them in their rehabilitation journeys, SUPT Won also sees herself as a custodian, ensuring not just the rehabilitation of inmates but the safe custody of those under her care as well.When asked how she successfully juggles her responsibilities as a prison officer, mother and a wife, she said, I give my best in all areas and appreciate the rewards and fulfilment that each role gives me In all that I do, I find meaning and inspiration, and that spurs me on. COL50Things

At the Prison Staff Training School (PSTS), officers undergo academic training, which equips them with the necessary knowledge and skills required of a prison officer.The lessons are centered largely on jailcraft principles and rehabilitation concepts that will allow them to perform their roles in keeping the Singapore Prisons safe and secure, as well to help offenders in their rehabilitation journey.Another key component of the training at PSTS is leadership development. The leadership training programme serves to prepare officers for leadership roles and to develop their capacity to lead.Upon completion of the residential phase, officers will be posted to the prison institutions for the On-the-Job Training (OJT) where they will be able to apply their acquired knowledge and skills under the supervision and guidance of the operational staff.COL50Things

After completing her Bachelors Degree in Sociology, Assistant Superintendent (ASP) Gladys Lim Shu Yu joined the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) as the principles: rehab, renew and restart resonated very well with her. She wanted to play her part in inspiring change, so as to create a safer society without re-offending.Being in the eighteenth week of her training at the Prison Staff Training School (PSTS) now, she shares that the biggest challenge lie in mastering various skills and knowledge within a stipulated time. This challenge has however helped strengthen her emotionally, mentally and physically. I am now not only able to endure more, but am able to take on more lead roles, she adds. She describes her favourite segment of the training to be the experiential learning, having had the opportunity to visit the various clusters and learn through hands-on experiences.Her advice to those interested in becoming a Captain of Lives is to Always have the desire to constantly strive, improve and excel. Embrace challenges as they come and use them as a platform to improve yourself. COL50Things

As a graduate of Republic Polytechnic in Diploma of Sports and Leisure Management and a recipient of the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) HOME Award, Sergeant (SGT) Zulkifli Bin Zakaria joined the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) as he wanted a challenging career that would allow him to impact the lives of others.Being in the sixteenth week of his training at the Prison Staff Training School (PSTS), he shares that the comprehensive nature of the training has enabled him to master key skills, such as discipline, leadership and agility- all which is highly essential in his course of work.He describes his favourite segment of the training program to be the tactical training, which has taught him to use a suite of mechanical restraint equipment, the deployment of the Protect and Restraint 24 (PR 24) baton and the Oleoresin Capsicum Delivery System (OCDS). His advice to present trainees and those interested to join SPS is to always give your best and ensure you have a positive mindset during the training programme, as the training would help build your confidence and develop you personally and in your career. COL50Things

Leveraging on technology is key in enhancing our capabilities. Find out how we have evolved with improvements in technology here!During his many years in service, Chief Warder (CW) Mohamad Nizam B Supri has first-handedly seen how the role of a prison officer has evolved over the years taking on more responsibilities while managing an even more diverse inmate population.He shares that one of the biggest changes include various technological advancements which aid in daily operations and the management of inmates. One such example he points out, is the development of PORTS, an inmate data-management system which is built toward ensuring the safe custody of inmates and the personnel within.Other than the introduction of the above system, CW Nizam notes that another key milestone of the Singapore Prison Service is the greater attention which has been given to aftercare. This focuses on the reintegration of ex-offenders into society, and in turn helps reduce recidivism rates, resulting in a safer and secure Singapore.COL50Things

In her speech at the National Youth Achievement Award (NYAA) Presentation Ceremony 2015, Guest-of-Honour, Senior Minister of State for Law and Education, Ms. Indranee Rajah spoke about the importance of encouraging young offenders to develop personal qualities of self-reliance, perseverance and a sense of responsibility, not only to themselves, but to society and the nation.This year, over 96 young offenders took part in the NYAA programme, which comprised of several character-building activities including community service projects, skills development courses and expedition/ exploration course, which helped encourage the spirit of adventure and discovery.The Singapore Prison Service continues to work with private-sector partners and the community, so as to provide offenders with the support and opportunities that they need in their rehabilitation journey. Through the successful implementation of programmes such as the NYAA, we are able to better impact and inspire change.

Following the National Youth Achievement Award (NYAA) Presentation Ceremony 2015, we caught up with Assistant Superintendent of Prisons (ASP) Nurazura Mohamed Jani, who was one of the NYAA coordinators this year.A big part of her role in the Singapore Prison Service involves introducing programmes suited to the risks and needs of inmates, so as to help them in their rehabilitation journey.She mentions that, Apart from ensuring that the right programmes are catered to inmates to steer them on towards change, we maintain discipline and ensure the safe and secure custody of inmates. The drive towards positive change should not only start upon an inmates release but during their incarceration she added. Thus, as a prison officer, she understands the multiple roles that she has to take on to see that change happen.

The National Youth Achievement Awards (NYAA) Presentation Ceremony will be held on Thursday, 23rd April 2015 at the Tanah Merah Prison. Since the implementation of the NYAA programme in the year 2000, more than 1460 awards have been given out to inmates between the ages of 18 and 25. This year, a total of 96 inmates qualified for the NYAA awards, after having completed several non-competitive activities, which were centered on helping them develop personal qualities of self-reliance, perseverance and a sense of responsibility not only to themselves, but to society and the nation as well.The Singapore Prison Service is committed to providing inmates with the support and opportunities needed for them to rehabilitate, so that they can break out from the cycle of re-offending and be contributors to society. By successfully impacting change, we are able to create a safer nation for all.

As a productive member of society, anyone has the ability to be a source of inspiration to others.Reintegration Officer (RO), Tann Yi Ru shares with us what she does to inspire those around her.Do you recall a time when you were a source of inspiration to others around you? We would love to hear from you! Have a fruitful Wednesday!COLinspire

Being a Captain of Lives mean wearing many hats, including that of a disciplinarian, a teacher and a counsel.We spoke to Senior Chief Warder, Mohamad Safrin Bin Saptu who shared that inspiring involves changing peoples perceptions about themselves.Do also share with us what being inspired or inspiring others mean to you. Have a lovely week ahead!COLinspire

This week, our officers stood up with their heads held high as the Singapore flag was raised in remembrance of all the efforts our founding Prime Minister, Mr Lee Kuan Yew had made to build this nation.Let us stay true to the ideals that our founding father fought for and remind ourselves to continue striving to realize his vision of a fair, meritocratic nation that stays united.RememberingLKYTributeToLKY

With a very heavy heart, Head, Civil Service, Mr Peter Ong wrote a heartfelt tribute after the passing of the founding Prime Minister of Singapore, Mr Lee Kuan Yew.In his tribute, he noted how Mr Lee served Singapore, transforming the country into one that is peaceful, cohesive and prosperous.He praised Mr Lees legendary attention to detail, his exacting performance standards and the clarity of purpose he applied to every problem, on top of his unwavering dedication in keeping Singapore successful. As we mourn the passing of a great leader, an astute statesman and an exceptional Singaporean, let us seek to emulate his passion and dedication in serving Singapore and Singaporeans. Let that be Mr Lees legacy to the Singapore Public Service, Mr Ong concluded.RememberingLKYTributeToLKY
A minute of silence as our Captains of Lives in honour of our founding Prime Minister Mr Lee Kuan Yew. RememberingLKY TributeToLKY
Captains of Lives take time to reflect on the valuable lessons Mr Lee has imparted RememberingLKY TributeToLKY
Tributes line the wall as Captains of Lives gather early this morning to honour the late Mr Lee. RememberingLKY TributeToLKY

In a glowing tribute to the late Mr Lee Kuan Yew, US President Barack Obama hailed the founding Prime Minister as a visionary who led his country from independence in 1965 to build one of the most prosperous countries in the world today. He further added that Mr Lee was a devoted public servant and a remarkable leader who will be remembered for generations to come as the father of modern Singapore.RememberingLKYTributeToLKY

Today we mourn the passing of founding Prime Minister, Mr Lee Kuan Yew, who was also known to many as the father of our nation. Mr Lee was instrumental in creating the Public Service ethos which Captains of Lives continue to emulate efficient, effective and exceptional. In this moment of grief, Captains of Lives will continue to imbibe the spirit of resilience, determination and courage exemplified by Mr Lee and honour his remarkable leadership, laying the foundation for Singapores success against the odds. Thank you for your dedication, determination and passion Mr Lee. Your contributions to Singapore will be remembered for generations to come.If you would like to express your condolences and share your memories of the late Mr Lee, visit the official website:

During his course of work, Superintendent Sebastian Liew Kok Keong has been involved in several developments, aimed at fostering closer bonds and kinship between inmates and their loved ones.One such development he feels fortunate to have been involved in is the Visit Management System. Apart from the Prison Link Centre (PLC) situated in Changi, there are two other PLCs located at Geylang Bahru and Jurong East, as well as several other satellite tele-visit centres managed by community partners to better accommodate to the needs of inmates visitors.Additionally, with the proliferation of smart phone technology, PLCs have started exploring the use of mobile applications for visit-related matters, such as visit bookings and the updating of contact information.Fostering closer ties between inmates and their families through a development as such would help smoothen the rehabilitation process and result in a smoother road to recovery. When we have helped an offender to rehabilitate and reintegrate, we help to create a safer Singapore for all.COL50Things

Following the Commissioner Awards, we caught up with Chief Warder 2 Ponnarasi D/O Gopal Chandra, recipient of the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) Long Service & Good Conduct- 10 years Medal.She attributes this significant milestone to the strong teamwork fostered within her cluster. Knowing that there are people who would stand by her side during challenges gives her the courage and assurance to persevere at work, she adds.Apart from teamwork, CW2 Ponnarasi also believes that every organisation should continue to develop their capabilities so that tasks may be carried out more efficiently. One such example, she points out is the clusterisation-technology, which assists officers with the locking and unlocking of doors in the prison so that prison officers can do more value-added work as professionals.As part of SPSs Integrated Security System (ISS), leveraging on technological advancements would further enable each cluster to fulfill SPSs mission of protecting society through the safe and secure custody of offenders.COL50Things

Historic Diplomat and American Statesman John Quincy Adams once said, If your actions inspire others to dream more, learn more, do more and become more, you are a leader. Here was what Assistant Superintendent 2 Muhammad Rizaluddin Bin Abdul Razak had to say.Do share with us what being inspired or inspiring others mean to you. Have a pleasant week ahead!COLinspire

Following the Opening Ceremony of the Community Rehabilitation Centre (CRC), a facility to help young drug offenders, we spoke to Mr Kelvin Hoo, Superintendent of the CRC who shared with us a little more about the centres objectives: The CRC is a customised regime aimed at mitigating the risk of re-offending for the under-21 drug offender population. By situating the CRC in the community, it would help facilitate greater community involvement in the programmes that these young drug offenders undergo.

What does it take to be a Singapore Prisons Emergency Action Response (SPEAR) Officer? Read on to find out more about the 3 Personality Types who will succeed as a SPEAR Officer.1. THE TEAM-PLAYERSPEARs Tactical Rappeling and Closed Quartered Restrained Techniques require a collective effort from the group. Hence, motivations given to one another in a must-have for every member of the team.2. THE LEADERIn a team, everyone is a leader. You must be driven to ensure that every team member is working together and that the mission is accomplished without any casualties.3. THE PASSIONATEThe rigorous trainings are for the physically fit. But if your passion burns for the role of SPEAR, being fit is easy. It can be a rewarding and fulfilling career to embark on!

As Singapore began to move towards independence in the 1950s, there was an increasing call for public service to 'malayanise'. Malaynise is the term used for locals to replace expatriate staffs in the prison service. In 1956, 61 out of 65 were expatriate prison staffs. Two officers, Mr. Yeow Koon Poh and Mr. Quek Shi Lei were selected to be sent to UK for training. They returned and later, became directors of prisons.
As Captains of Lives, we aspire to guide and inspire a positive attitude. We provide them an array of programmes so that they can better themselves before their release.

On 6th February 1847, Pearls Hill Civil Jail (also known as Outram Road Jail) was built. This civil jail housed prisoners waiting for trial and debtors. The prisoners were classified according to race, and the nature of crime they committed.

At SPS, we understand the need to get those under our custody to focus on getting back on their feet.Our Captains of Lives engage offenders regularly and help provide windows of opportunities for them. Taking that first step is tough but with adequate support and encouragement they can focus on creating and achieving milestones.

Weve come a long way since Prisons inception in 1825. This picture was taken when the first batch of offenders were housed in temporary huts along Bras Basah Canal. The philosophy of deterrence was adopted until the system of rehabilitation was introduced in 1974.Picture Source: GhettoSingapore.comAbout: Every week in February, we bring you The Evolution of Singapore Prison Service. A series aimed to enlighten your curiosity. This months theme is Infrastructure.
